class="mw-indicators mw-body-content">\n</div>\n<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Culture of the United Kingdom</h1>\t\t\t<div id="bodyContent" Kingdom">Coat of arms</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">\n<ul><li href="/wiki/Portal:United_Kingdom" title="Portal:United Kingdom">United Kingdom &#32;portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Promsinthepark2008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Promsinthepark2008.jpg/250px-Promsinthepark2008.jpg" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Promsinthepark2008.jpg/375px-Promsinthepark2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Promsinthepark2008.jpg/500px-Promsinthepark2008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Promsinthepark2008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Proms" title="The Proms">The Proms</a> is an eight-week summer season of daily classical music concerts, culminating with a final night of traditional <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Music of the United Kingdom">patriotic music</a>.</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg/250px-Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg" width="250" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg/375px-Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg/500px-Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2128" data-file-height="1416" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_wedding_street_party.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Street_party" class="mw-redirect" title="Street party">street party</a> at a primary school in Lancashire, England, on the occasion of the <a href="/wiki/Wedding_of_Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge,_and_Catherine_Middleton" class="mw-redirect" title="Wedding of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, and Catherine Middleton">wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The <b>culture of the United Kingdom</b> is influenced by the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">UK\'s history</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">state</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracy</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>; its predominantly <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Religion in the United Kingdom">religious life</a>; and its composition of <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">four countries</a>\xe2\x80\x94<a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>\xe2\x80\x94each of which has distinct customs, <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">cultures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Symbols_of_the_United_Kingdom,_the_Channel_Islands_and_the_Isle_of_Man" class="mw-redirect" title="Symbols of the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man">symbolism</a>. The wider <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">culture of Europe</a> has also influenced British culture, and <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">Humanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a> developed from broader <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">British literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Music of the United Kingdom">music</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="British cinema">cinema</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Art of the United Kingdom">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Theatre of the United Kingdom">theatre</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_comedy" title="British comedy">comedy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Media_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Media of the United Kingdom">media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Television in the United Kingdom">television</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_philosophy" title="British philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Architecture of the United Kingdom">architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Education in the United Kingdom">education</a> are important aspects of British culture. The United Kingdom is also prominent in science and technology, producing world-leading scientists (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a>) and inventions. Sport is an important part of British culture; numerous sports originated in the country, including <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. The UK has been described as a "cultural superpower",<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> has been described as a world cultural capital.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> A global opinion poll for the BBC saw the UK ranked the third most positively viewed nation in the world (behind Germany and Canada) in 2013 and 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, which started in the UK, had a profound effect on the family <a href="/wiki/Socioeconomics" title="Socioeconomics">socio-economic</a> and cultural conditions of the world. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, significant British influence can be observed in the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">law</a>, culture and institutions of a geographically wide assortment of countries, including Australia, Canada, India, the Republic of Ireland, New Zealand, Nigeria, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, the United States and English speaking Caribbean nations. These states are sometimes collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Anglosphere" title="Anglosphere">Anglosphere</a>, and are among Britain\'s closest allies.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> In turn the empire also influenced British culture, particularly <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_England" title="Culture of England">cultures of England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Scotland" title="Culture of Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Wales" title="Culture of Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Culture of Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> are diverse and have varying degrees of overlap and distinctiveness.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Language"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Language</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Regional_accents"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Regional accents</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Arts"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Arts</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Theatre"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Theatre</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#Cinema"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Cinema</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#Broadcasting"><span class="tocnumber">2.5</span> <span class="toctext">Broadcasting</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9"><a href="#Print"><span class="tocnumber">2.6</span> <span class="toctext">Print</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#Visual_arts"><span class="tocnumber">2.7</span> <span class="toctext">Visual arts</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Performing_arts,_carnivals,_parades"><span class="tocnumber">2.8</span> <span class="toctext">Performing arts, carnivals, parades</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-12"><a href="#Architecture"><span class="tocnumber">2.9</span> <span class="toctext">Architecture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-13"><a href="#Comics"><span class="tocnumber">2.10</span> <span class="toctext">Comics</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#Honours_system"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Honours system</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-15"><a href="#Folklore"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Folklore</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-16"><a href="#National_parks,_museums,_libraries,_and_galleries"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">National parks, museums, libraries, and galleries</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17"><a href="#Heritage_administration"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Heritage administration</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-18"><a href="#Museums_and_galleries"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Museums and galleries</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Libraries"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Libraries</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Historical_markers"><span class="tocnumber">5.4</span> <span class="toctext">Historical markers</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-21"><a href="#Counties"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Counties</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-22"><a href="#Science_and_technology"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Science and technology</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Industrial_Revolution"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Industrial Revolution</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-24"><a href="#Religion"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Religion</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-25"><a href="#Politics"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Politics</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-26"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-27"><a href="#Sport"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Sport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-28"><a href="#System_of_measurement,_roads"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">System of measurement, roads</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-29"><a href="#Healthcare"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">Healthcare</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-30"><a href="#Pets"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">Pets</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-31"><a href="#National_costume_and_dress"><span class="tocnumber">15</span> <span class="toctext">National costume and dress</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32"><a href="#Fashion"><span class="tocnumber">15.1</span> <span class="toctext">Fashion</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-33"><a href="#Symbols,_flags,_and_emblems"><span class="tocnumber">16</span> <span class="toctext">Symbols, flags, and emblems</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-34"><a href="#Traditional_communication_and_greeting_cards"><span class="tocnumber">17</span> <span class="toctext">Traditional communication and greeting cards</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-35"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">18</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-36"><a href="#Sociological_issues"><span class="tocnumber">19</span> <span class="toctext">Sociological issues</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37"><a href="#Housing"><span class="tocnumber">19.1</span> <span class="toctext">Housing</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38"><a href="#Living_arrangements"><span class="tocnumber">19.2</span> <span class="toctext">Living arrangements</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39"><a href="#Happiness"><span class="tocnumber">19.3</span> <span class="toctext">Happiness</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Feminism"><span class="tocnumber">19.4</span> <span class="toctext">Feminism</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-41"><a href="#Anglophilia"><span class="tocnumber">20</span> <span class="toctext">Anglophilia</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42"><a href="#Naming_conventions"><span class="tocnumber">21</span> <span class="toctext">Naming conventions</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-43"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">22</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-44"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">23</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-45"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">24</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-46"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">25</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Language">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Languages of the United Kingdom">Languages of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BLBeowulf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/BLBeowulf.jpg/170px-BLBeowulf.jpg" width="170" height="261" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/BLBeowulf.jpg/255px-BLBeowulf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/BLBeowulf.jpg/340px-BLBeowulf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="785" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BLBeowulf.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Anglo_Saxon" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglo Saxon">Anglo Saxon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">Old English</a> heroic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Beowulf" title="Beowulf">Beowulf</a></i> is located in the British Library.</div></div></div>\n<p>First spoken in <a href="/wiki/Early_medieval_England" class="mw-redirect" title="Early medieval England">early medieval England</a>, the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a> is the <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> of the UK, and is spoken monolingually by an estimated 95% of the <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Demography of the United Kingdom">British population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Individual countries within the UK have frameworks for the promotion of their indigenous languages. In Wales, all pupils at state schools must either be taught through the medium of <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> or study it as an additional language until age 16, and the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Language_Act_1993" title="Welsh Language Act 1993">Welsh Language Act 1993</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Wales_Act_1998" title="Government of Wales Act 1998">Government of Wales Act 1998</a> provide that the Welsh and English languages should be treated equally in the public sector, so far as is reasonable and practicable. Irish and <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulster Scots language">Ulster Scots</a> enjoy limited use alongside English in Northern Ireland, mainly in publicly commissioned translations. The <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Language_(Scotland)_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act">Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act</a>, passed by the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Scottish Parliament</a> in 2005, recognised <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Gaelic</a> as an official language of Scotland, commanding equal respect with English, and required the creation of a national plan for Gaelic to provide strategic direction for the development of the Gaelic language.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;note 2&#93;</a></sup> A 2010 poll among Scots saw a majority view <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a> as a dialect of English and not a separate language.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish language</a> enjoys neither official recognition nor promotion by the state in <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>.\n</p><p>Under the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">UK Government</a> has committed to the promotion of certain linguistic traditions. The United Kingdom has ratified the charter for: Welsh (in Wales), Scottish Gaelic and Scots (in Scotland), Cornish (in Cornwall), and <a href="/wiki/Irish_language_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Irish language in Northern Ireland">Irish</a> and Ulster Scots (in Northern Ireland). <a href="/wiki/British_Sign_Language" title="British Sign Language">British Sign Language</a> is also a recognised language.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_accents">Regional accents</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Regional accents">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg/180px-Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg" width="180" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg/270px-Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg/360px-Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg 2x" data-file-width="489" data-file-height="620" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Harry_Stradling-Audrey_Hepburn_in_My_Fair_Lady.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn" title="Audrey Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a> as the flower girl <a href="/wiki/Eliza_Doolittle" title="Eliza Doolittle">Eliza Doolittle</a> on the set of the 1964 movie musical <i>My Fair Lady</i>. Receiving elocution lessons to remove her <a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a> accent, she "gets it" when she says "<a href="/wiki/The_Rain_in_Spain" title="The Rain in Spain">The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain</a>".</div></div></div>\n<p>Owing to its long history, dialects and regional accents vary amongst the four <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a>, as well as within the countries themselves. Some nearby cities have different dialects and accents, such as <a href="/wiki/Scouser" class="mw-redirect" title="Scouser">Scousers</a> from Liverpool and <a href="/wiki/Manchester_dialect" title="Manchester dialect">Mancunians</a> from Manchester, which are separated by just 35 miles (56&#160;km). Notable Scouse speakers include <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">Paul McCartney</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a>, while Mancunians include <a href="/wiki/Liam_Gallagher" title="Liam Gallagher">Liam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Noel_Gallagher" title="Noel Gallagher">Noel Gallagher</a> from Oasis.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a> accent is traditionally spoken by working-class Londoners. <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a> is a notable exponent, as is <a href="/wiki/Eliza_Doolittle" title="Eliza Doolittle">Eliza Doolittle</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Pygmalion_(play)" title="Pygmalion (play)">Pygmalion</a></i> (<i>My Fair Lady</i>), whose dialect includes words that are common among working-class Londoners, such as <a href="/wiki/Ain%27t" title="Ain&#39;t">ain\'t</a>: "I ain\'t done nothing wrong", said Doolittle.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a> is the accent of standard English in the UK, with speakers including the <a href="/wiki/British_Royal_Family" class="mw-redirect" title="British Royal Family">British Royal Family</a>. <a href="/wiki/Brummie" class="mw-redirect" title="Brummie">Brummie</a> is the dialect of natives of Birmingham in the West Midlands of England: notable Brummies include rock musicians <a href="/wiki/Ozzy_Osbourne" title="Ozzy Osbourne">Ozzy Osbourne</a> (and all of <a href="/wiki/Black_Sabbath" title="Black Sabbath">Black Sabbath</a>), <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Lynne" title="Jeff Lynne">Jeff Lynne</a> (ELO), and <a href="/wiki/Rob_Halford" title="Rob Halford">Rob Halford</a> (Judas Priest).<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geordie" title="Geordie">Geordie</a> is the dialect of people from <a href="/wiki/Tyneside" title="Tyneside">Tyneside</a> in northeast England: musicians <a href="/wiki/Brian_Johnson" title="Brian Johnson">Brian Johnson</a> (AC/DC), <a href="/wiki/Mark_Knopfler" title="Mark Knopfler">Mark Knopfler</a> (Dire Straits) and <a href="/wiki/Sting_(musician)" title="Sting (musician)">Sting</a> are Geordies (though Sting has lost much of his Geordie accent and speaks in a standard English accent).<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec" title="Ant &amp; Dec">Ant &amp; Dec</a> are also notable television presenters with Geordie accents.\n</p><p>Notable exponents of <a href="/wiki/Scottish_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Scottish accent">Scottish accents</a> include <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a>, comedian <a href="/wiki/Billy_Connolly" title="Billy Connolly">Billy Connolly</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Proclaimers" title="The Proclaimers">The Proclaimers</a> (their song "<a href="/wiki/I%27m_Gonna_Be_(500_Miles)" title="I&#39;m Gonna Be (500 Miles)">I\'m Gonna Be (500 Miles)</a>" showcases their strong Scottish accent). The <a href="/wiki/West_Country_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="West Country accent">West Country accent</a> from southwest England is identified in film as "<a href="/wiki/Pirate_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirate accent">pirate speech</a>"&#160;&#8211;&#32;cartoon-like "Ooh arr, me \'earties! Sploice the mainbrace!" talk is very similar, while famous pirates hailed from this region, including <a href="/wiki/Blackbeard" title="Blackbeard">Blackbeard</a>; West Country native <a href="/wiki/Robert_Newton" title="Robert Newton">Robert Newton</a>\'s performance as <a href="/wiki/Long_John_Silver" title="Long John Silver">Long John Silver</a> in films standardised the pirate voice.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ulster_English" title="Ulster English">Northern Irish accent</a> includes golfer <a href="/wiki/Rory_McIlroy" title="Rory McIlroy">Rory McIlroy</a> and actor <a href="/wiki/Liam_Neeson" title="Liam Neeson">Liam Neeson</a>, also the actor <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a> adopts a strong Northern Irish accent in <i><a href="/wiki/In_the_Name_of_the_Father_(film)" title="In the Name of the Father (film)">In the Name of the Father</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The actor <a href="/wiki/Russell_Brand" title="Russell Brand">Russell Brand</a> has a strong <a href="/wiki/Essex_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Essex accent">Essex accent</a>, actor <a href="/wiki/Sean_Bean" title="Sean Bean">Sean Bean</a> is known for his distinctive <a href="/wiki/Yorkshire_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Yorkshire accent">Yorkshire accent</a>, the comedian <a href="/wiki/Eric_Morecambe" title="Eric Morecambe">Eric Morecambe</a> possessed a <a href="/wiki/Lancashire_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Lancashire accent">Lancashire accent</a>, while English speakers in a <a href="/wiki/Welsh_English" title="Welsh English">Welsh accent</a> include <a href="/wiki/Michael_Sheen" title="Michael Sheen">Michael Sheen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Jones_(singer)" title="Tom Jones (singer)">Tom Jones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catherine_Zeta-Jones" title="Catherine Zeta-Jones">Catherine Zeta-Jones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/182px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" width="182" height="233" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/273px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/364px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="513" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> is often called the <a href="/wiki/National_poet" title="National poet">national poet</a> of England.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Literature_of_the_United_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Literature of the United Kingdom">Literature of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>At its formation, the United Kingdom inherited the literary traditions of England, Scotland and Wales, including the earliest existing native literature written in the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic languages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_English_literature" title="Old English literature">Old English literature</a> and more recent <a href="/wiki/English_literature" title="English literature">English literature</a> including the works of <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Milton" title="John Milton">John Milton</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Robert_Burns_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Robert_Burns_1.jpg/182px-Robert_Burns_1.jpg" width="182" height="243" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Robert_Burns_1.jpg/273px-Robert_Burns_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Robert_Burns_1.jpg/364px-Robert_Burns_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="798" data-file-height="1067" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Robert_Burns_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Robert_Burns" title="Robert Burns">Robert Burns</a> is regarded as the <a href="/wiki/National_poet" title="National poet">national poet</a> of Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The early 18th century is known as the <a href="/wiki/Augustan_literature" title="Augustan literature">Augustan Age of English literature</a>. The poetry of the time was highly formal, as exemplified by the works of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pope" title="Alexander Pope">Alexander Pope</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/English_novel" title="English novel">English novel</a> became popular, with <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i> (1721), <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Richardson" title="Samuel Richardson">Samuel Richardson</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Pamela,_or_Virtue_Rewarded" class="mw-redirect" title="Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded">Pamela</a></i> (1740) and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Fielding" title="Henry Fielding">Henry Fielding</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_History_of_Tom_Jones,_a_Foundling" title="The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling">Tom Jones</a></i> (1749).\n</p><p>Completed after nine years work, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Johnson" title="Samuel Johnson">Samuel Johnson</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/A_Dictionary_of_the_English_Language" title="A Dictionary of the English Language">A Dictionary of the English Language</a></i> was published in 1755, and was viewed as the pre-eminent British dictionary until the completion of the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> 150 years later.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>From the late 18th century, the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic</a> period showed a flowering of poetry comparable with the Renaissance 200 years earlier, and a revival of interest in <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_literature" title="Vernacular literature">vernacular literature</a>. In Scotland the poetry of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Burns" title="Robert Burns">Robert Burns</a> revived interest in <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a> literature, and the <a href="/wiki/Weaver_Poets" title="Weaver Poets">Weaver Poets</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ulster" title="Ulster">Ulster</a> were influenced by literature from Scotland. In Wales the late 18th century saw the revival of the <a href="/wiki/Eisteddfod" title="Eisteddfod">eisteddfod</a> tradition, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Iolo_Morganwg" title="Iolo Morganwg">Iolo Morganwg</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/A_Vindication_of_the_Rights_of_Woman" title="A Vindication of the Rights of Woman">A Vindication of the Rights of Woman</a></i> (1792), by <a href="/wiki/Mary_Wollstonecraft" title="Mary Wollstonecraft">Mary Wollstonecraft</a>, is one of the earliest works of feminist philosophy.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg/182px-George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg" width="182" height="249" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg/273px-George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg/364px-George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2924" data-file-height="3994" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:George_Charles_Beresford_-_Virginia_Woolf_in_1902_-_Restoration.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a> was a leading modernist writer of the 20th century.</div></div></div>\n<p>Major poets in 19th-century English literature included <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Wordsworth" title="William Wordsworth">William Wordsworth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Taylor_Coleridge" title="Samuel Taylor Coleridge">Samuel Taylor Coleridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Lord_Tennyson" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfred Lord Tennyson">Alfred Lord Tennyson</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Keats" title="John Keats">John Keats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Barrett_Browning" title="Elizabeth Barrett Browning">Elizabeth Barrett Browning</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Lear" title="Edward Lear">Edward Lear</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Limerick_(poetry)" title="Limerick (poetry)">limerick</a>), <a href="/wiki/Percy_Shelley" class="mw-redirect" title="Percy Shelley">Percy Shelley</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Gordon_Byron,_6th_Baron_Byron" class="mw-redirect" title="George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron">Lord Byron</a>. The Victorian era was the golden age of the <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">realistic</a> English novel, with <a href="/wiki/Jane_Austen" title="Jane Austen">Jane Austen</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bront%C3%AB_sisters" class="mw-redirect" title="Bront\xc3\xab sisters">Bront\xc3\xab sisters</a> (<a href="/wiki/Charlotte_Bront%C3%AB" title="Charlotte Bront\xc3\xab">Charlotte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emily_Bront%C3%AB" title="Emily Bront\xc3\xab">Emily</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anne_Bront%C3%AB" title="Anne Bront\xc3\xab">Anne</a>), <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Thackeray" class="mw-redirect" title="William Thackeray">William Thackeray</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Eliot" title="George Eliot">George Eliot</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hardy" title="Thomas Hardy">Thomas Hardy</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> gave rise to British <a href="/wiki/War_poets" class="mw-redirect" title="War poets">war poets</a> and writers such as <a href="/wiki/Wilfred_Owen" title="Wilfred Owen">Wilfred Owen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siegfried_Sassoon" title="Siegfried Sassoon">Siegfried Sassoon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Graves" title="Robert Graves">Robert Graves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rupert_Brooke" title="Rupert Brooke">Rupert Brooke</a> who wrote (often <a href="/wiki/Paradox" title="Paradox">paradoxically</a>) of their expectations of war, and/or their experiences in the <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">trenches</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Roald_Dahl.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Roald_Dahl.jpg/182px-Roald_Dahl.jpg" width="182" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Roald_Dahl.jpg/273px-Roald_Dahl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Roald_Dahl.jpg/364px-Roald_Dahl.jpg 2x" data-file-width="636" data-file-height="859" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Roald_Dahl.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Welsh native <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a> is frequently ranked the best children\'s author in UK polls.<sup id="cite_ref-Dahl1_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dahl1-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The most widely popular writer of the early years of the 20th century was arguably <a href="/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling" title="Rudyard Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>, the youngest ever recipient of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_for_Literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Prize for Literature">Nobel Prize for Literature</a>. His novels include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Jungle_Book" title="The Jungle Book">The Jungle Book</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Man_Who_Would_Be_King" title="The Man Who Would Be King">The Man Who Would Be King</a></i>. His poem <i><a href="/wiki/If%E2%80%94" title="If\xe2\x80\x94">If\xe2\x80\x94</a></i> is a national favourite. Like <a href="/wiki/William_Ernest_Henley" title="William Ernest Henley">William Ernest Henley</a>\'s poem <i><a href="/wiki/Invictus" title="Invictus">Invictus</a></i>, it is a memorable evocation of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian</a> <a href="/wiki/Stoicism" title="Stoicism">stoicism</a> and a "<a href="/wiki/Stiff_upper_lip" title="Stiff upper lip">stiff upper lip</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Notable Irish writers include <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Joyce" title="James Joyce">James Joyce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bram_Stoker" title="Bram Stoker">Bram Stoker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Swift" title="Jonathan Swift">Jonathan Swift</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/W._B._Yeats" title="W. B. Yeats">W. B. Yeats</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Revival" title="Celtic Revival">Celtic Revival</a> stimulated a new appreciation of traditional <a href="/wiki/Irish_literature" title="Irish literature">Irish literature</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Renaissance" title="Scottish Renaissance">Scottish Renaissance</a> of the early 20th century brought modernism to <a href="/wiki/Scottish_literature" title="Scottish literature">Scottish literature</a> as well as an interest in new forms in the literatures of Scottish Gaelic and Scots. The English novel developed in the 20th century into much greater variety and it remains today the dominant English literary form.\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:228px;max-width:228px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:112px;max-width:112px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg/110px-George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg" width="110" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg/165px-George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg/220px-George_Orwell_press_photo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1176" data-file-height="1596" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:112px;max-width:112px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png/110px-Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png" width="110" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png/165px-Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png/220px-Aldous_Huxley_psychical_researcher.png 2x" data-file-width="454" data-file-height="613" /></a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a> (left) and <a href="/wiki/Aldous_Huxley" title="Aldous Huxley">Aldous Huxley</a> (right). Orwell\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Nineteen_Eighty-Four" title="Nineteen Eighty-Four">Nineteen Eighty-Four</a></i>, Huxley\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Brave_New_World" title="Brave New World">Brave New World</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(novel)" title="A Clockwork Orange (novel)">A Clockwork Orange</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Burgess" title="Anthony Burgess">Anthony Burgess</a>, are set in <a href="/wiki/Dystopia" title="Dystopia">dystopian</a> Britain.</div></div></div>\n<p>Other prominent novelists from the UK include <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a>, <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a>, <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a>, <a href="/wiki/D._H._Lawrence" title="D. H. Lawrence">D. H. Lawrence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Carroll" title="Lewis Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien" title="J. R. R. Tolkien">J. R. R. Tolkien</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ian_Fleming" title="Ian Fleming">Ian Fleming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Walter Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Graham_Greene" title="Graham Greene">Graham Greene</a>, <a href="/wiki/E._M._Forster" title="E. M. Forster">E. M. Forster</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aldous_Huxley" title="Aldous Huxley">Aldous Huxley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_C._Clarke" title="Arthur C. Clarke">Arthur C. Clarke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daphne_du_Maurier" title="Daphne du Maurier">Daphne du Maurier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">Alan Moore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ian_McEwan" title="Ian McEwan">Ian McEwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Burgess" title="Anthony Burgess">Anthony Burgess</a>, <a href="/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh" title="Evelyn Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Golding" title="William Golding">William Golding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">Salman Rushdie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Douglas_Adams" title="Douglas Adams">Douglas Adams</a>, <a href="/wiki/P._G._Wodehouse" title="P. G. Wodehouse">P. G. Wodehouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_Amis" title="Martin Amis">Martin Amis</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._G._Ballard" title="J. G. Ballard">J. G. Ballard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beatrix_Potter" title="Beatrix Potter">Beatrix Potter</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._A._Milne" title="A. A. Milne">A. A. Milne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Pullman" title="Philip Pullman">Philip Pullman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terry_Pratchett" title="Terry Pratchett">Terry Pratchett</a>, <a href="/wiki/H._Rider_Haggard" title="H. Rider Haggard">H. Rider Haggard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enid_Blyton" title="Enid Blyton">Enid Blyton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neil_Gaiman" title="Neil Gaiman">Neil Gaiman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazuo_Ishiguro" title="Kazuo Ishiguro">Kazuo Ishiguro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a>. Important British poets of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling" title="Rudyard Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>, <a href="/wiki/W._H._Auden" title="W. H. Auden">W. H. Auden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ted_Hughes" title="Ted Hughes">Ted Hughes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Larkin" title="Philip Larkin">Philip Larkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/T._S._Eliot" title="T. S. Eliot">T. S. Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Betjeman" title="John Betjeman">John Betjeman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dylan_Thomas" title="Dylan Thomas">Dylan Thomas</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg/182px-J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg" width="182" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg/273px-J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/80/J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="358" data-file-height="450" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:J._K._Rowling_04-2010.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a> is the UK\xe2\x80\x99s best selling author of the 21st century</div></div></div>\n<p>Created in 1969, the <a href="/wiki/Man_Booker_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Man Booker Prize">Man Booker Prize</a> is the highest profile British literary award. It is awarded each year in early October for the best original novel, written in English and published in the UK. Devised in 1988, the <a href="/wiki/Hay_Festival" title="Hay Festival">Hay Festival</a> is an annual literature festival held in <a href="/wiki/Hay-on-Wye" title="Hay-on-Wye">Hay-on-Wye</a> in Wales for ten days from May to June. In 2003 the BBC carried out a UK survey entitled <i><a href="/wiki/The_Big_Read" title="The Big Read">The Big Read</a></i> in order to find the "nation\'s best-loved novel" of all time, with works by English novelists J. R. R. Tolkien, Jane Austen, Philip Pullman, Douglas Adams and J. K. Rowling making up the top five on the list.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg/182px-Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg" width="182" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg/273px-Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg/364px-Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hayfestival-2016-crowd-reading.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hay_Festival" title="Hay Festival">Hay Festival</a> crowds reading between sessions. More than 75% of the British public read at least one book annually.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Known for his macabre, <a href="/wiki/Black_comedy" title="Black comedy">darkly comic</a>, fantasy children\'s books, Roald Dahl is frequently ranked the best children\'s author in UK polls.<sup id="cite_ref-Dahl1_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dahl1-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> While in the trenches during WWI, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Lofting" title="Hugh Lofting">Hugh Lofting</a> created <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Dolittle" title="Doctor Dolittle">Doctor Dolittle</a>, a doctor who talks to animals. British children\'s literature was celebrated in the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony" title="2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony">opening ceremony</a> of the London 2012 Olympic Games during the sequence called "<a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony#Second_to_the_right.2C_and_straight_on_till_morning_.2821:35.E2.80.9321:47.29" title="2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony">Second to the right and straight on till morning</a>" which saw over thirty <a href="/wiki/Mary_Poppins_(character)" title="Mary Poppins (character)">Mary Poppins\'</a> descend with umbrellas to fight and defeat the villains <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Hearts_(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland)" title="Queen of Hearts (Alice&#39;s Adventures in Wonderland)">Queen of Hearts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Captain_Hook" title="Captain Hook">Captain Hook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cruella_de_Vil" title="Cruella de Vil">Cruella de Vil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lord_Voldemort" title="Lord Voldemort">Lord Voldemort</a> who were haunting children\'s dreams.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1476, <a href="/wiki/William_Caxton" title="William Caxton">William Caxton</a> was the first person to introduce a printing press into England, and he became the first English retailer of printed books. The UK has remained among the largest publishers of books. As of  2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, six firms in the United Kingdom rank among the world\'s biggest publishers of books in terms of revenue: <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury_Publishing" title="Bloomsbury Publishing">Bloomsbury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Informa" title="Informa">Informa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pearson_plc" title="Pearson plc">Pearson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/RELX_Group" title="RELX Group">RELX Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre">Theatre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Theatre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg/220px-Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg/330px-Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg/440px-Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bristol_Old_Vic_interior.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Interior of the Theatre Royal at the <a href="/wiki/Bristol_Old_Vic" title="Bristol Old Vic">Bristol Old Vic</a>. Opened in 1768, English actor <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a> called it "the most beautiful theatre in England."<sup id="cite_ref-Anniversary_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anniversary-31">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Theatre of the United Kingdom">Theatre of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>From its formation in 1707, the United Kingdom has had a vibrant tradition of theatre, much of it inherited from England and Scotland. The <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> is the <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">main theatre district</a> in the UK. The West End\'s <a href="/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane" title="Theatre Royal, Drury Lane">Theatre Royal</a> in <a href="/wiki/Covent_Garden" title="Covent Garden">Covent Garden</a> in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a> dates back to the mid-17th century, making it the oldest London theatre. Opened in 1768, the Theatre Royal at the <a href="/wiki/Bristol_Old_Vic" title="Bristol Old Vic">Bristol Old Vic</a> is the oldest continually-operating theatre in the English speaking world.<sup id="cite_ref-Anniversary_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anniversary-31">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RSC_Theatre,_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg/220px-RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg/330px-RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg/440px-RSC_Theatre%2C_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RSC_Theatre,_Stratford-upon-Avon_13f2005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Shakespeare_Theatre" title="Royal Shakespeare Theatre">Royal Shakespeare Theatre</a>, opened in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1932</div></div></div>\n<p>In the 18th century, the highbrow and provocative <a href="/wiki/Restoration_comedy" title="Restoration comedy">Restoration comedy</a> lost favour, to be replaced by <a href="/wiki/Sentimentalism_(literature)" title="Sentimentalism (literature)">sentimental</a> comedy, domestic <a href="/wiki/Tragedy" title="Tragedy">tragedy</a> such as George Lillo\'s <a href="/wiki/The_London_Merchant" title="The London Merchant">The London Merchant</a> (1731), and by an overwhelming interest in Italian opera. Popular entertainment became more important in this period than ever before, with fair-booth burlesque and mixed forms that are the ancestors of the English <a href="/wiki/Music_hall" title="Music hall">music hall</a>. These forms flourished at the expense of other forms of English drama, which went into a long period of decline. By the early 19th century it was no longer represented by stage plays at all, but by the <a href="/wiki/Closet_drama" title="Closet drama">closet drama</a>, plays written to be privately read in a "closet" (a small domestic room).\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:278px;max-width:278px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG/130px-Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG" width="130" height="179" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG/195px-Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG/260px-Gilbert-GS-Big.JPG 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="414" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:142px;max-width:142px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg/140px-Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg" width="140" height="178" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg/210px-Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="219" data-file-height="279" /></a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Gilbert_and_Sullivan" title="Gilbert and Sullivan">Gilbert and Sullivan</a>. Their Victorian era <a href="/wiki/Comic_opera" title="Comic opera">comic operas</a> introduced innovations in content and form that directly influenced the development of <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">musical theatre</a> through the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-PeterDowns_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PeterDowns-32">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In 1847, a critic using the pseudonym "Dramaticus" published a pamphlet<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> describing the parlous state of British theatre. Production of serious plays was restricted to the <a href="/wiki/Patent_theatre" title="Patent theatre">patent theatres</a>, and new plays were subject to censorship by the <a href="/wiki/Lord_Chamberlain%27s_Office" title="Lord Chamberlain&#39;s Office">Lord Chamberlain\'s Office</a>. At the same time, there was a burgeoning theatre sector featuring a diet of low <a href="/wiki/Melodrama" title="Melodrama">melodrama</a> and musical <a href="/wiki/Burlesque" title="Burlesque">burlesque</a>; but critics described British theatre as driven by commercialism and a "star" system. A change came in the late 19th century with the plays on the London stage by the Irishmen <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>, who influenced domestic English drama and revitalised it. The <a href="/wiki/Shakespeare_Memorial_Theatre" class="mw-redirect" title="Shakespeare Memorial Theatre">Shakespeare Memorial Theatre</a> was opened in Shakespeare\'s birthplace <a href="/wiki/Stratford_upon_Avon" class="mw-redirect" title="Stratford upon Avon">Stratford upon Avon</a> in 1879; and <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Beerbohm_Tree" title="Herbert Beerbohm Tree">Herbert Beerbohm Tree</a> founded an <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art" title="Royal Academy of Dramatic Art">Academy of Dramatic Art</a> at <a href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Theatre" title="Her Majesty&#39;s Theatre">Her Majesty\'s Theatre</a> in 1904.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Laurence_Olivier,_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg/190px-Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg" width="190" height="290" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg/285px-Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg/380px-Laurence_Olivier%2C_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg 2x" data-file-width="420" data-file-height="640" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Laurence_Olivier,_South_Bank_SE1_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1268529.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a> outside the <a href="/wiki/Royal_National_Theatre" title="Royal National Theatre">Royal National Theatre</a> in London. The highest accolade in British theatre, the <a href="/wiki/Olivier_Awards" class="mw-redirect" title="Olivier Awards">Olivier Awards</a>, are named after him.</div></div></div>\n<p>Producer <a href="/wiki/Richard_D%27Oyly_Carte" title="Richard D&#39;Oyly Carte">Richard D\'Oyly Carte</a> brought together librettist <a href="/wiki/W._S._Gilbert" title="W. S. Gilbert">W. S. Gilbert</a> and composer <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Sullivan" title="Arthur Sullivan">Arthur Sullivan</a>, nurtured their collaboration, and had their first success with <i><a href="/wiki/Trial_by_Jury" title="Trial by Jury">Trial by Jury</a></i>. Among <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_and_Sullivan" title="Gilbert and Sullivan">Gilbert and Sullivan</a>\'s best known <a href="/wiki/Comic_opera" title="Comic opera">comic operas</a> are <i><a href="/wiki/H.M.S._Pinafore" title="H.M.S. Pinafore">H.M.S. Pinafore</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pirates_of_Penzance" title="The Pirates of Penzance">The Pirates of Penzance</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mikado" title="The Mikado">The Mikado</a></i>. Carte built the West End\'s <a href="/wiki/Savoy_Theatre" title="Savoy Theatre">Savoy Theatre</a> in 1881 to present their joint works, and through the inventor of electric light <a href="/wiki/Sir_Joseph_Swan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Joseph Swan">Sir Joseph Swan</a>, the Savoy was the first theatre, and the first public building in the world, to be lit entirely by electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> In 1895, <a href="/wiki/Lyceum_Theatre,_London" title="Lyceum Theatre, London">Lyceum Theatre</a> stage actor <a href="/wiki/Henry_Irving" title="Henry Irving">Henry Irving</a> became the first actor to be awarded a <a href="/wiki/Knighthood" class="mw-redirect" title="Knighthood">knighthood</a>. The performing arts theatre <a href="/wiki/Sadler%27s_Wells" class="mw-redirect" title="Sadler&#39;s Wells">Sadler\'s Wells</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Lilian_Baylis" title="Lilian Baylis">Lilian Baylis</a>, nurtured talent that led to the development of an opera company, which became the <a href="/wiki/English_National_Opera" title="English National Opera">English National Opera</a> (ENO); a theatre company, which evolved into the National Theatre; and a ballet company, which eventually became the English <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ballet" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Ballet">Royal Ballet</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:207px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg/205px-2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg" width="205" height="308" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg/308px-2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ac/2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="540" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2008-11-15_%D0%AD%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D1%8E_%D0%9B%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%B4_%D0%A3%D1%8D%D0%B1%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Musicals of <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a> have dominated London\'s <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End</a> since the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-BTR_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BTR-36">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Making his professional West End debut at the <a href="/wiki/Garrick_Theatre" title="Garrick Theatre">Garrick Theatre</a> in 1911, flamboyant playwright, composer and actor <a href="/wiki/No%C3%ABl_Coward" title="No\xc3\xabl Coward">No\xc3\xabl Coward</a> had a career spanning over 50 years, in which he wrote many comic plays, and over a dozen musical theatre works. <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Richardson" title="Ralph Richardson">Ralph Richardson</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Gielgud" title="John Gielgud">John Gielgud</a> dominated British theatre of the mid-20th century. The National Theatre\'s largest auditorium is named after Olivier, and he is commemorated in the <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier_Awards" class="mw-redirect" title="Laurence Olivier Awards">Laurence Olivier Awards</a>, given annually by the <a href="/wiki/Society_of_London_Theatre" title="Society of London Theatre">Society of London Theatre</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Bart" title="Lionel Bart">Lionel Bart</a>\'s 1960 musical <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver!" title="Oliver!">Oliver!</a></i> (based on <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a> novel) contains the songs "<a href="/wiki/Food,_Glorious_Food" title="Food, Glorious Food">Food, Glorious Food</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Consider_Yourself" title="Consider Yourself">Consider Yourself</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/You%27ve_Got_to_Pick_a_Pocket_or_Two" title="You&#39;ve Got to Pick a Pocket or Two">You\'ve Got to Pick a Pocket or Two</a>". <i>Oliver!</i> has received thousands of performances in British schools since. In July 1962, a board was set up to supervise construction of a <a href="/wiki/Royal_National_Theatre" title="Royal National Theatre">National Theatre</a> in London, and a separate board was constituted to run a National Theatre Company and lease the <a href="/wiki/Old_Vic" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Vic">Old Vic</a> theatre. The Company remained at the Old Vic until 1976, when the new <a href="/wiki/South_Bank" title="South Bank">South Bank</a> building was opened. A <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_of_Scotland" title="National Theatre of Scotland">National Theatre of Scotland</a> was set up in 2006. Today the <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End of London</a> has many theatres, particularly centred on <a href="/wiki/Shaftesbury_Avenue" title="Shaftesbury Avenue">Shaftesbury Avenue</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WeWillRockYouDominion.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1a/WeWillRockYouDominion.jpg/190px-WeWillRockYouDominion.jpg" width="190" height="276" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/1a/WeWillRockYouDominion.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="284" data-file-height="412" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WeWillRockYouDominion.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Freddie_Mercury" title="Freddie Mercury">Freddie Mercury</a> statue at the West End\'s <a href="/wiki/Dominion_Theatre" title="Dominion Theatre">Dominion Theatre</a> where Queen and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Elton" title="Ben Elton">Ben Elton</a>\'s musical <i><a href="/wiki/We_Will_Rock_You_(musical)" title="We Will Rock You (musical)">We Will Rock You</a></i> was performed from 2002 to 2014</div></div></div>\n<p>A prolific composer of musical theatre in the 20th century, <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a> has been referred to as "the most commercially successful composer in history".<sup id="cite_ref-BTR_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BTR-36">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> His musicals, which include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Phantom_of_the_Opera_(1986_musical)" title="The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)">The Phantom of the Opera</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Cats_(musical)" title="Cats (musical)">Cats</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Jesus_Christ_Superstar" title="Jesus Christ Superstar">Jesus Christ Superstar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Evita_(musical)" title="Evita (musical)">Evita</a></i>, have dominated the West End for a number of years and have travelled around the world as well as being turned into films. Lloyd Webber has worked with producer <a href="/wiki/Cameron_Mackintosh" title="Cameron Mackintosh">Cameron Mackintosh</a>, lyricist <a href="/wiki/Tim_Rice" title="Tim Rice">Tim Rice</a>, actor <a href="/wiki/Michael_Crawford" title="Michael Crawford">Michael Crawford</a> (originated <a href="/wiki/Erik_(The_Phantom_of_the_Opera)" title="Erik (The Phantom of the Opera)">the title role in <i>The Phantom of the Opera</i></a>), actress and singer <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Brightman" title="Sarah Brightman">Sarah Brightman</a>, while his musicals originally starred <a href="/wiki/Elaine_Paige" title="Elaine Paige">Elaine Paige</a> (originated the role of <a href="/wiki/Grizabella" title="Grizabella">Grizabella</a> in <i>Cats</i> and had a chart hit with "<a href="/wiki/Memory_(song)" title="Memory (song)">Memory</a>"), who with continued success has become known as the First Lady of British Musical Theatre.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg/220px-Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg/330px-Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg/440px-Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7055" data-file-height="4649" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Strand_Theater_Rocky_Horror.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tim_Curry" title="Tim Curry">Tim Curry</a> (middle) as Dr. Frank-N-Furter in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Show" title="The Rocky Horror Show">The Rocky Horror Show</a></i></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mousetrap" title="The Mousetrap">The Mousetrap</a></i> has seen more than 25,000 performances in the West End, and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_longest-running_West_End_shows" title="List of the longest-running West End shows">longest-running West End show</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Woman_in_Black_(play)" title="The Woman in Black (play)">The Woman in Black</a></i> is the second longest running stage play. Written by <a href="/wiki/Catherine_Johnson_(playwright)" title="Catherine Johnson (playwright)">Catherine Johnson</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Mamma_Mia!" title="Mamma Mia!">Mamma Mia!</a></i> is the West End\'s longest running jukebox musical. <a href="/wiki/Richard_O%27Brien" title="Richard O&#39;Brien">Richard O\'Brien</a>\'s 1973 West End musical <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Show" title="The Rocky Horror Show">The Rocky Horror Show</a></i> has been ranked among the "Nation\'s Number One Essential Musicals".<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Shaffer" title="Peter Shaffer">Peter Shaffer</a>\'s 1979 play <i><a href="/wiki/Amadeus" title="Amadeus">Amadeus</a></i> premiered at the National Theatre. <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a> composed the music for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lion_King_(musical)" title="The Lion King (musical)">The Lion King</a></i> (lyrics by Rice) and <i><a href="/wiki/Billy_Elliot_the_Musical" title="Billy Elliot the Musical">Billy Elliot the Musical</a></i>, with both running for over a decade on the West End. <a href="/wiki/Eric_Idle" title="Eric Idle">Eric Idle</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Spamalot" class="mw-redirect" title="Monty Python&#39;s Spamalot">Monty Python\'s Spamalot</a></i> made its West End debut in 2006. <i><a href="/wiki/Matilda_the_Musical" title="Matilda the Musical">Matilda the Musical</a></i> (an adaptation of <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a>\'s children\'s book) won seven 2012 <a href="/wiki/Olivier_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Olivier Award">Olivier Awards</a>. In 2017, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child">Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</a></i> won nine Olivier Awards.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Shakespeare_Company" title="Royal Shakespeare Company">Royal Shakespeare Company</a>, at <a href="/wiki/Stratford-upon-Avon" title="Stratford-upon-Avon">Stratford-upon-Avon</a>, produces mainly but not exclusively Shakespeare plays. Important modern playwrights include Nobel laureate <a href="/wiki/Harold_Pinter" title="Harold Pinter">Harold Pinter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Stoppard" title="Tom Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Ayckbourn" title="Alan Ayckbourn">Alan Ayckbourn</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Osborne" title="John Osborne">John Osborne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Frayn" title="Michael Frayn">Michael Frayn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Wesker" title="Arnold Wesker">Arnold Wesker</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Music of the United Kingdom">Music of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/British_pop_music" title="British pop music">British pop music</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="British rock">British rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_blues" title="British blues">British blues</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_wave_of_British_heavy_metal" title="New wave of British heavy metal">New wave of British heavy metal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Britpop" title="Britpop">Britpop</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_soul" title="British soul">British soul</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Invasion" title="British Invasion">British Invasion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_British_Invasion" title="Second British Invasion">Second British Invasion</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rule_Britannia_1.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rule_Britannia_1.png/180px-Rule_Britannia_1.png" width="180" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rule_Britannia_1.png/270px-Rule_Britannia_1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rule_Britannia_1.png/360px-Rule_Britannia_1.png 2x" data-file-width="2402" data-file-height="3619" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rule_Britannia_1.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>First page of an 1890s edition of the sheet music for \xe2\x80\x9c<a href="/wiki/Rule,_Britannia!"
