title="Rule, Britannia!">Rule, Britannia!</a>"</div></div></div>\n<p>While the British <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">national anthem</a> "<a href="/wiki/God_Save_the_Queen" title="God Save the Queen">God Save the Queen</a>" and other patriotic songs such as "<a href="/wiki/Rule,_Britannia!" title="Rule, Britannia!">Rule, Britannia!</a>" represent the United Kingdom, each of the four individual countries of the UK also has its own patriotic hymns. <a href="/wiki/Edward_Elgar" title="Edward Elgar">Edward Elgar</a>\'s "<a href="/wiki/Land_of_Hope_and_Glory" title="Land of Hope and Glory">Land of Hope and Glory</a>", and <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>\'s poem <i><a href="/wiki/And_did_those_feet_in_ancient_time" title="And did those feet in ancient time">And did those feet in ancient time</a></i> set to <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Parry" title="Hubert Parry">Hubert Parry</a>\'s "<a href="/wiki/And_did_those_feet_in_ancient_time#Popularisation_of_the_hymn" title="And did those feet in ancient time">Jerusalem</a>", are among England\'s most patriotic hymns. Scottish patriotic songs include "<a href="/wiki/Flower_of_Scotland" title="Flower of Scotland">Flower of Scotland</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Scotland_the_Brave" title="Scotland the Brave">Scotland the Brave</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Scots_Wha_Hae" title="Scots Wha Hae">Scots Wha Hae</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Highland_Cathedral" title="Highland Cathedral">Highland Cathedral</a>"; patriotic Welsh hymns include "<a href="/wiki/Cwm_Rhondda" title="Cwm Rhondda">Guide me, O Thou Great Redeemer</a>" by <a href="/wiki/William_Williams_Pantycelyn" title="William Williams Pantycelyn">William Williams Pantycelyn</a>, and "<a href="/wiki/Hen_Wlad_Fy_Nhadau" title="Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau">Land of My Fathers</a>"; the latter is the national anthem of Wales. The patriotic Northern Irish ballad <i><a href="/wiki/Danny_Boy" title="Danny Boy">Danny Boy</a></i> is set to the tune "<a href="/wiki/Londonderry_Air" title="Londonderry Air">Londonderry Air</a>".\n</p><p>The traditional marching song "<a href="/wiki/The_British_Grenadiers" title="The British Grenadiers">The British Grenadiers</a>" is often performed by <a href="/wiki/British_Army_bands" class="mw-redirect" title="British Army bands">British Army bands</a>, and is played at the <a href="/wiki/Trooping_the_Colour" title="Trooping the Colour">Trooping the Colour</a> ceremony. Written by <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a> bandmaster <a href="/wiki/F._J._Ricketts" class="mw-redirect" title="F. J. Ricketts">F. J. Ricketts</a>, the "<a href="/wiki/Colonel_Bogey_March" title="Colonel Bogey March">Colonel Bogey March</a>" is often whistled, becoming part of <a href="/wiki/British_way_of_life_during_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="British way of life during World War II">British way of life during World War II</a>. <a href="/wiki/George_Frideric_Handel" title="George Frideric Handel">George Frideric Handel</a> composed <i><a href="/wiki/Zadok_the_Priest" title="Zadok the Priest">Zadok the Priest</a></i> in 1727 for the coronation of <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain" title="George II of Great Britain">George II</a>: it has been performed during the Sovereign\'s anointing at every subsequent <a href="/wiki/Coronation_of_the_British_monarch" title="Coronation of the British monarch">British coronation</a>. <a href="/wiki/Jeremiah_Clarke" title="Jeremiah Clarke">Jeremiah Clarke</a>\'s "<a href="/wiki/Trumpet_Voluntary" class="mw-redirect" title="Trumpet Voluntary">Trumpet Voluntary</a>" is popular for wedding music, and has featured in royal weddings.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Band_Trooping_the_Colour,_16th_June_2007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg/220px-Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg/330px-Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg/440px-Band_Trooping_the_Colour%2C_16th_June_2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Band_Trooping_the_Colour,_16th_June_2007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Grenadier_Guards" title="Grenadier Guards">Grenadier Guards</a> band playing \xe2\x80\x9c<a href="/wiki/The_British_Grenadiers" title="The British Grenadiers">The British Grenadiers</a>\xe2\x80\x9d at <a href="/wiki/Trooping_the_Colour" title="Trooping the Colour">Trooping the Colour</a>. Formed in 1685 the band performs at British ceremonial events.</div></div></div>\n<p>Other notable British composers, including <a href="/wiki/Henry_Purcell" title="Henry Purcell">Henry Purcell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Vaughan_Williams" title="Ralph Vaughan Williams">Ralph Vaughan Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Britten" title="Benjamin Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustav_Holst" title="Gustav Holst">Gustav Holst</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Byrd" title="William Byrd">William Byrd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Tallis" title="Thomas Tallis">Thomas Tallis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Wood" title="Henry Wood">Henry Wood</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Taverner" title="John Taverner">John Taverner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Sullivan" title="Arthur Sullivan">Arthur Sullivan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Coleridge-Taylor" title="Samuel Coleridge-Taylor">Samuel Coleridge-Taylor</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Walton" title="William Walton">William Walton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Rodney_Bennett" title="Richard Rodney Bennett">Richard Rodney Bennett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Maxwell_Davies" title="Peter Maxwell Davies">Peter Maxwell Davies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivor_Novello" title="Ivor Novello">Ivor Novello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Arnold" title="Malcolm Arnold">Malcolm Arnold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Tippett" title="Michael Tippett">Michael Tippett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sir_George_Martin" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir George Martin">Sir George Martin</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Barry_(composer)" title="John Barry (composer)">John Barry</a>, have made major contributions to British music. Living composers include <a href="/wiki/John_Rutter" title="John Rutter">John Rutter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Knussen" title="Oliver Knussen">Oliver Knussen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Oldfield" title="Mike Oldfield">Mike Oldfield</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_MacMillan_(composer)" class="mw-redirect" title="James MacMillan (composer)">James MacMillan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Ades" class="mw-redirect" title="Thomas Ades">Thomas Ades</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harrison_Birtwistle" title="Harrison Birtwistle">Harrison Birtwistle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joby_Talbot" title="Joby Talbot">Joby Talbot</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Powell_(composer)" class="mw-redirect" title="John Powell (composer)">John Powell</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Arnold" title="David Arnold">David Arnold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anne_Dudley" title="Anne Dudley">Anne Dudley</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Murphy_(composer)" title="John Murphy (composer)">John Murphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Jackman" title="Henry Jackman">Henry Jackman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leslie_Bricusse" title="Leslie Bricusse">Leslie Bricusse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brian_Eno" title="Brian Eno">Brian Eno</a> (pioneer of "<a href="/wiki/Ambient_music" title="Ambient music">ambient music</a>" which emerged in the early 1970s in the UK), <a href="/wiki/Clint_Mansell" title="Clint Mansell">Clint Mansell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Jenkins" title="Karl Jenkins">Karl Jenkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Gregson_Williams" class="mw-redirect" title="Harry Gregson Williams">Harry Gregson Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Craig_Armstrong_(composer)" title="Craig Armstrong (composer)">Craig Armstrong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Nyman" title="Michael Nyman">Michael Nyman</a>.\n</p>\n<table role="presentation" class="mbox-small" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, /></div></div></td>\n<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em"><div class="haudio">\n<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Handel_-_Arrival_of_the_Queen_of_Sheba.ogg" class="haudio">\n<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Auld_Lang_Syne_-_U.S._Navy_Band.ogg" title="File:Auld Lang Syne - U.S. Navy Band.ogg">"Auld Lang Syne"</a></div>\n<div><div style="padding:2px 0 0 0"></div></div></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan="2" class="mbox-text" style="line-height:1.1em"><hr /><span><i>Problems playing these files? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></span></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The traditional <a href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_England" title="Folk music of England">folk music of England</a> has contributed to several genres, such as <a href="/wiki/Sea_shanties" class="mw-redirect" title="Sea shanties">sea shanties</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jigs" class="mw-redirect" title="Jigs">jigs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hornpipe" title="Hornpipe">hornpipes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dance_music" title="Dance music">dance music</a>. It has its own distinct variations and regional peculiarities. <a href="/wiki/Wynkyn_de_Worde" title="Wynkyn de Worde">Wynkyn de Worde</a>\'s printed ballads of Robin Hood from the 16th century are an important artefact, as are <a href="/wiki/John_Playford" title="John Playford">John Playford</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dancing_Master" title="The Dancing Master">The Dancing Master</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Harley,_1st_Earl_of_Oxford_and_Earl_Mortimer" title="Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer">Robert Harley\'s</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Roxburghe_Ballads" title="Roxburghe Ballads">Roxburghe Ballads</a></i> collections. Some of the best known songs are "<a href="/wiki/Greensleeves" title="Greensleeves">Greensleeves</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Fair_(ballad)" title="Scarborough Fair (ballad)">Scarborough Fair</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Over_the_Hills_and_Far_Away_(traditional_song)" title="Over the Hills and Far Away (traditional song)">Over the Hills and Far Away</a>". Accompanied with music, <a href="/wiki/Morris_dancing" class="mw-redirect" title="Morris dancing">Morris dancing</a> is an English folk dance that first appeared in the 1440s.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bagpipe" class="mw-redirect" title="Bagpipe">bagpipes</a> have long been a national symbol of Scotland, and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Highland_Bagpipe" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Highland Bagpipe">Great Highland Bagpipe</a> is widely recognised. Scottish folk songs include "<a href="/wiki/The_Bonnie_Banks_o%27_Loch_Lomond" title="The Bonnie Banks o&#39; Loch Lomond">The Bonnie Banks o\' Loch Lomond</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Wild_Mountain_Thyme" title="Wild Mountain Thyme">Will Ye Go, Lassie, Go?</a>" while "<a href="/wiki/Auld_Lang_Syne" title="Auld Lang Syne">Auld Lang Syne</a>" is sung throughout the English-speaking world to celebrate the start of the <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve" title="New Year&#39;s Eve">New Year</a>, especially at <a href="/wiki/Hogmanay" title="Hogmanay">Hogmanay</a> in Scotland. A depiction of a <a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harp</a> was carved out by the <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">Picts</a> (medieval Celts) on the <a href="/wiki/Dupplin_Cross" title="Dupplin Cross">Dupplin Cross</a>, Scotland, circa 800 AD. The <a href="/wiki/Child_Ballads" title="Child Ballads">Child Ballads</a>, a <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_Child_Ballads" title="List of the Child Ballads">collection of <i>English and Scottish Popular Ballads</i></a>, are <a href="/wiki/Ballad" title="Ballad">ballads</a> of the British Isles from the later medieval period until the 19th century. Both Northern English and Southern Scots shared in the identified tradition of <a href="/wiki/Border_ballads" class="mw-redirect" title="Border ballads">Border ballads</a>, such as the cross-border narrative in "<a href="/wiki/The_Ballad_of_Chevy_Chase" title="The Ballad of Chevy Chase">The Ballad of Chevy Chase</a>" from 1540. Many ballads were written and sold as single sheet <a href="/wiki/Broadside_(music)" class="mw-redirect" title="Broadside (music)">broadsides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> British folk groups, such as <a href="/wiki/Fairport_Convention" title="Fairport Convention">Fairport Convention</a>, have drawn heavily from these ballads.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aa.vv.,_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes,_warner_%26_routledge,_londra_1859_ca._(gabinetto_vieusseux).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG/220px-Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG/330px-Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG/440px-Aa.vv.%2C_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes%2C_warner_%26_routledge%2C_londra_1859_ca._%28gabinetto_vieusseux%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2172" data-file-height="1492" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Aa.vv.,_popular_nursery_tales_and_rhymes,_warner_%26_routledge,_londra_1859_ca._(gabinetto_vieusseux).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Popular Nursery Tales and Rhymes</i>, Warner &amp; Routledge, London 1859 ca.</div></div></div>\n<p>In the mid-16th century <a href="/wiki/Nursery_rhymes" class="mw-redirect" title="Nursery rhymes">nursery rhymes</a> begin to be recorded in English plays, and the most popular date from the 17th and 18th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> The first English collections, <i><a href="/wiki/Tommy_Thumb%27s_Song_Book" title="Tommy Thumb&#39;s Song Book">Tommy Thumb\'s Song Book</a></i> and a sequel, <i><a href="/wiki/Tommy_Thumb%27s_Pretty_Song_Book" title="Tommy Thumb&#39;s Pretty Song Book">Tommy Thumb\'s Pretty Song Book</a></i>, were published before 1744.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>  <a href="/wiki/John_Newbery" title="John Newbery">John Newbery</a>\'s compilation of English rhymes, <i>Mother Goose\'s Melody, or, Sonnets for the Cradle</i> (London, c. 1765), is the first record we have of many classic rhymes, still in use today.<sup id="cite_ref-Bullen_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bullen-46">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> The 19th-century historian  <a href="/wiki/James_Orchard_Halliwell" class="mw-redirect" title="James Orchard Halliwell">James Orchard Halliwell</a> was a notable collector of English nursery rhymes.\n</p><p>Some of the best known nursery rhymes from Britain are "<a href="/wiki/Twinkle_Twinkle_Little_Star" class="mw-redirect" title="Twinkle Twinkle Little Star">Twinkle Twinkle Little Star</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Roses_Are_Red" title="Roses Are Red">Roses Are Red</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Jack_and_Jill_(song)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jack and Jill (song)">Jack and Jill</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Cock_a_doodle_doo" title="Cock a doodle doo">Cock a doodle doo</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Baa,_Baa,_Black_Sheep" title="Baa, Baa, Black Sheep">Baa, Baa, Black Sheep</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_Grand_Old_Duke_of_York" title="The Grand Old Duke of York">The Grand Old Duke of York</a>", "<a href="/wiki/London_Bridge_Is_Falling_Down" title="London Bridge Is Falling Down">London Bridge Is Falling Down</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Hey_Diddle_Diddle" title="Hey Diddle Diddle">Hey Diddle Diddle</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Three_Blind_Mice" title="Three Blind Mice">Three Blind Mice</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Little_Miss_Muffet" title="Little Miss Muffet">Little Miss Muffet</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Pat-a-cake" class="mw-redirect" title="Pat-a-cake">Pat-a-cake</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Pop_Goes_the_Weasel" title="Pop Goes the Weasel">Pop Goes the Weasel</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_Queen_of_Hearts_(poem)" title="The Queen of Hearts (poem)">The Queen of Hearts</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Polly_Put_the_Kettle_On" title="Polly Put the Kettle On">Polly Put the Kettle On</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Peter_Piper" title="Peter Piper">Peter Piper</a>", "<a href="/wiki/One,_Two,_Buckle_My_Shoe" title="One, Two, Buckle My Shoe">One, Two, Buckle My Shoe</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Hickory_Dickory_Dock" title="Hickory Dickory Dock">Hickory Dickory Dock</a>", "<a href="/wiki/One_for_Sorrow_(nursery_rhyme)" title="One for Sorrow (nursery rhyme)">One for Sorrow</a>", "<a href="/wiki/This_Old_Man" title="This Old Man">This Old Man</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Simple_Simon_(nursery_rhyme)" title="Simple Simon (nursery rhyme)">Simple Simon</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Old_Mother_Hubbard" title="Old Mother Hubbard">Old Mother Hubbard</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Little_Bo_Peep" class="mw-redirect" title="Little Bo Peep">Little Bo Peep</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Sing_a_Song_of_Sixpence" title="Sing a Song of Sixpence">Sing a Song of Sixpence</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Mary,_Mary,_Quite_Contrary" title="Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary">Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Old_King_Cole" title="Old King Cole">Old King Cole</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Humpty_Dumpty" title="Humpty Dumpty">Humpty Dumpty</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> Many of these rhymes are based on figures in British history, for example "<a href="/wiki/Pussy_Cat_Pussy_Cat" title="Pussy Cat Pussy Cat">Pussy Cat Pussy Cat</a>" (from 1805) is about going to see the Queen. The 1730 rhyme "<a href="/wiki/As_I_was_going_to_St_Ives" title="As I was going to St Ives">As I was going to St Ives</a>" (southern English town) is in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Riddle" title="Riddle">riddle</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nos_galan.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Nos_galan.png/220px-Nos_galan.png" width="220" height="79" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Nos_galan.png/330px-Nos_galan.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Nos_galan.png/440px-Nos_galan.png 2x" data-file-width="782" data-file-height="282" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nos_galan.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The tune of "<a href="/wiki/Deck_the_Halls" title="Deck the Halls">Deck the Halls</a>" from <i>Musical and poetical relicks of the Welsh bards</i> (1794). <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Oliphant_(musician_and_artist)" class="mw-redirect" title="Thomas Oliphant (musician and artist)">Thomas Oliphant</a> added the English lyrics in 1862.</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Christmas_carol" title="Christmas carol">Christmas carols</a> in English first appear in a 1426 work by <a href="/wiki/John_Audelay" title="John Audelay">John Awdlay</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Shropshire" title="Shropshire">Shropshire</a> chaplain who lists 25 "caroles of Cristemas", probably sung by groups of \'<a href="/wiki/Wassailing" title="Wassailing">wassailers</a>\', who went from house to house.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Some of the most notable carols from the UK are "<a href="/wiki/We_Wish_You_a_Merry_Christmas" title="We Wish You a Merry Christmas">We Wish You a Merry Christmas</a>", \'"<a href="/wiki/O_Come_All_Ye_Faithful" class="mw-redirect" title="O Come All Ye Faithful">O Come All Ye Faithful</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_First_Noel" title="The First Noel">The First Noel</a>", "<a href="/wiki/God_Rest_You_Merry,_Gentlemen" title="God Rest You Merry, Gentlemen">God Rest You Merry, Gentlemen</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_Holly_and_the_Ivy" title="The Holly and the Ivy">The Holly and the Ivy</a>", "<a href="/wiki/I_Saw_Three_Ships" title="I Saw Three Ships">I Saw Three Ships</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Deck_the_Halls#History" title="Deck the Halls">Deck the Halls</a>", "<a href="/wiki/In_the_Bleak_Midwinter" title="In the Bleak Midwinter">In the Bleak Midwinter</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Joy_to_the_World" title="Joy to the World">Joy to the World</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Once_in_Royal_David%27s_City" title="Once in Royal David&#39;s City">Once in Royal David\'s City</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Hark!_The_Herald_Angels_Sing" title="Hark! The Herald Angels Sing">Hark! The Herald Angels Sing</a>", "<a href="/wiki/What_Child_Is_This%3F" title="What Child Is This?">What Child Is This?</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Good_King_Wenceslas" title="Good King Wenceslas">Good King Wenceslas</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Here_We_Come_A-wassailing" title="Here We Come A-wassailing">Here We Come A-Caroling</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/While_Shepherds_Watched_Their_Flocks" title="While Shepherds Watched Their Flocks">While Shepherds Watched Their Flocks</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg/220px-Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg/330px-Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg/440px-Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4309" data-file-height="2579" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kings_College_Chapeljh.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_Chapel,_Cambridge" title="King&#39;s College Chapel, Cambridge">King\'s College Chapel, Cambridge</a> (left) from where the <a href="/wiki/Nine_Lessons_and_Carols" title="Nine Lessons and Carols">Nine Lessons and Carols</a> are broadcast on the BBC on Christmas Eve</div></div></div>\n<p>A Festival of <a href="/wiki/Nine_Lessons_and_Carols" title="Nine Lessons and Carols">Nine Lessons and Carols</a> held in <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_Chapel,_Cambridge" title="King&#39;s College Chapel, Cambridge">King\'s College Chapel, Cambridge</a> was introduced in 1918 and first broadcast on the BBC in 1928. The service is broadcast around the world. The <a href="/wiki/Christmas_music" title="Christmas music">music of Christmas</a> has always been a combination of sacred and secular, and every year in the UK there is highly publicised competition to be the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christmas_number_one_singles_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Christmas number one singles (UK)">Christmas number one single</a>, which has led to the production of music which provides the mainstay of festive playlists. Responding to a BBC report on the 1984 famine in Ethiopia, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Geldof" title="Bob Geldof">Bob Geldof</a> created the charity supergroup <a href="/wiki/Band_Aid_(band)" title="Band Aid (band)">Band Aid</a> who recorded "<a href="/wiki/Do_They_Know_It%27s_Christmas%3F" title="Do They Know It&#39;s Christmas?">Do They Know It\'s Christmas?</a>". It has been Christmas number one three times.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg/220px-Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg/330px-Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5d/Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="373" data-file-height="240" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Academy_of_Music_London.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Opened in 1822, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a> is one of the leading <a href="/wiki/Music_school" title="Music school">music schools</a> in the UK. Famous alumni include <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a> who studied piano.</div></div></div>\n<p>Written by <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Flower_Adams" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarah Flower Adams">Sarah Flower Adams</a> in 1841, the Christian hymn "<a href="/wiki/Nearer,_My_God,_to_Thee" title="Nearer, My God, to Thee">Nearer, My God, to Thee</a>" is associated with the sinking of the <a href="/wiki/RMS_Titanic" title="RMS Titanic">RMS <i>Titanic</i></a>, as some survivors reported that the ship\'s string ensemble (led by <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Hartley" title="Wallace Hartley">Wallace Hartley</a>) played it as the vessel sank.\n</p><p>The UK has several major orchestras, including the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Symphony_Orchestra" title="BBC Symphony Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Royal Philharmonic Orchestra">Royal Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philharmonia" class="mw-redirect" title="Philharmonia">Philharmonia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="London Philharmonic Orchestra">London Philharmonic Orchestra</a>. The <a href="/wiki/BBC_Philharmonic" title="BBC Philharmonic">BBC Philharmonic</a>\'s recent work includes recording "<a href="/wiki/First_Steps_(Elbow_song)" title="First Steps (Elbow song)">First Steps</a>", the BBC theme for the 2012 London Olympics. London is one of the world\'s major centres for classical music: it has several important concert halls and is also home to the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Royal Opera House</a>, one of the world\'s leading opera houses. British traditional music has also been very influential abroad.\n</p><p>During World War II, <a href="/wiki/Vera_Lynn" title="Vera Lynn">Vera Lynn</a> was known as the <a href="/wiki/Forces%27_Sweetheart" class="mw-redirect" title="Forces&#39; Sweetheart">Forces\' Sweetheart</a>, with "<a href="/wiki/We%27ll_Meet_Again" title="We&#39;ll Meet Again">We\'ll Meet Again</a>", sung to British troops, among the songs most associated with her. In addition to "<a href="/wiki/Colonel_Bogey_March" title="Colonel Bogey March">Colonel Bogey March</a>" (which was whistled), another popular British song during the war, "<a href="/wiki/Run_Rabbit_Run" title="Run Rabbit Run">Run Rabbit Run</a>", contained <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Butler" title="Ralph Butler">Ralph Butler</a>\'s lyrics "Run rabbit \xe2\x80\x93 run rabbit \xe2\x80\x93 Run! Run! Run!", which were altered by the public to poke fun at the Axis. Butler also wrote "<a href="/wiki/The_Sun_Has_Got_His_Hat_On" title="The Sun Has Got His Hat On">The Sun Has Got His Hat On</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Nellie_the_Elephant" title="Nellie the Elephant">Nellie the Elephant</a>". The UK <a href="/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart" title="UK Singles Chart">single</a> and <a href="/wiki/UK_Album_Chart" class="mw-redirect" title="UK Album Chart">album</a> charts are revealed every Friday on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_1" title="BBC Radio 1">BBC Radio 1</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a>\'s "<a href="/wiki/Candle_in_the_Wind_1997" title="Candle in the Wind 1997">Candle in the Wind 1997</a>" the <a href="/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart#Best-selling_singles" title="UK Singles Chart">best-selling single</a> in the UK, and <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Greatest_Hits_(Queen_album)" title="Greatest Hits (Queen album)">Greatest Hits</a></i> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of best-selling albums in the United Kingdom">best-selling album</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/180px-The_Fabs.JPG" width="180" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/270px-The_Fabs.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/360px-The_Fabs.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1110" data-file-height="1110" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> are the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed <a href="/wiki/Musical_ensemble" title="Musical ensemble">band</a> in popular music, with estimated sales of over one billion.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a>, the <a href="/wiki/British_Phonographic_Industry" title="British Phonographic Industry">BPI</a>\'s annual pop music awards, take place at <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">The O2 Arena</a> in London every February.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ivor_Novello_Awards" title="Ivor Novello Awards">Ivor Novello Awards</a> for songwriting and composing are presented annually by the <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Songwriters,_Composers_and_Authors" class="mw-redirect" title="British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors">British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors</a>. Large outdoor <a href="/wiki/List_of_music_festivals_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of music festivals in the United Kingdom">music festivals and concerts</a> in the summer are popular, such as <a href="/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival" title="Glastonbury Festival">Glastonbury</a>, <a href="/wiki/V_Festival" title="V Festival">V Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Summertime_Ball" title="Summertime Ball">Summertime Ball</a>, <a href="/wiki/T_in_the_Park" title="T in the Park">T in the Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Download_Festival" title="Download Festival">Download Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Reading_and_Leeds_Festivals" title="Reading and Leeds Festivals">Reading and Leeds Festivals</a>.\n</p><p>The UK was one of the two main countries in the creation and development of many genres of popular music, including rock music: <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">The Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Kinks" title="The Kinks">The Kinks</a>; hard rock: <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cream_(band)" title="Cream (band)">Cream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Def_Leppard" title="Def Leppard">Def Leppard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whitesnake" title="Whitesnake">Whitesnake</a>; prog rock: <a href="/wiki/Pink_Floyd" title="Pink Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genesis_(band)" title="Genesis (band)">Genesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yes_(band)" title="Yes (band)">Yes</a>, <a href="/wiki/King_Crimson" title="King Crimson">King Crimson</a>; glam rock: <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a>, <a href="/wiki/T._Rex_(band)" title="T. Rex (band)">T. Rex</a>, blues rock: <a href="/wiki/The_Yardbirds" title="The Yardbirds">The Yardbirds</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Animals" title="The Animals">The Animals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dire_Straits" title="Dire Straits">Dire Straits</a>; heavy metal: <a href="/wiki/Black_Sabbath" title="Black Sabbath">Black Sabbath</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deep_Purple" title="Deep Purple">Deep Purple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_Maiden" title="Iron Maiden">Iron Maiden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mot%C3%B6rhead" title="Mot\xc3\xb6rhead">Mot\xc3\xb6rhead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judas_Priest" title="Judas Priest">Judas Priest</a>; punk rock: <a href="/wiki/Sex_Pistols" title="Sex Pistols">Sex Pistols</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Clash" title="The Clash">The Clash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Idol" title="Billy Idol">Billy Idol</a>; new wave: <a href="/wiki/The_Police" title="The Police">The Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Costello" title="Elvis Costello">Elvis Costello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_Club" title="Culture Club">Culture Club</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duran_Duran" title="Duran Duran">Duran Duran</a>; goth rock: <a href="/wiki/The_Cure" title="The Cure">The Cure</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siouxsie_and_the_Banshees" title="Siouxsie and the Banshees">Siouxsie and the Banshees</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Cult" title="The Cult">The Cult</a>; art rock: <a href="/wiki/The_Moody_Blues" title="The Moody Blues">The Moody Blues</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emerson,_Lake_and_Palmer" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerson, Lake and Palmer">Emerson, Lake and Palmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Procol_Harum" title="Procol Harum">Procol Harum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Gabriel" title="Peter Gabriel">Peter Gabriel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bryan_Ferry" title="Bryan Ferry">Bryan Ferry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kate_Bush" title="Kate Bush">Kate Bush</a>; folk rock: <a href="/wiki/Van_Morrison" title="Van Morrison">Van Morrison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cat_Stevens" title="Cat Stevens">Cat Stevens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donovan" title="Donovan">Donovan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jethro_Tull_(band)" title="Jethro Tull (band)">Jethro Tull</a>; soft rock: <a href="/wiki/The_Hollies" title="The Hollies">The Hollies</a>; blue-eyed soul: <a href="/wiki/Dusty_Springfield" title="Dusty Springfield">Dusty Springfield</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Jones_(singer)" title="Tom Jones (singer)">Tom Jones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Winwood" title="Steve Winwood">Steve Winwood</a>; disco: <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a>; synth pop: <a href="/wiki/Depeche_Mode" title="Depeche Mode">Depeche Mode</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurythmics" title="Eurythmics">Eurythmics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pet_Shop_Boys" title="Pet Shop Boys">Pet Shop Boys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Numan" title="Gary Numan">Gary Numan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erasure" title="Erasure">Erasure</a>; reggae: <a href="/wiki/UB40" title="UB40">UB40</a>; ska: <a href="/wiki/Madness_(band)" title="Madness (band)">Madness</a>; shock rock: <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Brown_(musician)" title="Arthur Brown (musician)">Arthur Brown</a>; pop rock: <a href="/wiki/Rod_Stewart" title="Rod Stewart">Rod Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Collins" title="Phil Collins">Phil Collins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sting_(musician)" title="Sting (musician)">Sting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Cocker" title="Joe Cocker">Joe Cocker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Palmer_(singer)" title="Robert Palmer (singer)">Robert Palmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bonnie_Tyler" title="Bonnie Tyler">Bonnie Tyler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tears_for_Fears" title="Tears for Fears">Tears for Fears</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simple_Minds" title="Simple Minds">Simple Minds</a>; alternative rock: <a href="/wiki/The_Smiths" title="The Smiths">The Smiths</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Order_(band)" title="New Order (band)">New Order</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stone_Roses" class="mw-redirect" title="Stone Roses">Stone Roses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radiohead" title="Radiohead">Radiohead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coldplay" title="Coldplay">Coldplay</a>; symphonic rock: <a href="/wiki/Electric_Light_Orchestra" title="Electric Light Orchestra">ELO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muse_(band)" title="Muse (band)">Muse</a>; Britpop: <a href="/wiki/Oasis_(band)" title="Oasis (band)">Oasis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blur_(band)" title="Blur (band)">Blur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pulp_(band)" title="Pulp (band)">Pulp</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Verve" title="The Verve">The Verve</a>; soul: <a href="/wiki/Sade_(singer)" title="Sade (singer)">Sade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soul_II_Soul" title="Soul II Soul">Soul II Soul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simply_Red" title="Simply Red">Simply Red</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adele" title="Adele">Adele</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg/200px-Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg" width="200" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg/300px-Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg/400px-Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="721" data-file-height="818" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Geri_Halliwell_in_concert_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a> singer <a href="/wiki/Geri_Halliwell" title="Geri Halliwell">Geri Halliwell</a> performing in a <a href="/wiki/Union_Jack_dress" title="Union Jack dress">Union Jack dress</a>, an enduring image of <a href="/wiki/Cool_Britannia" title="Cool Britannia">Cool Britannia</a>, the mid-1990s celebration of youth culture in the UK</div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has also pioneered various forms of <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">electronic dance music</a> including <a href="/wiki/Dubstep" title="Dubstep">dubstep</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acid_house" title="Acid house">acid house</a>, <a href="/wiki/UK_garage" title="UK garage">UK garage</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drum_and_bass" title="Drum and bass">drum and bass</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trip_hop" title="Trip hop">trip hop</a>, with acts including <a href="/wiki/The_Prodigy" title="The Prodigy">The Prodigy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Massive_Attack" title="Massive Attack">Massive Attack</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamiroquai" title="Jamiroquai">Jamiroquai</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Chemical_Brothers" title="The Chemical Brothers">The Chemical Brothers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gorillaz" title="Gorillaz">Gorillaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Harris" title="Calvin Harris">Calvin Harris</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norman_Cook" class="mw-redirect" title="Norman Cook">Fatboy Slim</a>. Other notable British artists in pop music include <a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Michael" title="George Michael">George Michael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seal_(musician)" title="Seal (musician)">Seal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Ocean" title="Billy Ocean">Billy Ocean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Annie_Lennox" title="Annie Lennox">Annie Lennox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leona_Lewis" title="Leona Lewis">Leona Lewis</a>, <a href="/wiki/One_Direction" title="One Direction">One Direction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sam_Smith_(singer)" title="Sam Smith (singer)">Sam Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ellie_Goulding" title="Ellie Goulding">Ellie Goulding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Ronson" title="Mark Ronson">Mark Ronson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cliff_Richard" title="Cliff Richard">Cliff Richard</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Shadows" title="The Shadows">The Shadows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ed_Sheeran" title="Ed Sheeran">Ed Sheeran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Mix" title="Little Mix">Little Mix</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robbie_Williams" title="Robbie Williams">Robbie Williams</a>. At the 1997 <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a>, Spice Girls singer <a href="/wiki/Geri_Halliwell" title="Geri Halliwell">Geri Halliwell</a> wore the iconic red, white and blue <a href="/wiki/Union_Jack_dress" title="Union Jack dress">Union Jack mini-dress</a>, which became an enduring image of the <a href="/wiki/Cool_Britannia" title="Cool Britannia">Cool Britannia</a> era.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, British artists topped the decade end ranking, with "<a href="/wiki/Chasing_Cars" title="Chasing Cars">Chasing Cars</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Snow_Patrol" title="Snow Patrol">Snow Patrol</a> announced as the most widely played song of the decade in the UK, and <i><a href="/wiki/Back_to_Bedlam" title="Back to Bedlam">Back to Bedlam</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/James_Blunt" title="James Blunt">James Blunt</a> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums_of_the_2000s_(decade)_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of best-selling albums of the 2000s (decade) in the United Kingdom">best selling album of the 2000s in the UK</a>. Other successful 2000s UK acts include <a href="/wiki/Dido_(singer)" title="Dido (singer)">Dido</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Monkeys" title="Arctic Monkeys">Arctic Monkeys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mika_(singer)" title="Mika (singer)">Mika</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bullet_for_My_Valentine" title="Bullet for My Valentine">Bullet for My Valentine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bring_Me_the_Horizon" title="Bring Me the Horizon">Bring Me the Horizon</a>. Since the early-2000s, <a href="/wiki/British_hip_hop" title="British hip hop">British hip hop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Grime_(music_genre)" title="Grime (music genre)">grime</a> has become increasingly popular, mainly within the youth of cities such as London, Manchester, Birmingham, Nottingham, Leeds and Sheffield. <a href="/wiki/British_R%26B" class="mw-redirect" title="British R&amp;B">British R&amp;B</a> artists include <a href="/wiki/Taio_Cruz" title="Taio Cruz">Taio Cruz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jay_Sean" title="Jay Sean">Jay Sean</a>, <a href="/wiki/M.I.A._(rapper)" title="M.I.A. (rapper)">M.I.A.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tinie_Tempah" title="Tinie Tempah">Tinie Tempah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zayn_Malik" title="Zayn Malik">Zayn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wiley_(musician)" title="Wiley (musician)">Wiley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skepta" title="Skepta">Skepta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rita_Ora" title="Rita Ora">Rita Ora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jessie_J" title="Jessie J">Jessie J</a>.\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Cinema">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cinema of the United Kingdom">Cinema of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_British_films" title="Lists of British films">Lists of British films</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Charlie_Chaplin.jpg/200px-Charlie_Chaplin.jpg" width="200" height="250" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Charlie_Chaplin.jpg/300px-Charlie_Chaplin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Charlie_Chaplin.jpg/400px-Charlie_Chaplin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="1600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>English actor Sir <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a> was described by the British Film Institute as "a towering figure in world culture."<sup id="cite_ref-BFIChaplinproject_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFIChaplinproject-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has had a large impact on modern cinema, producing some of the greatest actors, directors and motion pictures, including <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Attenborough" title="Richard Attenborough">Richard Attenborough</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vivien_Leigh" title="Vivien Leigh">Vivien Leigh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn" title="Audrey Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Gielgud" title="John Gielgud">John Gielgud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_O%27Toole" title="Peter O&#39;Toole">Peter O\'Toole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Burton" title="Richard Burton">Richard Burton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanessa_Redgrave" title="Vanessa Redgrave">Vanessa Redgrave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Hopkins" title="Anthony Hopkins">Anthony Hopkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julie_Andrews" title="Julie Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judi_Dench" title="Judi Dench">Judi Dench</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maggie_Smith" title="Maggie Smith">Maggie Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Rickman" title="Alan Rickman">Alan Rickman</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Hurt" title="John Hurt">John Hurt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>. The <a href="/wiki/BFI_Top_100_British_films" title="BFI Top 100 British films">BFI Top 100 British films</a> is a <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a> poll which ranks what they consider to be the 100 greatest British films of the 20th century. Two of the biggest actors in the silent era were Chaplin and <a href="/wiki/Stan_Laurel" title="Stan Laurel">Stan Laurel</a>.\n</p><p>The UK was the location of the oldest surviving motion picture film, <i><a href="/wiki/Roundhay_Garden_Scene" title="Roundhay Garden Scene">Roundhay Garden Scene</a></i> (1888), which was shot in <a href="/wiki/Roundhay" title="Roundhay">Roundhay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leeds" title="Leeds">Leeds</a> in the north of England by French inventor <a href="/wiki/Louis_Le_Prince" title="Louis Le Prince">Louis Le Prince</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> The world\'s first <a href="/wiki/Color_motion_picture_film" title="Color motion picture film">colour motion picture</a> was shot by <a href="/wiki/Edward_Raymond_Turner" title="Edward Raymond Turner">Edward Raymond Turner</a> in 1902.<sup id="cite_ref-Colour_picture_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Colour_picture-58">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eadweard_Muybridge" title="Eadweard Muybridge">Eadweard Muybridge</a> was another notable English pioneer of motion picture,<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> while pioneering Scottish documentary maker <a href="/wiki/John_Grierson" title="John Grierson">John Grierson</a> coined the term <a href="/wiki/Documentary#Defining_documentary" class="mw-redirect" title="Documentary">"documentary"</a> to describe a non-fiction film in 1926.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:217px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/215px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg" width="215" height="239" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/323px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/430px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="802" data-file-height="890" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Often regarded as the greatest British filmmaker, Sir <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a> was described as "a straightforward middle-class Englishman who just happened to be an artistic genius."<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Ranked by many as the best British filmmaker,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> Hitchcock\'s first thriller, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lodger:_A_Story_of_the_London_Fog" title="The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog">The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog</a></i> (1926), helped shape the <a href="/wiki/Thriller_film" title="Thriller film">thriller</a> genre in film, while his 1929 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Blackmail_(1929_film)" title="Blackmail (1929 film)">Blackmail</a></i>, is often regarded as the first British sound feature film.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_39_Steps_(1935_film)" title="The 39 Steps (1935 film)">The 39 Steps</a></i> (1935) features a signature <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hitchcock_cameo_appearances" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Hitchcock cameo appearances">Hitchcock cameo</a>, and established the quintessential English \'Hitchcock blonde\' <a href="/wiki/Madeleine_Carroll" title="Madeleine Carroll">Madeleine Carroll</a> as the template for his succession of ice cold and elegant leading ladies. <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Korda" title="Alexander Korda">Alexander Korda</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Private_Life_of_Henry_VIII" title="The Private Life of Henry VIII">The Private Life of Henry VIII</a></i> (1933), was the first British production to be nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture. <a href="/wiki/Boris_Karloff" title="Boris Karloff">Boris Karloff</a> played the leading role in major horror films in the 1930s, and collaborated with film director <a href="/wiki/James_Whale" title="James Whale">James Whale</a>. Famous for their motion picture <a href="/wiki/Film_scores" class="mw-redirect" title="Film scores">film scores</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a> first performed film music in 1935.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> The 1939 romantic drama <i><a href="/wiki/Goodbye,_Mr._Chips_(1939_film)" title="Goodbye, Mr. Chips (1939 film)">Goodbye, Mr. Chips</a></i> about a beloved aged schoolteacher Mr. Chipping was based on the <a href="/wiki/Goodbye,_Mr._Chips" title="Goodbye, Mr. Chips">1934 novel</a> by <a href="/wiki/James_Hilton_(novelist)" title="James Hilton (novelist)">James Hilton</a>. In the 1940s <a href="/wiki/James_Mason" title="James Mason">James Mason</a> was the top box office star in the UK, and starred in <i><a href="/wiki/Odd_Man_Out" title="Odd Man Out">Odd Man Out</a></i> (1947).\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dracula_1958_c.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Dracula_1958_c.jpg/190px-Dracula_1958_c.jpg" width="190" height="104" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Dracula_1958_c.jpg/285px-Dracula_1958_c.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Dracula_1958_c.jpg/380px-Dracula_1958_c.jpg 2x" data-file-width="866" data-file-height="473" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dracula_1958_c.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christopher_Lee" title="Christopher Lee">Christopher Lee</a> (as <a href="/wiki/Count_Dracula" title="Count Dracula">Dracula</a> in 1958) starred in numerous British <a href="/wiki/Horror_film" title="Horror film">horror films</a> produced by <a href="/wiki/Hammer_Film_Productions" title="Hammer Film Productions">Hammer</a>. Lee fixed the image of the fanged vampire in popular culture.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The first <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a> (BAFTA) ceremony took place in 1947. <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Sir Laurence Olivier</a> starred in and directed <i><a href="/wiki/Henry_V_(1944_film)" title="Henry V (1944 film)">Henry V</a></i> (1944), and <i><a href="/wiki/Hamlet_(1948_film)" title="Hamlet (1948 film)">Hamlet</a></i> (1948), the latter picked up the <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film" title="BAFTA Award for Best Film">BAFTA Award for Best Film</a> and also became the first British film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. The third <a href="/wiki/Shakespearean" class="mw-redirect" title="Shakespearean">Shakespearean</a> film directed by Olivier was <i><a href="/wiki/Richard_III_(1955_film)" title="Richard III (1955 film)">Richard III</a></i> (1955). The British film-making partnership of <a href="/wiki/Powell_and_Pressburger" title="Powell and Pressburger">Powell and Pressburger</a> made a series of influential films in the 1940s and 1950s, with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Red_Shoes_(1948_film)" title="The Red Shoes (1948 film)">The Red Shoes</a></i> (1948) their most commercially successful film. With a screenplay by <a href="/wiki/Graham_Greene" title="Graham Greene">Graham Greene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carol_Reed" title="Carol Reed">Carol Reed</a> directed the film noir <i><a href="/wiki/The_Third_Man" title="The Third Man">The Third Man</a></i> (1949), regarded among the best British films of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg/190px-Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg" width="190" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg/285px-Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg/380px-Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1139" data-file-height="1372" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Burton_-_The_Robe.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Welsh actor <a href="/wiki/Richard_Burton" title="Richard Burton">Richard Burton</a> was one of the highest paid film stars in the world in the mid-1960s</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a> emerged as a major filmmaker in the 1940s with <i><a href="/wiki/Brief_Encounter" title="Brief Encounter">Brief Encounter</a></i> (1945) and <i><a href="/wiki/Great_Expectations_(1946_film)" title="Great Expectations (1946 film)">Great Expectations</a></i> (1946), with his first big-screen epic <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bridge_on_the_River_Kwai" title="The Bridge on the River Kwai">The Bridge on the River Kwai</a></i> (1957): these are ranked among the best British films. Towards the end of the 1950s, <a href="/wiki/Hammer_Film_Productions" title="Hammer Film Productions">Hammer Films</a> embarked on their series of influential and wildly successful horror films, including lavish colour versions of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Curse_of_Frankenstein" title="The Curse of Frankenstein">Frankenstein</a></i> (1957), <i><a href="/wiki/Dracula_(1958_film)" title="Dracula (1958 film)">Dracula</a></i> (1958) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mummy_(1959_film)" title="The Mummy (1959 film)">The Mummy</a></i> (1959), with actors <a href="/wiki/Peter_Cushing" title="Peter Cushing">Peter Cushing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Lee" title="Christopher Lee">Christopher Lee</a> at the forefront. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dam_Busters_(film)" title="The Dam Busters (film)">The Dam Busters</a></i> (1955), recreates the true story of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">RAF</a>\'s raid on dams in Nazi Germany using Sir <a href="/wiki/Barnes_Wallis" title="Barnes Wallis">Barnes Wallis</a>\'s invention the "<a href="/wiki/Bouncing_bomb" title="Bouncing bomb">bouncing bomb</a>". The <i><a href="/wiki/Carry_On_(franchise)" title="Carry On (franchise)">Carry On</a></i> series, which consists of 31 comedy motion pictures, commenced in 1958. A <a href="/wiki/West_Country" title="West Country">West Country</a> native where many well-known English pirates hailed from, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Newton" title="Robert Newton">Robert Newton</a>\'s portrayal of <a href="/wiki/Long_John_Silver" title="Long John Silver">Long John Silver</a> in 1950s films popularised the stereotypical <a href="/wiki/West_Country_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="West Country accent">West Country</a> <a href="/wiki/Pirate_accent" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirate accent">pirate accent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Konstam_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konstam-67">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> Often portraying disreputable members of the upper classes, comedian <a href="/wiki/Terry-Thomas" title="Terry-Thomas">Terry-Thomas</a>\' personification of the Englishman as an amiable <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bounder" class="extiw" title="wikt:bounder">bounder</a> struck a chord with British audiences during the 1950s.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sean_Connery_1964.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Sean_Connery_1964.png/190px-Sean_Connery_1964.png" width="190" height="242" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0b/Sean_Connery_1964.png 1.5x" data-file-width="250" data-file-height="318" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sean_Connery_1964.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Scottish actor <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a> played <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a> in seven films between 1962 and 1983.</div></div></div>\n<p>Films that explored the "<a href="/wiki/Swinging_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Swinging London">Swinging London</a>" phenomenon of the 1960s included, <i><a href="/wiki/Alfie_(1966_film)" title="Alfie (1966 film)">Alfie</a></i> (1966), <i><a href="/wiki/Blowup" title="Blowup">Blowup</a></i> (1966) and <i><a href="/wiki/Bedazzled_(1967_film)" title="Bedazzled (1967 film)">Bedazzled</a></i> (1967). The <a href="/wiki/James_Bond_(film_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="James Bond (film series)"><i>James Bond</i> film series</a> began in the early 1960s, with <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a> in the leading role. Bond, portrayed by Connery, was selected as the <a href="/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years..._100_Heroes_and_Villains" class="mw-redirect" title="AFI&#39;s 100 Years... 100 Heroes and Villains">third-greatest hero in cinema history</a> by the <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">AFI</a>. After <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> films <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(film)" title="A Hard Day&#39;s Night (film)">A Hard Day\'s Night</a></i> (1964) and <i><a href="/wiki/Help!_(film)" title="Help! (film)">Help!</a></i> (1965), it became standard for each new pop group to have a verit\xc3\xa9 style feature film made about them. <a href="/wiki/Michael_Powell" title="Michael Powell">Michael Powell</a>\'s hugely controversial thriller/horror film <i><a href="/wiki/Peeping_Tom_(film)" title="Peeping Tom (film)">Peeping Tom</a></i> was released in 1960, which is today considered a classic, and is regarded as a contender for the first "<a href="/wiki/Slasher_film" title="Slasher film">slasher</a>" film.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ipcress_File_(film)" title="The Ipcress File (film)">The Ipcress File</a></i> (1965) stars <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a> as <a href="/wiki/Harry_Palmer" title="Harry Palmer">Harry Palmer</a>, a British Army sergeant with a criminal past now working for a <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a> (MoD). Adjusted for inflation, David Lean\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Zhivago_(film)" title="Doctor Zhivago (film)">Doctor Zhivago</a></i> (1965) is among the top ten highest-grossing films. <i><a href="/wiki/A_Man_for_All_Seasons_(1966_film)" title="A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)">A Man for All Seasons</a></i> (1966), based on Sir <a href="/wiki/Thomas_More" title="Thomas More">Thomas More</a>, is listed by the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Vatican</a> as being among the <a href="/wiki/Vatican%27s_list_of_films#Religion" title="Vatican&#39;s list of films">greatest religious movies of time</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png/190px-Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png" width="190" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png/285px-Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png/380px-Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="360" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_O%27Toole_in_Lawrence_of_Arabia.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Peter_O%27Toole" title="Peter O&#39;Toole">Peter O\'Toole</a> as T. E. Lawrence in <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a>\xe2\x80\x99s 1962 epic <i><a href="/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia_(film)" title="Lawrence of Arabia (film)">Lawrence of Arabia</a></i></div></div></div>\n<p>Other major British films of the 1960s included <i><a href="/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia_(film)" title="Lawrence of Arabia (film)">Lawrence of Arabia</a></i> (1962), <i><a href="/wiki/Tom_Jones_(1963_film)" title="Tom Jones (1963 film)">Tom Jones</a></i> (1963), <i><a href="/wiki/Zulu_(1964_film)" title="Zulu (1964 film)">Zulu</a></i> (1964) and <i><a href="/wiki/Those_Magnificent_Men_in_Their_Flying_Machines" class="mw-redirect" title="Those Magnificent Men in Their Flying Machines">Those Magnificent Men in Their Flying Machines</a></i> (1965). Four of the decade\'s Academy Award winners for best picture were British productions, including the film musical <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver!_(film)" title="Oliver! (film)">Oliver!</a></i> (1968) based on <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>\' classic <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver_Twist" title="Oliver Twist">Oliver Twist</a></i>, with <a href="/wiki/Ron_Moody" title="Ron Moody">Ron Moody</a> acclaimed as Fagin. The <a href="/wiki/Caper_story" title="Caper story">caper film</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Italian_Job" title="The Italian Job">The Italian Job</a></i> (1969), starring Michael Caine, is one of the most popular British films ever. Other British actors in starring roles in 1960s films included <a href="/wiki/Richard_Burton" title="Richard Burton">Richard Burton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sellers" title="Peter Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn" title="Audrey Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a> (played <a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a> flower girl <a href="/wiki/Eliza_Doolittle" title="Eliza Doolittle">Eliza Doolittle</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/My_Fair_Lady_(film)" title="My Fair Lady (film)">My Fair Lady</a></i>, 1964), <a href="/wiki/Julie_Christie" title="Julie Christie">Julie Christie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Ustinov" title="Peter Ustinov">Peter Ustinov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rex_Harrison" title="Rex Harrison">Rex Harrison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, child star <a href="/wiki/Hayley_Mills" title="Hayley Mills">Hayley Mills</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Attenborough" title="Richard Attenborough">Richard Attenborough</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Niven" title="David Niven">David Niven</a> and <a href="/wiki/Julie_Andrews" title="Julie Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>, whose portrayal of English nanny <a href="/wiki/Mary_Poppins_(character)" title="Mary Poppins (character)">Mary Poppins</a> is named among the great movie characters. <a href="/wiki/Ken_Russell" title="Ken Russell">Ken Russell</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Women_in_Love_(film)" title="Women in Love (film)">Women in Love</a></i> (1969) starred <a href="/wiki/Glenda_Jackson" title="Glenda Jackson">Glenda Jackson</a>, who won numerous awards.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/190px-Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg" width="190" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/285px-Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/380px-Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2306" data-file-height="3074" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ridley_Scott_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sir <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a> was among a group of British filmmakers, including <a href="/wiki/Tony_Scott" title="Tony Scott">Tony Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Parker" title="Alan Parker">Alan Parker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Hudson" title="Hugh Hudson">Hugh Hudson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Lyne" title="Adrian Lyne">Adrian Lyne</a>, who emerged from making 1970s UK television commercials.<sup id="cite_ref-Ridley_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ridley-69">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Neame" title="Ronald Neame">Ronald Neame</a> directed the festive favourite <i><a href="/wiki/Scrooge_(1970_film)" title="Scrooge (1970 film)">Scrooge</a></i> (1970). <i><a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film)" title="A Clockwork Orange (film)">A Clockwork Orange</a></i> (1971), based on <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Burgess" title="Anthony Burgess">Anthony Burgess</a>\' novella <a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(novel)" title="A Clockwork Orange (novel)">of the same name</a>, starred <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_McDowell" title="Malcolm McDowell">Malcolm McDowell</a> as <a href="/wiki/Alex_(A_Clockwork_Orange)" title="Alex (A Clockwork Orange)">Alex</a>, the leader of a gang of thugs in a <a href="/wiki/Dystopia" title="Dystopia">dystopian</a> Britain. <i><a href="/wiki/Get_Carter" title="Get Carter">Get Carter</a></i> (1971) features the eponymous London gangster Jack Carter (played by Michael Caine). The horror film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wicker_Man_(1973_film)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Wicker Man (1973 film)">The Wicker Man</a></i> (1973), starring <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Lee" title="Christopher Lee">Christopher Lee</a>, is considered a <a href="/wiki/Cult_film" title="Cult film">cult classic</a>. In 1973 <i><a href="/wiki/The_Day_of_the_Jackal_(film)" title="The Day of the Jackal (film)">The Day of the Jackal</a></i> starred <a href="/wiki/Edward_Fox_(actor)" title="Edward Fox (actor)">Edward Fox</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Jackal_(The_Day_of_the_Jackal)" title="Jackal (The Day of the Jackal)">"Jackal"</a> (which was <a href="/wiki/The_Day_of_the_Jackal" title="The Day of the Jackal">based on a novel</a> by <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Forsyth" title="Frederick Forsyth">Frederick Forsyth</a>). <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Roeg" title="Nicolas Roeg">Nicolas Roeg</a>\'s acclaimed psychological horror/thriller <i><a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Look_Now" title="Don&#39;t Look Now">Don\'t Look Now</a></i> was released in 1973. Two adaptations of <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a> stories <i><a href="/wiki/Murder_on_the_Orient_Express_(1974_film)" title="Murder on the Orient Express (1974 film)">Murder on the Orient Express</a></i> (1974) and <i><a href="/wiki/Death_on_the_Nile_(1978_film)" title="Death on the Nile (1978 film)">Death on the Nile</a></i> (1978) were critically acclaimed. The film adaptation of the West End musical <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Picture_Show" title="The Rocky Horror Picture Show">The Rocky Horror Picture Show</a></i> (1975) sees <a href="/wiki/Tim_Curry" title="Tim Curry">Tim Curry</a> reprise his role as <a href="/wiki/Dr_Frank_N_Furter" class="mw-redirect" title="Dr Frank N Furter">Dr Frank N Furter</a>. Starring as James Bond in <i><a href="/wiki/Live_and_Let_Die_(film)" title="Live and Let Die (film)">Live and Let Die</a></i> (1973), <a href="/wiki/Roger_Moore" title="Roger Moore">Roger Moore</a> would go on to play 007 seven times.\n</p><p>In the mid-1970s, British comedy team <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python" title="Monty Python">Monty Python</a> switched their attention to films, beginning with <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python_and_the_Holy_Grail" title="Monty Python and the Holy Grail">Monty Python and the Holy Grail</a></i> (1975), followed by <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Life_of_Brian" title="Monty Python&#39;s Life of Brian">Monty Python\'s Life of Brian</a></i> (1979), the latter regularly voted the funniest film of all time by the British public.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> A notable song from <i>Life of Brian</i>, "<a href="/wiki/Always_Look_on_the_Bright_Side_of_Life" title="Always Look on the Bright Side of Life">Always Look on the Bright Side of Life</a>" has become a common <a href="/wiki/Singalong" class="mw-redirect" title="Singalong">singalong</a> at public events. Hollywood blockbusters filmed at major British studios in 1977\xe2\x80\x9379, include <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Wars_(film)" title="Star Wars (film)">Star Wars</a></i> (featuring <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, co-star <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Daniels" title="Anthony Daniels">Anthony Daniels</a>\xe2\x80\x93the only actor to appear in every film in the series\xe2\x80\x93and \'the dean of special effects\' <a href="/wiki/John_Stears" title="John Stears">John Stears</a>) at <a href="/wiki/Elstree_Studios" title="Elstree Studios">Elstree Studios</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Superman_(1978_film)" title="Superman (1978 film)">Superman</a></i> (featuring <a href="/wiki/Terence_Stamp" title="Terence Stamp">Terence Stamp</a>) at <a href="/wiki/Pinewood_Studios" title="Pinewood Studios">Pinewood</a>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Alien_(film)" title="Alien (film)">Alien</a></i> (directed by <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a>) at <a href="/wiki/Shepperton_Studios" title="Shepperton Studios">Shepperton</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gary_Oldman_(13925515511)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/198px-Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" width="198" height="277" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/297px-Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/396px-Gary_Oldman_%2813925515511%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2096" data-file-height="2936" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gary_Oldman_(13925515511)_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Renowned for his on-screen diversity, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a> was among a group of British actors dubbed the \'<a href="/wiki/Brit_Pack_(actors)" title="Brit Pack (actors)">Brit Pack</a>\', which included <a href="/wiki/Tim_Roth" title="Tim Roth">Tim Roth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a></div></div></div>\n<p>British films won back to back Academy and BAFTAs for best picture in the 1980s, with <i><a href="/wiki/Chariots_of_Fire" title="Chariots of Fire">Chariots of Fire</a></i> (1981), followed by <i><a href="/wiki/Gandhi_(film)" title="Gandhi (film)">Gandhi</a></i> (1982). <a href="/wiki/John_Hurt" title="John Hurt">John Hurt</a> starred as 19th-century Englishman <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Merrick" title="Joseph Merrick">Joseph Merrick</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Elephant_Man_(film)" title="The Elephant Man (film)">The Elephant Man</a></i> (1980). <a href="/wiki/Bob_Hoskins" title="Bob Hoskins">Bob Hoskins</a> played a London gangster in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Long_Good_Friday" title="The Long Good Friday">The Long Good Friday</a></i> (1980). In the 1980s, a wave of visually stylish directors, <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Parker" title="Alan Parker">Alan Parker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Scott" title="Tony Scott">Tony Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Hudson" title="Hugh Hudson">Hugh Hudson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Lyne" title="Adrian Lyne">Adrian Lyne</a>, were credited for "ushering in a new era of blockbusters using the crowd-pleasing skills they\'d honed in advertising."<sup id="cite_ref-Ridley_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ridley-69">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> The 1983 drama/comedy <i><a href="/wiki/Educating_Rita_(film)" title="Educating Rita (film)">Educating Rita</a></i> features <a href="/wiki/Julie_Walters" title="Julie Walters">Julie Walters</a> and Michael Caine. The 1985 dystopian fantasy, <i><a href="/wiki/Brazil_(1985_film)" title="Brazil (1985 film)">Brazil</a></i>, is regarded as one of the best British films of the mid-1980s. The 1987 black comedy, <i><a href="/wiki/Withnail_and_I" title="Withnail and I">Withnail and I</a></i>, has been described as "one of Britain\'s biggest cult films".<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a> portrayed British punk icon <a href="/wiki/Sid_Vicious" title="Sid Vicious">Sid Vicious</a> in the cult film <i><a href="/wiki/Sid_and_Nancy" title="Sid and Nancy">Sid and Nancy</a></i> (1986). In 1988 <a href="/wiki/Charles_Crichton" title="Charles Crichton">Charles Crichton</a> directed <i><a href="/wiki/A_Fish_Called_Wanda" title="A Fish Called Wanda">A Fish Called Wanda</a></i>, the most acclaimed British comedy of the era. During the late 1980s, a number of young British actors who were becoming major stars, Gary Oldman, <a href="/wiki/Tim_Roth" title="Tim Roth">Tim Roth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rupert_Everett" title="Rupert Everett">Rupert Everett</a>, were dubbed the \'<a href="/wiki/Brit_Pack_(actors)" title="Brit Pack (actors)">Brit Pack</a>\'.<sup id="cite_ref-beast_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beast-72">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg/190px-Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg" width="190" height="265" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg/285px-Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg/380px-Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1684" data-file-height="2346" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Curtis_MFF_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Screenwriter, producer and director <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a> is known for his British romantic comedies <i><a href="/wiki/Four_Weddings_and_a_Funeral" title="Four Weddings and a Funeral">Four Weddings and a Funeral</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_(film)" title="Notting Hill (film)">Notting Hill</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bridget_Jones%27s_Diary_(film)" title="Bridget Jones&#39;s Diary (film)">Bridget Jones\'s Diary</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Love_Actually" title="Love Actually">Love Actually</a></i>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The 1990s saw a large number of traditional British period dramas, including <i><a href="/wiki/Sense_and_Sensibility_(film)" title="Sense and Sensibility (film)">Sense and Sensibility</a></i> (1995), <i><a href="/wiki/Restoration_(1995_film)" title="Restoration (1995 film)">Restoration</a></i> (1995), <i><a href="/wiki/Emma_(1996_theatrical_film)" title="Emma (1996 theatrical film)">Emma</a></i> (1996), <i><a href="/wiki/Mrs._Brown" class="mw-redirect" title="Mrs. Brown">Mrs. Brown</a></i> (1997), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wings_of_the_Dove_(1997_film)" title="The Wings of the Dove (1997 film)">The Wings of the Dove</a></i> (1997) and <i><a href="/wiki/Topsy-Turvy" title="Topsy-Turvy">Topsy-Turvy</a></i> (1999). <i><a href="/wiki/Shakespeare_in_Love" title="Shakespeare in Love">Shakespeare in Love</a></i> (1998) depicts Shakespeare (<a href="/wiki/Joseph_Fiennes" title="Joseph Fiennes">Joseph Fiennes</a>) while he was writing <i><a href="/wiki/Romeo_and_Juliet" title="Romeo and Juliet">Romeo and Juliet</a></i>.
