Set in pre and post war Britain, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Remains_of_the_Day_(film)" title="The Remains of the Day (film)">The Remains of the Day</a></i> (1993), starring <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Hopkins" title="Anthony Hopkins">Anthony Hopkins</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emma_Thompson" title="Emma Thompson">Emma Thompson</a>, was based on <a href="/wiki/The_Remains_of_the_Day" title="The Remains of the Day">the novel</a> by <a href="/wiki/Kazuo_Ishiguro" title="Kazuo Ishiguro">Kazuo Ishiguro</a>. Thompson (as English lawyer <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Peirce" title="Gareth Peirce">Gareth Peirce</a>) starred <i><a href="/wiki/In_the_Name_of_the_Father_(film)" title="In the Name of the Father (film)">In the Name of the Father</a></i> alongside <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a> the same year. <a href="/wiki/Alan_Rickman" title="Alan Rickman">Alan Rickman</a> starred as a ghost in <i><a href="/wiki/Truly,_Madly,_Deeply" title="Truly, Madly, Deeply">Truly, Madly, Deeply</a></i> (1990) and <a href="/wiki/Nigel_Hawthorne" title="Nigel Hawthorne">Nigel Hawthorne</a> starred in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Madness_of_King_George" title="The Madness of King George">The Madness of King George</a></i> (1994). Other critical successes include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Crying_Game" title="The Crying Game">The Crying Game</a></i> (1992) \xe2\x80\x93 famous for its shocking twist,  <i><a href="/wiki/The_Secret_Garden_(1993_film)" title="The Secret Garden (1993 film)">The Secret Garden</a></i> (1993) \xe2\x80\x93 inspired by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Maytham_Hall#Gardens" title="Great Maytham Hall">walled garden at Great Maytham Hall</a> in Kent, and <i><a href="/wiki/Shadowlands_(1993_film)" title="Shadowlands (1993 film)">Shadowlands</a></i> (1993) starring Anthony Hopkins. <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Minghella" title="Anthony Minghella">Anthony Minghella</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient_(film)" title="The English Patient (film)">The English Patient</a></i> (1996) won nine Academy Awards. <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film" title="BAFTA Award for Best Film">BAFTA Award</a> winning films included <a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a>\'s black comedy drama <i><a href="/wiki/Trainspotting_(film)" title="Trainspotting (film)">Trainspotting</a></i> (1996) featuring heroin addict Mark Renton (<a href="/wiki/Ewan_McGregor" title="Ewan McGregor">Ewan McGregor</a>) and his circle of friends in Edinburgh, the 1997 comedy <i><a href="/wiki/The_Full_Monty" title="The Full Monty">The Full Monty</a></i> set in Sheffield, and the biographical drama <i><a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_(film)" title="Elizabeth (film)">Elizabeth</a></i> (1998).\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>\'s 1994 film <i><a href="/wiki/Four_Weddings_and_a_Funeral" title="Four Weddings and a Funeral">Four Weddings and a Funeral</a></i>, starring <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a> in his breakthrough role, set a pattern for British-set romantic comedies, including <i><a href="/wiki/Sliding_Doors" title="Sliding Doors">Sliding Doors</a></i> (1998) and <i><a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_(film)" title="Notting Hill (film)">Notting Hill</a></i> (1999). Grant also made headlines for his high-profile relationship with <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Hurley" title="Elizabeth Hurley">Elizabeth Hurley</a>, which was the focus of much attention in the British and international media. <a href="/wiki/Guy_Ritchie" title="Guy Ritchie">Guy Ritchie</a> filmed the crime comedies <i><a href="/wiki/Lock,_Stock_and_Two_Smoking_Barrels" title="Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels">Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels</a></i> (1998) and <i><a href="/wiki/Snatch_(film)" title="Snatch (film)">Snatch</a></i> (2000), both set in the London criminal underworld. London visual effects company <a href="/wiki/The_Mill_(post-production)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Mill (post-production)">The Mill</a> produced the computer-generated imagery effects for Ridley Scott\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Gladiator_(2000_film)" title="Gladiator (2000 film)">Gladiator</a></i> (2000); the film was dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Reed" title="Oliver Reed">Oliver Reed</a> who died during filming. The Mill created a digital body double for his remaining scenes.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Odeon,_Leicester_Square,_WC2_(7939351244).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg/200px-Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg" width="200" height="300" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg/300px-Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg/400px-Odeon%2C_Leicester_Square%2C_WC2_%287939351244%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2096" data-file-height="3144" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Odeon,_Leicester_Square,_WC2_(7939351244).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Odeon_Leicester_Square" title="Odeon Leicester Square">Odeon Leicester Square</a> hosts numerous European and world film premieres. <a href="/wiki/Odeon_Cinemas" title="Odeon Cinemas">Odeon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cineworld" title="Cineworld">Cineworld</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vue_Cinemas" title="Vue Cinemas">Vue</a> are the three busiest cinema chains in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>At the start of the 21st century, three major international British successes were the romantic comedies <i><a href="/wiki/Bridget_Jones%27s_Diary" title="Bridget Jones&#39;s Diary">Bridget Jones\'s Diary</a></i> (2001), sequel <i><a href="/wiki/Bridget_Jones:_The_Edge_of_Reason_(film)" title="Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (film)">Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason</a></i> (2004), and Richard Curtis\'s directorial debut <i><a href="/wiki/Love_Actually" title="Love Actually">Love Actually</a></i> (2003). In 2000, <a href="/wiki/Leavesden_Film_Studios" class="mw-redirect" title="Leavesden Film Studios">Leavesden Film Studios</a> began filming the first instalment of the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)"><i>Harry Potter</i> film series</a>. Set in north-east England, <i><a href="/wiki/Billy_Elliot" title="Billy Elliot">Billy Elliot</a></i> (2000) deals with a boy becoming a ballet dancer. Composer <a href="/wiki/Clint_Mansell" title="Clint Mansell">Clint Mansell</a>\'s theme \xe2\x80\x9c<a href="/wiki/Lux_Aeterna_(Requiem_for_a_Dream)" class="mw-redirect" title="Lux Aeterna (Requiem for a Dream)">Lux Aeterna</a>\xe2\x80\x9d has gained wide usage in popular culture and has featured in a number of <a href="/wiki/Film_trailers" class="mw-redirect" title="Film trailers">film trailers</a>. Written by <a href="/wiki/Julian_Fellowes" title="Julian Fellowes">Julian Fellowes</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Gosford_Park" title="Gosford Park">Gosford Park</a></i> (2001) is set in an English country house. The British Indian themed sports comedy drama <i><a href="/wiki/Bend_It_Like_Beckham" title="Bend It Like Beckham">Bend It Like Beckham</a></i> (2002) featured starring roles for <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parminder_Nagra" title="Parminder Nagra">Parminder Nagra</a>. Famous for his creation <a href="/wiki/Mr._Bean" title="Mr. Bean">Mr. Bean</a>, the comedian <a href="/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson" title="Rowan Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a> starred in <i><a href="/wiki/Johnny_English" title="Johnny English">Johnny English</a></i> (2003). <a href="/wiki/Wallace_and_Gromit" title="Wallace and Gromit">Wallace and Gromit</a> creator and award-winning animator <a href="/wiki/Nick_Park" title="Nick Park">Nick Park</a> directed <i><a href="/wiki/Chicken_Run" title="Chicken Run">Chicken Run</a></i> (2000) and <i><a href="/wiki/Wallace_%26_Gromit:_The_Curse_of_the_Were-Rabbit" title="Wallace &amp; Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit">Wallace &amp; Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit</a></i> (2005). They are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_animated_films#Stop-motion_animation" title="List of highest-grossing animated films">two highest-grossing stop motion animated films</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/170px-Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg" width="170" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/255px-Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/340px-Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1936" data-file-height="2824" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Andy_Serkis" title="Andy Serkis">Andy Serkis</a> has been acclaimed for his work in <a href="/wiki/Motion_capture" title="Motion capture">motion capture</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Gollum" title="Gollum">Gollum</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" title="The Lord of the Rings (film series)"><i>Lord of the Rings</i></a></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Helen_Mirren" title="Helen Mirren">Helen Mirren</a> starred as <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Queen_(2006_film)" title="The Queen (2006 film)">The Queen</a></i> (2006). Acclaimed British sci-fi films, <i><a href="/wiki/28_Days_Later" title="28 Days Later">28 Days Later</a></i> (2002), and <i><a href="/wiki/Children_of_Men" title="Children of Men">Children of Men</a></i> (2007), depict a dystopian Britain. <a href="/wiki/Joe_Wright" title="Joe Wright">Joe Wright</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Atonement_(film)" title="Atonement (film)">Atonement</a></i> (2007) is set in England through WWII. <a href="/wiki/Simon_Pegg" title="Simon Pegg">Simon Pegg</a> co-wrote and starred in the <i><a href="/wiki/Three_Flavours_Cornetto_trilogy" title="Three Flavours Cornetto trilogy">Three Flavours Cornetto</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Three_Flavours_Cornetto_trilogy" title="Three Flavours Cornetto trilogy">trilogy</a> of films: <i><a href="/wiki/Shaun_of_the_Dead" title="Shaun of the Dead">Shaun of the Dead</a></i> (2004), <i><a href="/wiki/Hot_Fuzz" title="Hot Fuzz">Hot Fuzz</a></i> (2007), and <i><a href="/wiki/The_World%27s_End_(film)" title="The World&#39;s End (film)">The World\'s End</a></i> (2013), which were directed by <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Wright" title="Edgar Wright">Edgar Wright</a>. <a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Slumdog_Millionaire" title="Slumdog Millionaire">Slumdog Millionaire</a></i> (2008) was the most successful British film of the decade. The 2008 horror <i><a href="/wiki/Eden_Lake" title="Eden Lake">Eden Lake</a></i> is among a group of contemporary films dealing with British "hoodies".<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> Based on <a href="/wiki/Mark_Millar" title="Mark Millar">Mark Millar</a>\'s comics, <i><a href="/wiki/Kick-Ass_(film)" title="Kick-Ass (film)">Kick-Ass</a></i> (2010), starring <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Taylor-Johnson" title="Aaron Taylor-Johnson">Aaron Taylor-Johnson</a> as the title character, and <i><a href="/wiki/Kingsman:_The_Secret_Service" title="Kingsman: The Secret Service">Kingsman: The Secret Service</a></i> (2015), starring Michael Caine as the head of the British secret service Kingsman \xe2\x80\x93 both directed by <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Vaughn" title="Matthew Vaughn">Matthew Vaughn</a> \xe2\x80\x93 won <a href="/wiki/Empire_Awards" title="Empire Awards">Empire Awards</a> for <a href="/wiki/Empire_Award_for_Best_British_Film" title="Empire Award for Best British Film">Best British Film</a>. Historical drama <i><a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_Speech" title="The King&#39;s Speech">The King\'s Speech</a></i> (2010), featuring <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a> as <a href="/wiki/George_VI" title="George VI">George VI</a>, received several awards.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:187px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg/185px-Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg" width="185" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg/278px-Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg/370px-Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="612" data-file-height="612" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Framestore_offices_London_March_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Framestore" title="Framestore">Framestore</a> office in London after <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="BAFTA Award">BAFTA</a> wins for <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(2013_film)" title="Gravity (2013 film)">Gravity</a></i>. The firm has provided visual effects for commercially successful films, including <i><a href="/wiki/Fantastic_Beasts_and_Where_to_Find_Them_(film)" title="Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)">Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them</a></i> (2016)</div></div></div>\n<p>Acclaimed for his <a href="/wiki/Motion_capture_acting" class="mw-redirect" title="Motion capture acting">motion capture work</a>, in 2011 actor <a href="/wiki/Andy_Serkis" title="Andy Serkis">Andy Serkis</a> opened his own motion capture workshop, <a href="/wiki/The_Imaginarium_Studios" class="mw-redirect" title="The Imaginarium Studios">The Imaginarium Studios</a> in London. In 2012, the twenty-third <i>James Bond</i> film <i><a href="/wiki/Skyfall" title="Skyfall">Skyfall</a></i> was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of highest-grossing films in the United Kingdom">highest-grossing film in the UK</a> at that point.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, British visual effects company <a href="/wiki/Framestore" title="Framestore">Framestore</a>, under chief supervisor <a href="/wiki/Tim_Webber" title="Tim Webber">Tim Webber</a> and film producer <a href="/wiki/David_Heyman" title="David Heyman">David Heyman</a>, produced the critically acclaimed space epic <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(2013_film)" title="Gravity (2013 film)">Gravity</a></i>. In 2014, the film biopics on two British scientists (<a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">Hawking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Turing</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Theory_of_Everything_(2014_film)" title="The Theory of Everything (2014 film)">The Theory of Everything</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Imitation_Game" title="The Imitation Game">The Imitation Game</a></i>, both achieved critical and commercial success. Produced and written by <a href="/wiki/Alex_Garland" title="Alex Garland">Alex Garland</a>, the science fiction films <i><a href="/wiki/Dredd" title="Dredd">Dredd</a></i> (2012) and <i><a href="/wiki/Ex_Machina_(film)" title="Ex Machina (film)">Ex Machina</a></i> (2015) have both met critical acclaim. <a href="/wiki/Asif_Kapadia" title="Asif Kapadia">Asif Kapadia</a>\'s documentary film <i><a href="/wiki/Amy_(2015_film)" title="Amy (2015 film)">Amy</a></i> (2015) \xe2\x80\x94 based on the life of <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a> \xe2\x80\x94 broke UK box office records, and also became the highest grossing British documentary.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Daniel_Radcliffe,_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg/200px-Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg" width="200" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg/300px-Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg/400px-Daniel_Radcliffe%2C_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="806" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Daniel_Radcliffe,_Emma_Watson_%26_Rupert_Grint_colour.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe" title="Daniel Radcliffe">Daniel Radcliffe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emma_Watson" title="Emma Watson">Emma Watson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rupert_Grint" title="Rupert Grint">Rupert Grint</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)"><i>Harry Potter</i> film series</a> at a London premiere</div></div></div>\n<p>The five most commercially successful British directors in recent years are <a href="/wiki/David_Yates" title="David Yates">David Yates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">Christopher Nolan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Newell_(director)" title="Mike Newell (director)">Mike Newell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Other contemporary British film directors include <a href="/wiki/Guy_Ritchie" title="Guy Ritchie">Guy Ritchie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Wright" title="Joe Wright">Joe Wright</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Parker" title="Alan Parker">Alan Parker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Scott" title="Tony Scott">Tony Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terry_Gilliam" title="Terry Gilliam">Terry Gilliam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Branagh" title="Kenneth Branagh">Kenneth Branagh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_W._S._Anderson" title="Paul W. S. Anderson">Paul W. S. Anderson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hooper" title="Tom Hooper">Tom Hooper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Daldry" title="Stephen Daldry">Stephen Daldry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Wright" title="Edgar Wright">Edgar Wright</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_McDonagh" title="Martin McDonagh">Martin McDonagh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Vaughn" title="Matthew Vaughn">Matthew Vaughn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Frears" title="Stephen Frears">Stephen Frears</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ken_Loach" title="Ken Loach">Ken Loach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Leigh" title="Mike Leigh">Mike Leigh</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Boorman" title="John Boorman">John Boorman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards_(director)" title="Gareth Edwards (director)">Gareth Edwards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_McQueen_(director)" title="Steve McQueen (director)">Steve McQueen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam_Mendes" title="Sam Mendes">Sam Mendes</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RADA_62_Gower_Street,_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/RADA_62_Gower_Street%2C_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG/198px-RADA_62_Gower_Street%2C_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG" 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/RADA_62_Gower_Street%2C_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG/396px-RADA_62_Gower_Street%2C_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RADA_62_Gower_Street,_London_WC1E_6ED._Frontage_dates_from_1905.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art" title="Royal Academy of Dramatic Art">Royal Academy of Dramatic Art</a> (RADA) is one of the most prestigious <a href="/wiki/Drama_school" title="Drama school">drama schools</a> in the UK</div></div></div>\n<p>British actors and actresses have always been significant in international cinema. Well-known currently active performers include <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hardy" title="Tom Hardy">Tom Hardy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Craig" title="Daniel Craig">Daniel Craig</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kate_Winslet" title="Kate Winslet">Kate Winslet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jude_Law" title="Jude Law">Jude Law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catherine_Zeta-Jones" title="Catherine Zeta-Jones">Catherine Zeta-Jones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ewan_McGregor" title="Ewan McGregor">Ewan McGregor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ian_McKellen" title="Ian McKellen">Ian McKellen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Weisz" title="Rachel Weisz">Rachel Weisz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe" title="Daniel Radcliffe">Daniel Radcliffe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emma_Watson" title="Emma Watson">Emma Watson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Fiennes" title="Ralph Fiennes">Ralph Fiennes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tilda_Swinton" title="Tilda Swinton">Tilda Swinton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andy_Serkis" title="Andy Serkis">Andy Serkis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Bloom" title="Orlando Bloom">Orlando Bloom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Bale" title="Christian Bale">Christian Bale</a>, <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">Idris Elba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sacha_Baron_Cohen" title="Sacha Baron Cohen">Sacha Baron Cohen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luke_Evans_(actor)" title="Luke Evans (actor)">Luke Evans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emma_Thompson" title="Emma Thompson">Emma Thompson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simon_Pegg" title="Simon Pegg">Simon Pegg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Bettany" title="Paul Bettany">Paul Bettany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kate_Beckinsale" title="Kate Beckinsale">Kate Beckinsale</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Sheen" title="Michael Sheen">Michael Sheen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter" title="Helena Bonham Carter">Helena Bonham Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Laurie" title="Hugh Laurie">Hugh Laurie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Kingsley" title="Ben Kingsley">Ben Kingsley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kristin_Scott_Thomas" title="Kristin Scott Thomas">Kristin Scott Thomas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Rylance" title="Mark Rylance">Mark Rylance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Holland_(actor)" title="Tom Holland (actor)">Tom Holland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daisy_Ridley" title="Daisy Ridley">Daisy Ridley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benedict_Cumberbatch" title="Benedict Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carey_Mulligan" title="Carey Mulligan">Carey Mulligan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Irons" title="Jeremy Irons">Jeremy Irons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gerard_Butler" title="Gerard Butler">Gerard Butler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lily_James" title="Lily James">Lily James</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helen_Mirren" title="Helen Mirren">Helen Mirren</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Thewlis" title="David Thewlis">David Thewlis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sean_Bean" title="Sean Bean">Sean Bean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hiddleston" title="Tom Hiddleston">Tom Hiddleston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miranda_Richardson" title="Miranda Richardson">Miranda Richardson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maggie_Smith" title="Maggie Smith">Maggie Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Gambon" title="Michael Gambon">Michael Gambon</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Boyega" title="John Boyega">John Boyega</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Broadbent" title="Jim Broadbent">Jim Broadbent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julie_Walters" title="Julie Walters">Julie Walters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gugu_Mbatha-Raw" title="Gugu Mbatha-Raw">Gugu Mbatha-Raw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Garfield" title="Andrew Garfield">Andrew Garfield</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sienna_Miller" title="Sienna Miller">Sienna Miller</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cavill" title="Henry Cavill">Henry Cavill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Redmayne" title="Eddie Redmayne">Eddie Redmayne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chiwetel_Ejiofor" title="Chiwetel Ejiofor">Chiwetel Ejiofor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thandie_Newton" title="Thandie Newton">Thandie Newton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_Freeman" title="Martin Freeman">Martin Freeman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Stewart" title="Patrick Stewart">Patrick Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emilia_Clarke" title="Emilia Clarke">Emilia Clarke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sally_Hawkins" title="Sally Hawkins">Sally Hawkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liam_Neeson" title="Liam Neeson">Liam Neeson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dev_Patel" title="Dev Patel">Dev Patel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Pattinson" title="Robert Pattinson">Robert Pattinson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Statham" title="Jason Statham">Jason Statham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Kaluuya" title="Daniel Kaluuya">Daniel Kaluuya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tim_Roth" title="Tim Roth">Tim Roth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clive_Owen" title="Clive Owen">Clive Owen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riz_Ahmed" title="Riz Ahmed">Riz Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Felicity_Jones" title="Felicity Jones">Felicity Jones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosamund_Pike" title="Rosamund Pike">Rosamund Pike</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samantha_Morton" title="Samantha Morton">Samantha Morton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judi_Dench" title="Judi Dench">Judi Dench</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Oyelowo" title="David Oyelowo">David Oyelowo</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_McAvoy" title="James McAvoy">James McAvoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naomie_Harris" title="Naomie Harris">Naomie Harris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Hopkins" title="Anthony Hopkins">Anthony Hopkins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>.\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:298px;max-width:298px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Frankenstein%27s_monster_(Boris_Karloff).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg/150px-Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg" width="150" height="188" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg/225px-Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg/300px-Frankenstein%27s_monster_%28Boris_Karloff%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1194" data-file-height="1499" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Boris_Karloff" title="Boris Karloff">Boris Karloff</a> as <a href="/wiki/Frankenstein%27s_monster" title="Frankenstein&#39;s monster">Frankenstein\'s monster</a> (from <a href="/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Frankenstein" title="Frankenstein">Frankenstein</a></i>)</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:142px;max-width:142px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_Pan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Peter_Pan.jpg/140px-Peter_Pan.jpg" width="140" height="187" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Peter_Pan.jpg/210px-Peter_Pan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Peter_Pan.jpg/280px-Peter_Pan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_statue" title="Peter Pan statue">Peter Pan statue</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kensington_Gardens" title="Kensington Gardens">Kensington Gardens</a>, London (from <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Peter_and_Wendy" title="Peter and Wendy">Peter Pan</a></i>)</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>Hollywood films with a British dimension have had enormous worldwide commercial success. Many of the highest-grossing films worldwide of all time have a British historical, cultural or creative theme. Films based on British historical events; <a href="/wiki/RMS_Titanic" title="RMS Titanic">RMS <i>Titanic</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Piracy_in_the_Caribbean" title="Piracy in the Caribbean">Piracy in the Caribbean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mutiny_on_the_Bounty" title="Mutiny on the Bounty">Mutiny on the Bounty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stalag_Luft_III_escape" class="mw-redirect" title="Stalag Luft III escape">The Great Escape</a>, historical people; <a href="/wiki/William_Wallace" title="William Wallace">William Wallace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Lawrence of Arabia">Lawrence of Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur" title="King Arthur">King Arthur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Elizabeth I">Elizabeth I</a>, British stories; <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter" title="Harry Potter">Harry Potter</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings" title="The Lord of the Rings">The Lord of the Rings</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia" title="The Chronicles of Narnia">The Chronicles of Narnia</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Frankenstein" title="Frankenstein">Frankenstein</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/A_Christmas_Carol" title="A Christmas Carol">A Christmas Carol</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie_and_the_Chocolate_Factory" title="Charlie and the Chocolate Factory">Charlie and the Chocolate Factory</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Treasure_Island" title="Treasure Island">Treasure Island</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds" title="The War of the Worlds">The War of the Worlds</a></i> among <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">many others</a>. British video game <i><a href="/wiki/Tomb_Raider" title="Tomb Raider">Tomb Raider</a></i> features English archaeologist <a href="/wiki/Lara_Croft" title="Lara Croft">Lara Croft</a> which has been made into feature films. British influence can also be seen with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios_films" title="List of Walt Disney Animation Studios films">\'English Cycle\'</a> of Disney films, which feature <i><a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland" class="mw-redirect" title="Alice in Wonderland">Alice in Wonderland</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan" title="Peter Pan">Peter Pan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Robin_Hood" title="Robin Hood">Robin Hood</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Jungle_Book" title="The Jungle Book">The Jungle Book</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sword_in_the_Stone_(novel)" title="The Sword in the Stone (novel)">The Sword in the Stone</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rescuers_(book)" title="The Rescuers (book)">The Rescuers</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hundred_and_One_Dalmatians" title="The Hundred and One Dalmatians">The Hundred and One Dalmatians</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Winnie_the_Pooh" class="mw-redirect" title="Winnie the Pooh">Winnie the Pooh</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Broadcasting">Broadcasting</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Broadcasting">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Television in the United Kingdom">Television in the United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Radio in the United Kingdom">Radio in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG/180px-BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG" width="180" height="194" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG/270px-BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG/360px-BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG 2x" data-file-width="679" data-file-height="733" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BBCBroadcastingHouse.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a>, the new headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has been at the forefront of developments in film, radio and television. Broadcasting in the UK has historically been dominated by the taxpayer-funded but independently run <a href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="British Broadcasting Corporation">British Broadcasting Corporation</a> (commonly known as the <i>BBC</i>), although other independent radio and television (<a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Channel_4" title="Channel 4">Channel 4</a>, <a href="/wiki/Five_(channel)" class="mw-redirect" title="Five (channel)">Five</a>) and satellite broadcasters (especially <a href="/wiki/British_Sky_Broadcasting" class="mw-redirect" title="British Sky Broadcasting">BSkyB</a> which has over 10 million subscribers) have become more important in recent years. BBC television, and the other three main television channels are <a href="/wiki/Public_service_broadcasting" class="mw-redirect" title="Public service broadcasting">public service broadcasters</a> who, as part of their licence allowing them to operate, broadcast a variety of minority interest programming. The BBC and Channel 4 are state-owned, though they operate independently.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Attenborough_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/David_Attenborough_%28cropped%29.jpg/180px-David_Attenborough_%28cropped%29.jpg" width="180" height="216" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/47/David_Attenborough_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="220" data-file-height="264" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Attenborough_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Broadcaster and naturalist <a href="/wiki/David_Attenborough" title="David Attenborough">David Attenborough</a> is the only person to have won <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts" title="British Academy of Film and Television Arts">BAFTAs</a> for programmes in each of black and white, colour, HD, and 3D.</div></div></div>\n<p>Many successful British TV shows have been exported around the world, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Pop_Idol" title="Pop Idol">Pop Idol</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Simon_Fuller" title="Simon Fuller">Simon Fuller</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Who_Wants_to_Be_a_Millionaire%3F_(UK_game_show)" title="Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)">Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent" title="Britain&#39;s Got Talent">Britain\'s Got Talent</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Simon_Cowell" title="Simon Cowell">Simon Cowell</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/The_X_Factor_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="The X Factor (UK)">The X Factor</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Hell%27s_Kitchen_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hell&#39;s Kitchen (UK)">Hell\'s Kitchen</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Ramsay" title="Gordon Ramsay">Gordon Ramsay</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Office_(UK_TV_series)" title="The Office (UK TV series)">The Office</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Ricky_Gervais" title="Ricky Gervais">Ricky Gervais</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Merchant" title="Stephen Merchant">Stephen Merchant</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Strictly_Come_Dancing" title="Strictly Come Dancing">Strictly Come Dancing</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/House_of_Cards_(UK_TV_series)" title="House of Cards (UK TV series)">House of Cards</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Who_Do_You_Think_You_Are%3F_(UK_TV_series)" title="Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)">Who Do You Think You Are?</a></i> (genealogy series where a celebrity traces their family tree), <i><a href="/wiki/Black_Mirror" title="Black Mirror">Black Mirror</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Brooker" title="Charlie Brooker">Charlie Brooker</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Sherlock_(TV_series)" title="Sherlock (TV series)">Sherlock</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who" title="Doctor Who">Doctor Who</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Downton_Abbey" title="Downton Abbey">Downton Abbey</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Crown_(TV_series)" title="The Crown (TV series)">The Crown</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Top_Gear_(2002_TV_series)" title="Top Gear (2002 TV series)">Top Gear</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/David_Attenborough" title="David Attenborough">David Attenborough</a>\'s acclaimed nature documentaries, including <i><a href="/wiki/The_Blue_Planet" title="The Blue Planet">The Blue Planet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Planet_Earth_(2006_TV_series)" title="Planet Earth (2006 TV series)">Planet Earth</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Life_on_Earth_(TV_series)" title="Life on Earth (TV series)">Life on Earth</a></i>, are produced by the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Natural_History_Unit" title="BBC Natural History Unit">BBC Natural History Unit</a>, the largest wildlife documentary production house in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a>\'s list of the <a href="/wiki/100_Greatest_British_Television_Programmes" class="mw-redirect" title="100 Greatest British Television Programmes">100 Greatest British Television Programmes</a> in 2000 was voted by industry insiders.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> In 2004 the BBC conducted a poll to find <a href="/wiki/Britain%27s_Best_Sitcom" title="Britain&#39;s Best Sitcom">Britain\'s Best Sitcom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pnkssn_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnkssn-83">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> The British public voted for <a href="/wiki/TV%27s_50_Greatest_Stars" title="TV&#39;s 50 Greatest Stars">TV\'s 50 Greatest Stars</a> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg/180px-RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg" width="180" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg/270px-RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg/360px-RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1138" data-file-height="1566" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RowanAtkinsonMar07.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Actor, comedian and screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson" title="Rowan Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a> starred in two sitcoms, <i><a href="/wiki/Blackadder" title="Blackadder">Blackadder</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mr._Bean" title="Mr. Bean">Mr. Bean</a></i>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Popular UK sitcoms (and their iconic characters and catchphrases) from each of the last four decades of the 20th century include <i><a href="/wiki/Dad%27s_Army" title="Dad&#39;s Army">Dad\'s Army</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Perry" title="Jimmy Perry">Jimmy Perry</a>) featuring <a href="/wiki/Captain_Mainwaring" title="Captain Mainwaring">Captain Mainwaring</a>\'s putdown "You stupid boy!", <i><a href="/wiki/Steptoe_and_Son" title="Steptoe and Son">Steptoe and Son</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Simpson_(scriptwriter)" title="Alan Simpson (scriptwriter)">Alan Simpson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ray_Galton" title="Ray Galton">Ray Galton</a>) with a disgusted Harold frequently calling his father "you dirty old man", <i><a href="/wiki/Fawlty_Towers" title="Fawlty Towers">Fawlty Towers</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/John_Cleese" title="John Cleese">John Cleese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Connie_Booth" title="Connie Booth">Connie Booth</a>) with <a href="/wiki/Basil_Fawlty" title="Basil Fawlty">Basil Fawlty</a> regularly slapping the hapless Spanish waiter Manuel, <i><a href="/wiki/Blackadder" title="Blackadder">Blackadder</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Elton" title="Ben Elton">Ben Elton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson" title="Rowan Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a>) where the idiotic <a href="/wiki/Baldrick" title="Baldrick">Baldrick</a> often reveals "I have a cunning plan", <i><a href="/wiki/Only_Fools_and_Horses" title="Only Fools and Horses">Only Fools and Horses</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/John_Sullivan_(writer)" title="John Sullivan (writer)">John Sullivan</a>) where <a href="/wiki/Del_Boy" title="Del Boy">Del Boy</a> often yells "you plonker!" to his brother Rodney, <i><a href="/wiki/Absolutely_Fabulous" title="Absolutely Fabulous">Absolutely Fabulous</a></i> (created by and starring <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Saunders" title="Jennifer Saunders">Jennifer Saunders</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Father_Ted" title="Father Ted">Father Ted</a></i> (by Irish writers <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Mathews_(writer)" title="Arthur Mathews (writer)">Arthur Mathews</a> and <a href="/wiki/Graham_Linehan" title="Graham Linehan">Graham Linehan</a>) which follows the misadventures of three Irish Roman Catholic priests (including the simple minded <a href="/wiki/Father_Dougal_McGuire" title="Father Dougal McGuire">Father Dougal McGuire</a>) along with their housekeeper Mrs Doyle who always wants to serve them tea, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Royle_Family" title="The Royle Family">The Royle Family</a></i> (created by <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Aherne" title="Caroline Aherne">Caroline Aherne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Craig_Cash" title="Craig Cash">Craig Cash</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gold_Hill,_Shaftsbury,_Dorset,_England.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG/220px-Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG/330px-Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG/440px-Gold_Hill%2C_Shaftsbury%2C_Dorset%2C_England.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gold_Hill,_Shaftsbury,_Dorset,_England.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Gold_Hill,_Shaftesbury" title="Gold Hill, Shaftesbury">Gold Hill, Shaftesbury</a> in Dorset where Ridley Scott filmed the nostalgic 1973 <a href="/wiki/Hovis" title="Hovis">Hovis</a> television commercial</div></div></div>\n<p>Launched in 1955, ITV is the oldest commercial television network in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a>\'s evocative 1973 <a href="/wiki/Hovis" title="Hovis">Hovis</a> bread television commercial captured the public imagination. Filmed on <a href="/wiki/Gold_Hill,_Shaftesbury" title="Gold Hill, Shaftesbury">Gold Hill, Shaftesbury</a> in Dorset, Scott\'s advert was voted the UK\'s favourite television advertisement of all time in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> Other notable British commercials include the 1989 <a href="/wiki/British_Airways_face_advertisement" title="British Airways face advertisement">British Airways face advertisement</a>, the 2007 <i><a href="/wiki/Gorilla_(advertisement)" title="Gorilla (advertisement)">Gorilla</a></i> advertisement by <a href="/wiki/Cadbury" title="Cadbury">Cadbury</a> chocolate featuring a gorilla playing drums with Phil Collins\' track "<a href="/wiki/In_the_Air_Tonight" title="In the Air Tonight">In the Air Tonight</a>" playing in the background, and a 2013 advert for <a href="/wiki/Galaxy_(chocolate)" title="Galaxy (chocolate)">Galaxy</a> chocolate bar featuring a computer-generated image of <a href="/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn" title="Audrey Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a>. Christmas commercials are screened from early November in the UK, with campaigns including the <a href="/wiki/John_Lewis_Christmas_advert" title="John Lewis Christmas advert">John Lewis Christmas advert</a> for the department store chain.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Monty_Python_Live_(Mostly).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg/220px-Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg/330px-Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg/440px-Monty_Python_Live_%28Mostly%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Monty_Python_Live_(Mostly).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Members of <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python" title="Monty Python">Monty Python</a> on stage at the O2 Arena, London in July 2014. <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Flying_Circus" title="Monty Python&#39;s Flying Circus">Monty Python\'s Flying Circus</a></i> was named among the best British TV shows</div></div></div>\n<p>International football tournaments, such as the World Cup, are historically the most viewed sports events among the public, while <i><a href="/wiki/Match_of_the_Day" title="Match of the Day">Match of the Day</a></i> is the most popular weekly football show. The <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="1966 FIFA World Cup Final">1966 FIFA World Cup Final</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Funeral_of_Diana,_Princess_of_Wales" title="Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales">Funeral of Princess Diana</a> are the two <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-watched_television_broadcasts#Most_watched_special_events" title="List of most-watched television broadcasts">most watched television events ever</a> in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-BARB_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BARB-88">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Satire" title="Satire">Satire</a> has been a prominent feature in <a href="/wiki/British_comedy" title="British comedy">British comedy</a> for centuries. The British <a href="/wiki/Satire_boom" title="Satire boom">satire boom</a> of the 1960s, which consisted of writers and performers such as <a href="/wiki/Peter_Cook" title="Peter Cook">Peter Cook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dudley_Moore" title="Dudley Moore">Dudley Moore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Bennett" title="Alan Bennett">Alan Bennett</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Frost" title="David Frost">David Frost</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Miller" title="Jonathan Miller">Jonathan Miller</a>, has heavily influenced British television, including the sketch comedy series <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Flying_Circus" title="Monty Python&#39;s Flying Circus">Monty Python\'s Flying Circus</a></i> created in 1969 by <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python" title="Monty Python">Monty Python</a>. Regarded as the leading figure of the satire boom, Peter Cook was ranked number one in the <i>Comedians\' Comedian</i> poll.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> The puppet show <i><a href="/wiki/Spitting_Image" title="Spitting Image">Spitting Image</a></i> was a satire of the <a href="/wiki/British_Royal_Family" class="mw-redirect" title="British Royal Family">royal family</a>, politics, entertainment, sport and UK culture of the 1980s up to the mid-1990s.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wallace,_Gromit,_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg/180px-Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg" width="180" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg/270px-Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg/360px-Wallace%2C_Gromit%2C_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="3072" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Wallace,_Gromit,_and_creator_Nick_Park.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Animator <a href="/wiki/Nick_Park" title="Nick Park">Nick Park</a> with his <a href="/wiki/Wallace_and_Gromit" title="Wallace and Gromit">Wallace and Gromit</a> characters</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_C.S._Lewis,_Belfast.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg/180px-Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg" width="180" height="270" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg/270px-Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg/360px-Statue_of_C.S._Lewis%2C_Belfast.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1365" data-file-height="2048" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_C.S._Lewis,_Belfast.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a> in front of the wardrobe in Belfast from his book <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe" title="The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe">The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe</a></i>. The book was adapted for a BBC miniseries.</div></div></div>\n<p><i><a href="/wiki/Have_I_Got_News_for_You" title="Have I Got News for You">Have I Got News for You</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mock_the_Week" title="Mock the Week">Mock the Week</a></i> are the two longest running satirical panel shows. Satire also features heavily in the <i><a href="/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto" title="Grand Theft Auto">Grand Theft Auto</a></i> video game series which has been ranked among Britain\'s most successful exports.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Slapstick" title="Slapstick">slapstick</a> and double entendre of <a href="/wiki/Benny_Hill" title="Benny Hill">Benny Hill</a> also achieved very high ratings on UK television, as did the physical humour of <i><a href="/wiki/Mr._Bean" title="Mr. Bean">Mr. Bean</a></i>. Popular comedy duos in television include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Two_Ronnies" title="The Two Ronnies">The Two Ronnies</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Morecambe_and_Wise" title="Morecambe and Wise">Morecambe and Wise</a></i>, with both shows featuring memorable sketches. <i><a href="/wiki/Jeeves_and_Wooster" title="Jeeves and Wooster">Jeeves and Wooster</a></i> starred <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Laurie" title="Hugh Laurie">Hugh Laurie</a> as <a href="/wiki/Bertie_Wooster" title="Bertie Wooster">Bertie Wooster</a>, an airy, nonchalant, gormless, idle young gentleman and <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Fry" title="Stephen Fry">Stephen Fry</a> as <a href="/wiki/Jeeves" title="Jeeves">Jeeves</a>, his calm, well-informed, and talented <a href="/wiki/Valet" title="Valet">valet</a>. Created by and starring <a href="/wiki/Rik_Mayall" title="Rik Mayall">Rik Mayall</a> as Richie and <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Edmondson" class="mw-redirect" title="Adrian Edmondson">Adrian Edmondson</a> as Eddie, <i><a href="/wiki/Bottom_(TV_series)" title="Bottom (TV series)">Bottom</a></i> features two crude, perverted flatmates with no jobs and little money, which is noted for its chaotic, nihilistic humour and violent comedy slapstick.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Coogan" title="Steve Coogan">Steve Coogan</a> created the character <a href="/wiki/Alan_Partridge" title="Alan Partridge">Alan Partridge</a>, a tactless and inept television presenter who often insults his guests and whose inflated sense of celebrity drives him to shameless self-promotion. <i><a href="/wiki/Da_Ali_G_Show" title="Da Ali G Show">Da Ali G Show</a></i> starred <a href="/wiki/Sacha_Baron_Cohen" title="Sacha Baron Cohen">Sacha Baron Cohen</a> as a faux-streetwise poseur <a href="/wiki/Ali_G" title="Ali G">Ali G</a> from west London, who would conduct real interviews with unsuspecting people, many of whom are celebrities, during which they are asked absurd and ridiculous questions.\n</p><p>Animator <a href="/wiki/Nick_Park" title="Nick Park">Nick Park</a> created the <a href="/wiki/Wallace_and_Gromit" title="Wallace and Gromit">Wallace and Gromit</a> characters at <a href="/wiki/Aardman_Animations" title="Aardman Animations">Aardman Animations</a> studio in Bristol. They feature in <i><a href="/wiki/A_Grand_Day_Out" title="A Grand Day Out">A Grand Day Out</a></i> (1989), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wrong_Trousers" title="The Wrong Trousers">The Wrong Trousers</a></i> (1993) and <i><a href="/wiki/A_Close_Shave" title="A Close Shave">A Close Shave</a></i> (1995), which all have <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_with_a_100%25_rating_on_Rotten_Tomatoes" title="List of films with a 100% rating on Rotten Tomatoes">100% positive ratings</a> on the aggregation site Rotten Tomatoes, while <i><a href="/wiki/A_Matter_of_Loaf_and_Death" title="A Matter of Loaf and Death">A Matter of Loaf and Death</a></i> was the most watched television programme in the UK in 2008. Aardman also produce the kid\'s show <i><a href="/wiki/Shaun_the_Sheep" title="Shaun the Sheep">Shaun the Sheep</a></i>. Popular pre-school shows include <i><a href="/wiki/Teletubbies" title="Teletubbies">Teletubbies</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Thomas_the_Tank_Engine" title="Thomas the Tank Engine">Thomas the Tank Engine</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Bob_the_Builder" title="Bob the Builder">Bob the Builder</a></i>.\n</p><p>First airing in 1958, <i><a href="/wiki/Blue_Peter" title="Blue Peter">Blue Peter</a></i> is famous for its <a href="/wiki/Handicraft" title="Handicraft">arts and crafts</a> "makes". The show has been a staple for generations of British children. Popular live action TV shows include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Borrowers_(miniseries)" title="The Borrowers (miniseries)">The Borrowers</a></i> (based on <a href="/wiki/Mary_Norton_(author)" title="Mary Norton (author)">Mary Norton</a> books on little people), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Black_Beauty" title="The Adventures of Black Beauty">The Adventures of Black Beauty</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Famous_Five_(1970s_TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Famous Five (1970s TV series)">The Famous Five</a></i> (based on <a href="/wiki/Enid_Blyton" title="Enid Blyton">Enid Blyton</a> books), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe_(1988_TV_serial)" title="The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (1988 TV serial)">The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe</a></i> (based on the <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a> novel), and <i><a href="/wiki/Pride_and_Prejudice_(1995_TV_series)" title="Pride and Prejudice (1995 TV series)">Pride and Prejudice</a></i> (starring <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a> as <a href="/wiki/Mr._Darcy" title="Mr. Darcy">Mr. Darcy</a>). The actor <a href="/wiki/David_Jason" title="David Jason">David Jason</a> has voiced a number of popular characters in children\'s animation, including <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wind_in_the_Willows_(1983_film)" title="The Wind in the Willows (1983 film)">The Wind in the Willows</a></i> (based on the children\'s book by <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Grahame" title="Kenneth Grahame">Kenneth Grahame</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Danger_Mouse_(1981_TV_series)" title="Danger Mouse (1981 TV series)">Danger Mouse</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Count_Duckula" title="Count Duckula">Count Duckula</a></i>. Other children\'s shows include <i><a href="/wiki/Where%27s_Wally%3F" title="Where&#39;s Wally?">Where\'s Wally?</a></i> (a series based on books by author <a href="/wiki/Martin_Handford" title="Martin Handford">Martin Handford</a> where readers are challenged to find Wally who is hidden in the group), <i><a href="/wiki/Dennis_the_Menace_and_Gnasher" title="Dennis the Menace and Gnasher">Dennis the Menace and Gnasher</a></i>, while <i><a href="/wiki/Thunderbirds_(TV_series)" title="Thunderbirds (TV series)">Thunderbirds</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Terrahawks" title="Terrahawks">Terrahawks</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Gerry_Anderson" title="Gerry Anderson">Gerry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sylvia_Anderson" title="Sylvia Anderson">Sylvia Anderson</a> have been praised for creating <a href="/wiki/Supermarionation" title="Supermarionation">Supermarionation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_Vic.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/The_Queen_Vic.jpg/180px-The_Queen_Vic.jpg" width="180" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/The_Queen_Vic.jpg/270px-The_Queen_Vic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/The_Queen_Vic.jpg/360px-The_Queen_Vic.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_Vic.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Queen_Victoria" title="The Queen Victoria">The Queen Vic</a> pub is a prominent setting in the BBC soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>. The show has often vied with ITV\'s soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/Coronation_Street" title="Coronation Street">Coronation Street</a></i> for the top spot in weekly TV ratings</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg/180px-Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg" width="180" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg/270px-Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg/360px-Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="547" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Helen_Mirren_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Helen_Mirren" title="Helen Mirren">Helen Mirren</a> won three <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Television_Award_for_Best_Actress" title="British Academy Television Award for Best Actress">BAFTA Awards for Best Actress</a> for her performance in the British television series <i><a href="/wiki/Prime_Suspect" title="Prime Suspect">Prime Suspect</a></i>. The <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts" title="British Academy of Film and Television Arts">BAFTA Awards</a> are the highest British accolade in film (<a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">ceremony</a> in February) and television (<a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Television_Awards" title="British Academy Television Awards">ceremony</a> in April).</div></div></div>\n<p>Debuting in 1982, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Snowman" title="The Snowman">The Snowman</a></i> (featuring the festive song "<a href="/wiki/Walking_in_the_Air" title="Walking in the Air">Walking in the Air</a>") is annually screened at Christmas. Shown on the BBC, the UK holds two high-profile charity telethon events, <a href="/wiki/Children_in_Need" title="Children in Need">Children in Need</a>, held annually in November, and <a href="/wiki/Comic_Relief" title="Comic Relief">Comic Relief</a>, which alternates with <a href="/wiki/Sports_Relief" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports Relief">Sports Relief</a>, every March. The 2011 edition of Comic Relief saw the first appearance of <a href="/wiki/James_Corden" title="James Corden">James Corden</a>\'s Carpool Karaoke sketch when he drove around London singing songs with <a href="/wiki/George_Michael" title="George Michael">George Michael</a>. British programmes dominate the list of TV\'s most watched shows in the UK, with the <a href="/wiki/Kitchen_sink_realism" title="Kitchen sink realism">kitchen sink dramas</a>, ITV\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Coronation_Street" title="Coronation Street">Coronation Street</a></i> and BBC\'s <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>, both often ranking high on the ratings list compiled by <a href="/wiki/Broadcasters%27_Audience_Research_Board" title="Broadcasters&#39; Audience Research Board">BARB</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BARB_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BARB-88">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> \nThe major <a href="/wiki/Soap_opera" title="Soap opera">soap operas</a> each feature a <a href="/wiki/Pub" title="Pub">pub</a>, and these pubs have become household names throughout the UK. The <a href="/wiki/Rovers_Return" class="mw-redirect" title="Rovers Return">Rovers Return</a> is the pub in <i>Coronation Street</i>, the <a href="/wiki/The_Queen_Victoria" title="The Queen Victoria">Queen Vic</a> (short for the <a href="/wiki/Queen_Victoria" title="Queen Victoria">Queen Victoria</a>) is the pub in <i>EastEnders</i>, and the <a href="/wiki/Woolpack" class="mw-redirect" title="Woolpack">Woolpack</a> in ITV\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Emmerdale" title="Emmerdale">Emmerdale</a></i>. The pub being a prominent setting in the three major television soap operas reflects the role pubs have as the focal point of the community in many towns and villages across the UK. Espionage and detective shows have long been a staple of British television, such as the 1960s series <i><a href="/wiki/The_Avengers_(TV_series)" title="The Avengers (TV series)">The Avengers</a></i> featuring lady spy adventurer and cultural (and feminist) icon <a href="/wiki/Emma_Peel" title="Emma Peel">Emma Peel</a>.\n</p><p>The United Kingdom has a large number of national and local radio stations which cover a great variety of programming. The most listened to stations are the five main national <a href="/wiki/BBC_radio" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC radio">BBC radio</a> stations. <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_1" title="BBC Radio 1">BBC Radio 1</a>, a new music station aimed at the 16\xe2\x80\x9324 age group. <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_2" title="BBC Radio 2">BBC Radio 2</a>, a varied <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a> and chat station aimed at adults is consistently highest in the ratings. <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4" title="BBC Radio 4">BBC Radio 4</a>, a varied talk station, is noted for its news, <a href="/wiki/Current_affairs_(news_format)" title="Current affairs (news format)">current affairs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_drama" title="Radio drama">drama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radio_comedy" title="Radio comedy">comedy</a> output as well as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Archers" title="The Archers">The Archers</a></i>, its long running soap opera, and other unique programmes, including <i><a href="/wiki/Desert_Island_Discs" title="Desert Island Discs">Desert Island Discs</a></i> (1942\xe2\x80\x93present), an interview programme in which a famous guest (called a "<a href="/wiki/Castaway" title="Castaway">castaway</a>") chooses eight pieces of music, a book and a luxury item that they would take with them to a desert island. Currently presented by <a href="/wiki/Kirsty_Young" title="Kirsty Young">Kirsty Young</a>, it is the longest running music radio programme in British history.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_broadcast,_Christmas_1934_(Our_Generation,_1938).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg/220px-Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg/330px-Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg/440px-Royal_broadcast%2C_Christmas_1934_%28Our_Generation%2C_1938%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1806" data-file-height="1198" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_broadcast,_Christmas_1934_(Our_Generation,_1938).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/George_V" title="George V">George V</a> giving the 1934 <a href="/wiki/Royal_Christmas_Message" title="Royal Christmas Message">Royal Christmas Message</a> on BBC Radio. The annual message typically chronicles the year\'s major events.</div></div></div>\n<p>The idea for a <a href="/wiki/Royal_Christmas_Message" title="Royal Christmas Message">Christmas message</a> was conceived by one of the founders of the BBC. Delivered annually by the monarch, it was first broadcast on BBC Radio in 1932. An <a href="/wiki/Alternative_Christmas_message" title="Alternative Christmas message">alternative Christmas message</a> was first broadcast on Channel 4 in 1993. Broadcast from 1951 to 1960, radio comedy <i><a href="/wiki/The_Goon_Show" title="The Goon Show">The Goon Show</a></i>, starring <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sellers" title="Peter Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spike_Milligan" title="Spike Milligan">Spike Milligan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Secombe" title="Harry Secombe">Harry Secombe</a>, mixed ludicrous plots with surreal humour, puns, catchphrases and an array of bizarre sound effects. The show has exerted considerable influence on British comedy and culture. As a film star Sellers in particular became influential to film actors by using different accents and guises and assuming multiple roles in the same film. The long running radio comedy <i><a href="/wiki/Just_a_Minute" title="Just a Minute">Just a Minute</a></i> first aired on BBC Radio 4 in 1967. Panellists must talk for sixty seconds on a given subject, "without hesitation, repetition or deviation". Guests over the years have included <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Fry" title="Stephen Fry">Stephen Fry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Izzard" title="Eddie Izzard">Eddie Izzard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sue_Perkins" title="Sue Perkins">Sue Perkins</a>. First broadcast on BBC Radio 4 in 1978, the science fiction comedy radio series <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hitchhiker%27s_Guide_to_the_Galaxy_(radio_series)" title="The Hitchhiker&#39;s Guide to the Galaxy (radio series)">The Hitchhiker\'s Guide to the Galaxy</a></i> was innovative in its use of music and sound effects. The BBC, as a <a href="/wiki/Public_service_broadcasting" class="mw-redirect" title="Public service broadcasting">public service broadcaster</a>, also runs minority stations such as <a href="/wiki/BBC_Asian_Network" title="BBC Asian Network">BBC Asian Network</a>, <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_1Xtra" title="BBC Radio 1Xtra">BBC Radio 1Xtra</a> and <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_6_Music" title="BBC Radio 6 Music">BBC Radio 6 Music</a>, and local stations throughout the country. Rock music station <a href="/wiki/Absolute_Radio" title="Absolute Radio">Absolute Radio</a>, and sports station <a href="/wiki/Talksport" title="Talksport">Talksport</a>, are among the biggest commercial radio stations in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of radio stations in the United Kingdom">List of radio stations in the United Kingdom</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_television_stations_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of television stations in the United Kingdom">List of television stations in the United Kingdom</a></li></ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Print">Print</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Print">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_Disraeli,_Vanity_Fair,_1869-01-13.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg/190px-Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg" width="190" height="327" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg/285px-Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg/380px-Benjamin_Disraeli%2C_Vanity_Fair%2C_1869-01-13.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1858" data-file-height="3200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_Disraeli,_Vanity_Fair,_1869-01-13.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Caricature of British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Disraeli" title="Benjamin Disraeli">Benjamin Disraeli</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Vanity_Fair_(UK_magazine)" title="Vanity Fair (UK magazine)">Vanity Fair</a></i>, 30 January 1869</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">Freedom of the press</a> was established in Great Britain in 1695.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> Popular British daily national newspapers include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sun_(United_Kingdom)" title="The Sun (United Kingdom)">The Sun</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mirror" title="Daily Mirror">Daily Mirror</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Express" title="Daily Express">Daily Express</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>. Founded by publisher <a href="/wiki/John_Walter_(publisher)" title="John Walter (publisher)">John Walter</a> in 1785, <i>The Times</i> is the first newspaper to have borne that name, lending it to numerous other papers around the world, and is the originator of the widely used <a href="/wiki/Times_New_Roman" title="Times New Roman">Times Roman</a> typeface, created by <a href="/wiki/Victor_Lardent" title="Victor Lardent">Victor Lardent</a> and commissioned by <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Morison" title="Stanley Morison">Stanley Morison</a> in 1931.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> The weekly newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> was founded by <a href="/wiki/James_Wilson_(businessman)" title="James Wilson (businessman)">James Wilson</a> in 1843, and the daily <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i> was founded in 1888. Founding <i><a href="/wiki/The_Gentleman%27s_Magazine" title="The Gentleman&#39;s Magazine">The Gentleman\'s Magazine</a></i> in 1731, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Cave" title="Edward Cave">Edward Cave</a> coined the term "<a href="/wiki/Magazine" title="Magazine">magazine</a>" for a periodical, and was the first publisher to successfully fashion a wide-ranging publication.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> Founded by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gibson_Bowles" title="Thomas Gibson Bowles">Thomas Gibson Bowles</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Vanity_Fair_(UK_magazine)" title="Vanity Fair (UK magazine)">Vanity Fair</a></i> featured <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vanity_Fair_(British_magazine)_caricatures" title="List of Vanity Fair (British magazine) caricatures">caricatures</a> of famous people for which it is best known today.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>A pioneer of children\'s publishing, <a href="/wiki/John_Newbery" title="John Newbery">John Newbery</a> made children\'s literature a sustainable and profitable part of the literary market.<sup id="cite_ref-Grenby_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grenby-98">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_History_of_Little_Goody_Two-Shoes" title="The History of Little Goody Two-Shoes">The History of Little Goody Two-Shoes</a></i> was published by Newbery in 1765.<sup id="cite_ref-Grenby_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grenby-98">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Founded by Sir <a href="/wiki/Allen_Lane" title="Allen Lane">Allen Lane</a> in 1935, <a href="/wiki/Penguin_Books" title="Penguin Books">Penguin Books</a> revolutionised publishing in the 1930s through its inexpensive <a href="/wiki/Paperback" title="Paperback">paperbacks</a>, bringing high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction to the mass market.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> Formed four years later, <a href="/wiki/Puffin_Books" title="Puffin Books">Puffin Books</a> is the children\'s imprint of Penguin Books: <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Euphan_Todd" title="Barbara Euphan Todd">Barbara Euphan Todd</a>\'s 1936 story about the scarecrow <i><a href="/wiki/Worzel_Gummidge" title="Worzel Gummidge">Worzel Gummidge</a></i> was the first Puffin story book in 1941.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Defoe_(1719)_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg/220px-Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg" width="220" height="202" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg/330px-Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg/440px-Defoe_%281719%29_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg 2x" data-file-width="953" data-file-height="874" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Defoe_(1719)_Robinson_Crusoe.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Published in 1719, <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i> is often considered the first <a href="/wiki/English_novel" title="English novel">English novel</a>. A story about a <a href="/wiki/Castaway" title="Castaway">castaway</a> on a <a href="/wiki/Desert_island" title="Desert island">desert island</a>, the novel has spawned so many imitations in film, television and radio that its name was used to define a genre, <a href="/wiki/Robinsonade" title="Robinsonade">Robinsonade</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/English_novel" title="English novel">English novel</a> has generally been seen as beginning with <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i> (1719) and <i><a href="/wiki/Moll_Flanders" title="Moll Flanders">Moll Flanders</a></i> (1722).<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> These books were published after the creation of Copyright in 1709, with other notable published works including <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Richardson" title="Samuel Richardson">Samuel Richardson</a>\'s <i> <a href="/wiki/Pamela,_or_Virtue_Rewarded" class="mw-redirect" title="Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded">Pamela</a></i> (1740) and <i><a href="/wiki/Clarissa" title="Clarissa">Clarissa</a></i> (1747);
