class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Original_laws_of_the_game_1863.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The original hand-written \'Laws of the Game\' drafted for and on behalf of <a href="/wiki/The_Football_Association" title="The Football Association">The Football Association</a> by Ebenezer Cobb Morley in 1863 on display at the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_Museum" title="National Football Museum">National Football Museum</a>, Manchester</div></div></div>\n<p>Both in participation and watching, the <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom#Popularity" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">most popular sport in the UK</a> is association football.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Laws_of_the_Game_(association_football)" title="Laws of the Game (association football)">rules</a> were first drafted in England in 1863 by <a href="/wiki/Ebenezer_Cobb_Morley" title="Ebenezer Cobb Morley">Ebenezer Cobb Morley</a>, and the UK has the oldest football clubs in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> England is recognised as the birthplace of club football by <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Sheffield_F.C." title="Sheffield F.C.">Sheffield F.C.</a>, founded in 1857, the world\'s oldest football club.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Home_nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Home nations">home nations</a> all have separate national teams and domestic competitions, most notably England\'s <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a> and <a href="/wiki/FA_Cup" title="FA Cup">FA Cup</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Premiership" title="Scottish Premiership">Scottish Premiership</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Cup" title="Scottish Cup">Scottish Cup</a>. The top three Welsh football clubs feature in the English league system. The first ever international football match was between <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team" title="Scotland national football team">Scotland</a> and <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a> in 1872.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> Referred to as the "home of football" by FIFA, England hosted the <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1966 FIFA World Cup">1966 FIFA World Cup</a>, and won the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> The British television audience for the 1966 World Cup <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="1966 FIFA World Cup Final">final</a> peaked at 32.30&#160;million viewers, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-watched_television_broadcasts#Most_watched_special_events" title="List of most-watched television broadcasts">most watched television event ever</a> in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-BARB_88-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BARB-88">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain,_Bobby_Moore._(7936243534).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg/220px-The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg/330px-The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg/440px-The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1744" data-file-height="1236" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain,_Bobby_Moore._(7936243534).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a> presenting the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy" title="FIFA World Cup Trophy">World Cup trophy</a> to 1966 World Cup winning England captain <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Moore" title="Bobby Moore">Bobby Moore</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The four home nations have produced some of the greatest players in the game\'s history, including, from England, <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Moore" title="Bobby Moore">Bobby Moore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Banks" title="Gordon Banks">Gordon Banks</a>; from Northern Ireland, <a href="/wiki/George_Best" title="George Best">George Best</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pat_Jennings" title="Pat Jennings">Pat Jennings</a>; from Scotland, <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Dalglish" title="Kenny Dalglish">Kenny Dalglish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Johnstone" title="Jimmy Johnstone">Jimmy Johnstone</a>; and from Wales, <a href="/wiki/Ian_Rush" title="Ian Rush">Ian Rush</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Giggs" title="Ryan Giggs">Ryan Giggs</a>. The first recipient of the <a href="/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or" title="Ballon d&#39;Or">Ballon d\'Or</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Matthews" title="Stanley Matthews">Stanley Matthews</a> was knighted while still a player. The English <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a> (formed in 1992 by member clubs of the old <a href="/wiki/Football_League_First_Division" title="Football League First Division">Football League First Division</a>) is the most-watched football league in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> and its biggest clubs include <a href="/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C." title="Manchester United F.C.">Manchester United</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liverpool_F.C." title="Liverpool F.C.">Liverpool</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arsenal_F.C." title="Arsenal F.C.">Arsenal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_F.C." title="Chelsea F.C.">Chelsea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur" class="mw-redirect" title="Tottenham Hotspur">Tottenham Hotspur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C." title="Manchester City F.C.">Manchester City</a>. Scotland\'s <a href="/wiki/Celtic_F.C." title="Celtic F.C.">Celtic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rangers_F.C." title="Rangers F.C.">Rangers</a> also have a global fanbase. <a href="/wiki/Leicester_City_F.C." title="Leicester City F.C.">Leicester City</a>\'s 2016 Premier League title win is regarded among the greatest sporting upsets ever.\n</p>\n<div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:26%;&#32;;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303512">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{margin:0.5em auto 0.8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft p,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright p{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:larger;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" \xe2\x80\x9c ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" \xe2\x80\x9d ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:360px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{min-width:100%;margin:0 0 0.8em!important;float:none!important}}</style>\n<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">Early references to <a href="/wiki/Dribbling#Association_football" title="Dribbling">dribbling</a> come from accounts of medieval football games in England. <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a> offered an allusion to such ball skills in 14th-century England. In the <i><a href="/wiki/Canterbury_Tales" class="mw-redirect" title="Canterbury Tales">Canterbury Tales</a></i> he uses the following line:  "rolleth under foot as doth a ball"</div>\n<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">\xe2\x80\x94From Chaucer\'s 14th-century work, <a href="/wiki/The_Knight%27s_Tale" title="The Knight&#39;s Tale">The Knight\'s Tale</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup></cite>\n</p>\n</div>\n<p>The best-placed teams in the domestic leagues of England and Scotland qualify for Europe\'s premier competition, the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a> (European Cup). Previous winners from the UK are Liverpool, Manchester United, <a href="/wiki/Nottingham_Forest_F.C." title="Nottingham Forest F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a>, Celtic, Chelsea and <a href="/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C." title="Aston Villa F.C.">Aston Villa</a>. The <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League_Anthem" title="UEFA Champions League Anthem">UEFA Champions League Anthem</a>, written by English composer <a href="/wiki/Tony_Britten" title="Tony Britten">Tony Britten</a> and based on Handel\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Zadok_the_Priest" title="Zadok the Priest">Zadok the Priest</a></i>, is played before each game.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Henry_Francis_Lyte" title="Henry Francis Lyte">Henry Lyte</a>\'s Christian hymn "<a href="/wiki/Abide_With_Me" class="mw-redirect" title="Abide With Me">Abide With Me</a>" is sung prior to kick-off at every  <a href="/wiki/FA_Cup_Final" title="FA Cup Final">FA Cup Final</a>, a tradition since 1927.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SundayLeagueFootball.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/SundayLeagueFootball.jpg/220px-SundayLeagueFootball.jpg" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/SundayLeagueFootball.jpg/330px-SundayLeagueFootball.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/SundayLeagueFootball.jpg/440px-SundayLeagueFootball.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1309" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:SundayLeagueFootball.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sunday_league_football" title="Sunday league football">Sunday league football</a> (a form of amateur football). Amateur matches often take place in public parks.</div></div></div>\n<p>The practice of \xe2\x80\x9cjumpers for goalposts\xe2\x80\x9d alludes to <a href="/wiki/Street_football" title="Street football">street/park football</a> in the UK where <a href="/wiki/Sweater" title="Sweater">jumpers</a> would be placed on the ground and used as <a href="/wiki/Goalposts" class="mw-redirect" title="Goalposts">goalposts</a>. This practice was referenced by singer <a href="/wiki/Ed_Sheeran" title="Ed Sheeran">Ed Sheeran</a> in his DVD <i><a href="/wiki/Jumpers_for_Goalposts:_Live_at_Wembley_Stadium" title="Jumpers for Goalposts: Live at Wembley Stadium">Jumpers for Goalposts: Live at Wembley Stadium</a></i> as a nod to playing concerts at Wembley Stadium, the home of English football.\n</p>\n<table role="presentation" class="mbox-small" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td class="mbox-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" width="50" height="50" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160" /></div></div></td>\n<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em"><div class="haudio">\n<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Cwm_Rhondda.ogg" title="File:Cwm Rhondda.ogg">"Cwm Rhondda"</a></div>\n<div><div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio id="mwe_player_5" controls="" preload="none" style="width:220px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="27.924897959184" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Cwm_Rhondda.ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/c/c0/Cwm_Rhondda.ogg/Cwm_Rhondda.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-title="MP3" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="152920" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c0/Cwm_Rhondda.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file (336 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="336212" /></audio></div></div>\n<div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">"You\'re Not Singing Any More" chants are sung to the Welsh hymn.</div></div></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan="2" class="mbox-text" style="line-height:1.1em"><hr /><span><i>Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></span></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Football in Britain is renowned for the intense rivalries between clubs and the passion of the supporters, which includes a tradition of football chants, such as, "<a href="/wiki/You%27re_Not_Singing_Any_More" title="You&#39;re Not Singing Any More">You\'re Not Singing Any More</a>" (or its variant "We Can See You Sneaking Out!"), sung by jubilant fans towards the opposition fans who have gone silent (or left early).<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> Many teams in the UK have their own club anthem or have a song closely associated with them, for example "<a href="/wiki/Local_Hero_(album)" title="Local Hero (album)">Local Hero</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Dire_Straits" title="Dire Straits">Dire Straits</a> frontman and <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C." title="Newcastle United F.C.">Newcastle United</a> fan <a href="/wiki/Mark_Knopfler" title="Mark Knopfler">Mark Knopfler</a> is played before the start of every Newcastle home game.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup> Throughout the UK, <a href="/wiki/Steak_pie" title="Steak pie">meat pies</a> (as well as burgers and chips) is a traditional hot food eaten at football games either before kick-off or during half time. The purchase of a <a href="/wiki/Football_programme" title="Football programme">football programme</a> (a pre-match magazine produced by the home team that gives details on that days game, including player profiles, recent form, interviews etc.) is also part of the \'ritual\' of attending a football match in the UK. The Football Association dropped its ban on <a href="/wiki/Floodlights" class="mw-redirect" title="Floodlights">floodlights</a> in 1950, and night games attracted increasingly large crowds of fans\xe2\x80\x93some of them unruly\xe2\x80\x94as well as large television audiences. Architects built bigger stadia, and \xe2\x80\x9ctheir cantilevered constructions dwarfing mean streets, supplanted the cathedral as a symbol of the city\'s identity and aspirations.\xe2\x80\x9d<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:247px;"><a href="/wiki/File:18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/245px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg" width="245" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/368px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/490px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="427" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">St Andrews</a>, Scotland, <a href="/wiki/Golf_in_Scotland" title="Golf in Scotland">home of golf</a><sup id="cite_ref-Keay_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Keay-328">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a> originated in Scotland, with the <a href="/wiki/Fife" title="Fife">Fife</a> town of <a href="/wiki/St_Andrews" title="St Andrews">St Andrews</a> known internationally as the "<a href="/wiki/Golf_in_Scotland" title="Golf in Scotland">home of golf</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Keay_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Keay-328">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup> and to many golfers the <a href="/wiki/Old_Course_at_St_Andrews" title="Old Course at St Andrews">Old Course</a>, an ancient <a href="/wiki/Links_(golf)" title="Links (golf)">links</a> course dating to before 1574, is considered to be a site of pilgrimage.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> In 1764, the standard 18 hole golf course was created at St Andrews when members modified the course from 22 to 18 holes.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> Golf is documented as being played on <a href="/wiki/Musselburgh_Links" title="Musselburgh Links">Musselburgh Links</a>, East Lothian, Scotland as early as 2 March 1672, which is certified as the oldest golf course in the world by Guinness World Records.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup> The oldest known <a href="/wiki/Rules_of_golf#Origin" title="Rules of golf"><i>rules of golf</i></a> were compiled in March 1744 in <a href="/wiki/Leith_Links" title="Leith Links">Leith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> The oldest golf tournament in the world, and the first major championship in golf, <a href="/wiki/The_Open_Championship" title="The Open Championship">The Open Championship</a>, first took place in Ayrshire, Scotland in 1860, and today it is played on the weekend of the third Friday in July.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> Golf\'s first superstar <a href="/wiki/Harry_Vardon" title="Harry Vardon">Harry Vardon</a>, a member of the fabled <a href="/wiki/Great_Triumvirate_(golf)" title="Great Triumvirate (golf)">Great Triumvirate</a> who were pioneers of the modern game, won the Open a record six times. Since the 2010s, three Northern Irish golfers have had major success; <a href="/wiki/Graeme_McDowell" title="Graeme McDowell">Graeme McDowell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darren_Clarke" title="Darren Clarke">Darren Clarke</a> and four time major winner <a href="/wiki/Rory_McIlroy" title="Rory McIlroy">Rory McIlroy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> The biennial golf competition, the <a href="/wiki/Ryder_Cup" title="Ryder Cup">Ryder Cup</a>, is named after English businessman <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Ryder" title="Samuel Ryder">Samuel Ryder</a> who sponsored the event and donated the trophy.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> Sir <a href="/wiki/Nick_Faldo" title="Nick Faldo">Nick Faldo</a> is the most successful Ryder Cup player ever, having won the most points (25) of any player on either the European or U.S. teams.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:217px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/215px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg" width="215" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/323px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/430px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Millennium_Stadium" title="Millennium Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, home of the <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_rugby_union_team" title="Wales national rugby union team">Wales Rugby Union team</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In 1845, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> was created when the first rules were written by pupils at <a href="/wiki/Rugby_School" title="Rugby School">Rugby School</a>, Warwickshire.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup> A former pupil of the school <a href="/wiki/William_Webb_Ellis" title="William Webb Ellis">William Webb Ellis</a>, is often fabled with the invention of running with the ball in hand in 1823. The <a href="/wiki/1871_England_versus_Scotland_rugby_union_match" class="mw-redirect" title="1871 England versus Scotland rugby union match">first rugby international</a> took place on 27 March 1871, played between <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team" title="England national rugby union team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team" title="Scotland national rugby union team">Scotland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> By 1881 both <a href="/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_union_team" title="Ireland national rugby union team">Ireland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_rugby_union_team" title="Wales national rugby union team">Wales</a> had teams, and in 1883 the first international competition the annual <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Home Nations Championship</a> took place. In 1888, the Home Nations combined to form what is today called the <a href="/wiki/British_and_Irish_Lions" title="British and Irish Lions">British and Irish Lions</a>, who now tour every four years to face a Southern Hemisphere team. The Wales team of the 1970s, which included a backline consisting of <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._P._R._Williams" title="J. P. R. Williams">J. P. R. Williams</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phil_Bennett" title="Phil Bennett">Phil Bennett</a> who were known for their feints, sidesteps and attacking running rugby, are regarded as one of the greatest teams in the game \xe2\x80\x94 all three players were involved in <i><a href="/wiki/The_greatest_try_ever_scored" class="mw-redirect" title="The greatest try ever scored">The greatest try ever scored</a></i> in 1973. <a href="/wiki/Jonny_Wilkinson" title="Jonny Wilkinson">Jonny Wilkinson</a> scored the winning <a href="/wiki/Drop_kick" title="Drop kick">drop goal</a> for England in the last minute of extra time in the <a href="/wiki/2003_Rugby_World_Cup_Final" title="2003 Rugby World Cup Final">2003 Rugby World Cup Final</a>. The major domestic club competitions are the <a href="/wiki/English_Premiership_(rugby_union)" class="mw-redirect" title="English Premiership (rugby union)">Premiership</a> in England and the <a href="/wiki/Pro14" title="Pro14">Celtic League</a> in Ireland, Scotland, Wales and (since <a href="/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Celtic_League" title="2010\xe2\x80\x9311 Celtic League">2010</a>) Italy. Of Cornish origin, the chant \xe2\x80\x9c<a href="/wiki/Oggy_Oggy_Oggy" title="Oggy Oggy Oggy">Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi!</a>\xe2\x80\x9d is associated with rugby union (and its personalised variant with football); it inspired the \xe2\x80\x9c<a href="/wiki/Maggie_Out" title="Maggie Out">Maggie Maggie Maggie, Out Out Out!</a>" chant by opponents of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a> in the 1980s. In 1895, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Rugby League">rugby League</a> was created in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, as the result of a split with the other Rugby code. The <a href="/wiki/Super_League" title="Super League">Super League</a> is the sports top-level club competition in Britain, and the sport is especially popular in towns in the northern English counties of Yorkshire, Lancashire and Cumbria. The <a href="/wiki/Challenge_Cup" title="Challenge Cup">Challenge Cup</a> is the major rugby league cup competition.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Court_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Court_1.jpg/230px-Court_1.jpg" width="230" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Court_1.jpg/345px-Court_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Court_1.jpg/460px-Court_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="498" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Court_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/No._1_Court_(Wimbledon)" title="No. 1 Court (Wimbledon)">No. 1 Court</a> at <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>. First played in 1877, the Wimbledon Championships is the oldest tennis tournament in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-CNNTennis_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNNTennis-339">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Murray_A._US16_(10)_(29236489603).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg/170px-Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg" width="170" height="252" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg/255px-Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg/340px-Murray_A._US16_%2810%29_%2829236489603%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1055" data-file-height="1564" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Murray_A._US16_(10)_(29236489603).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a> has won three Grand Slams, including Wimbledon twice, and is the only two time Olympic singles champion.</div></div></div>\n<p>The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> originated in Birmingham, England in the 1860s, and after its creation, tennis spread throughout the upper-class English-speaking population, before spreading around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> Major <a href="/wiki/Walter_Clopton_Wingfield" title="Walter Clopton Wingfield">Walter Clopton Wingfield</a> is credited as being a pioneer of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> The world\'s oldest tennis tournament, the <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_championships" class="mw-redirect" title="Wimbledon championships">Wimbledon championships</a>, first occurred in 1877, and today the event takes place over two weeks in late June and early July.<sup id="cite_ref-CNNTennis_339-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNNTennis-339">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> Created in the Tudor period in the court of Henry VIII, the English dessert <a href="/wiki/Strawberry#Uses" title="Strawberry">Strawberries and cream</a> is synonymous with the British summer, and is famously consumed at Wimbledon. The tournament itself has a major place in the British cultural calendar. The eight-time Slam winner and Britain\'s most successful player <a href="/wiki/Fred_Perry" title="Fred Perry">Fred Perry</a> is one of only seven men in history to have won all four Grand Slam events, which included three Wimbledons.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Wade" title="Virginia Wade">Virginia Wade</a> won three Grand Slams, the most famous of which was Wimbledon in 1977, the year of the <a href="/wiki/Silver_Jubilee" class="mw-redirect" title="Silver Jubilee">Silver Jubilee</a> of Queen Elizabeth II (the Queen attended Wimbledon for the first time since 1962 to watch the final). The 2013 and 2016 Wimbledon champion, Scotland\'s <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a>, is Britain\'s most recent Grand Slam winner.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marquess_of_Queensberry_10_November_1877.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Marquess_of_Queensberry_10_November_1877.jpg/170px-Marquess_of_Queensberry_10_November_1877.jpg" width="170" height="288" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6f/Marquess_of_Queensberry_10_November_1877.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="219" data-file-height="371" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marquess_of_Queensberry_10_November_1877.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Vanity Fair</i> caricature of <a href="/wiki/John_Douglas,_9th_Marquess_of_Queensberry" title="John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry">John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry</a>. The caption reads "A good light weight".</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WGGrace.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/WGGrace.jpg/170px-WGGrace.jpg" width="170" height="272" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/WGGrace.jpg/255px-WGGrace.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/WGGrace.jpg/340px-WGGrace.jpg 2x" data-file-width="494" data-file-height="789" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WGGrace.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Cricketer <a href="/wiki/W._G._Grace" title="W. G. Grace">W. G. Grace</a>, with his long beard and MCC cap, was the most famous British sportsman in the Victorian era.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Marquess_of_Queensberry_rules" class="mw-redirect" title="Marquess of Queensberry rules">\'Queensberry rules\'</a>, the code of general rules in <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, was named after <a href="/wiki/John_Douglas,_9th_Marquess_of_Queensberry" title="John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry">John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry</a> in 1867, that formed the basis of modern boxing.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> Britain\'s first heavyweight world champion <a href="/wiki/Bob_Fitzsimmons" title="Bob Fitzsimmons">Bob Fitzsimmons</a> made boxing history as the sport\'s first three-division <a href="/wiki/World_champion" class="mw-redirect" title="World champion">world champion</a>. Some of the best contemporary British boxers included; super-middleweight champion <a href="/wiki/Joe_Calzaghe" title="Joe Calzaghe">Joe Calzaghe</a>, featherweight champion <a href="/wiki/Naseem_Hamed" title="Naseem Hamed">Naseem Hamed</a>, and heavyweight champion <a href="/wiki/Lennox_Lewis" title="Lennox Lewis">Lennox Lewis</a>. Calzaghe\'s display against Jeff Lacy in 2006 prompted Lacy\'s trainer to state "I have never seen a better performance than that in the world."<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a> was created in England in the 1830s when <a href="/wiki/Round_arm" class="mw-redirect" title="Round arm">round arm</a> bowling was legalised, followed by the historical legalisation of <a href="/wiki/Overarm_bowling" title="Overarm bowling">overarm bowling</a> in 1864.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup> In 1876\xe2\x80\x9377, <a href="/wiki/England_cricket_team" title="England cricket team">England</a> took part in the first-ever <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test match</a> against Australia. Hugely influential to the development and popularity of the sport, <a href="/wiki/W._G._Grace" title="W. G. Grace">W. G. Grace</a> is regarded as one of the greatest cricket players of all time, devising most of the techniques of modern batting.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> W. G. Grace\'s fame has endured and his large beard in particular remains familiar; for example, <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python_and_the_Holy_Grail" title="Monty Python and the Holy Grail">Monty Python and the Holy Grail</a></i> uses his image as "the face of God" during the sequence in which God sends the knights out on their quest for the grail. The rivalry between England and Australia gave birth to <a href="/wiki/The_Ashes" title="The Ashes">The Ashes</a> in 1882 that has remained Test cricket\'s most famous contest, and takes place every two years. The <a href="/wiki/County_Championship" title="County Championship">County Championship</a> is the domestic competition in England and Wales.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beecher%27s-Brook,-1890.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bf/Beecher%27s-Brook%2C-1890.jpg/220px-Beecher%27s-Brook%2C-1890.jpg" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/b/bf/Beecher%27s-Brook%2C-1890.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="283" data-file-height="195" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Beecher%27s-Brook,-1890.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1890 engraving of horses jumping the <a href="/wiki/Becher%27s_Brook" title="Becher&#39;s Brook">Becher\'s Brook</a> fence in the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National" title="Grand National">Grand National</a>. With Its treacherous fences combined with the distance (over 4 miles), the race has been called "the ultimate test of horse and rider".<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Originating in 17th and 18th-century England, the <a href="/wiki/Thoroughbred" title="Thoroughbred">Thoroughbred</a> is a horse breed best known for its use in <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a>. Horse racing was popular with the aristocrats and royalty of British society, earning it the title "Sport of Kings."<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> Named after <a href="/wiki/Edward_Smith-Stanley,_12th_Earl_of_Derby" title="Edward Smith-Stanley, 12th Earl of Derby">Edward Smith-Stanley, 12th Earl of Derby</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epsom_Derby" title="Epsom Derby">The Derby</a> was first run in 1780. The race serves as the middle leg of the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing#United_Kingdom" title="Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing">Triple Crown</a>, preceded by the <a href="/wiki/2000_Guineas_Stakes" title="2000 Guineas Stakes">2000 Guineas</a> and followed by the <a href="/wiki/St_Leger_Stakes" title="St Leger Stakes">St&#160;Leger</a>. The name "<a href="/wiki/Derby_(horse_race)" title="Derby (horse race)">Derby</a>" has since become synonymous with great races all over the world, and as such has been borrowed many times in races abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Hunt" class="mw-redirect" title="National Hunt">National Hunt</a> horse race the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National" title="Grand National">Grand National</a>, is held annually at <a href="/wiki/Aintree_Racecourse" title="Aintree Racecourse">Aintree Racecourse</a> in early April. It is the most watched horse race in the UK, attracting casual observers, and three-time winner <a href="/wiki/Red_Rum" title="Red Rum">Red Rum</a> is the most successful racehorse in the event\'s history. Red Rum is the best-known racehorse in the UK, named by 45% of Britons, with <a href="/wiki/Black_Beauty" title="Black Beauty">Black Beauty</a> (from <a href="/wiki/Anna_Sewell" title="Anna Sewell">Anna Sewell</a>\'s novel) in second with 33%.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg/170px-Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg" width="170" height="361" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg/255px-Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg/340px-Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg 2x" data-file-width="555" data-file-height="1179" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Harold_Abrahams_1921.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1924 Olympic 100 m champion <a href="/wiki/Harold_Abrahams" title="Harold Abrahams">Harold Abrahams</a> (whose feats are depicted in the 1981 film  <i><a href="/wiki/Chariots_of_Fire" title="Chariots of Fire">Chariots of Fire</a></i>) wearing J.W. Foster\'s pioneering <a href="/wiki/Running_spikes" class="mw-redirect" title="Running spikes">running spikes</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Bolton company <a href="/wiki/J.W._Foster_and_Sons" title="J.W. Foster and Sons">J.W. Foster and Sons</a>\'s pioneering <a href="/wiki/Running_spikes" class="mw-redirect" title="Running spikes">running spikes</a> appear in the book, <i>Golden Kicks: The Shoes that changed Sport</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Abrahams_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abrahams-351">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> They were made famous by 1924 100 m Olympic champion <a href="/wiki/Harold_Abrahams" title="Harold Abrahams">Harold Abrahams</a> who would be immortalised in <i><a href="/wiki/Chariots_of_Fire" title="Chariots of Fire">Chariots of Fire</a></i>, the British Oscar winning film.<sup id="cite_ref-Abrahams_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abrahams-351">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> Foster\'s grandsons formed the sportswear company <a href="/wiki/Reebok" title="Reebok">Reebok</a> in Bolton.<sup id="cite_ref-Abrahams_351-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abrahams-351">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/1950_British_Grand_Prix" title="1950 British Grand Prix">1950 British Grand Prix</a> was the first <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> World Championship race. Since then, Britain has produced some of the greatest drivers in the sport, including <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Moss" title="Stirling Moss">Stirling Moss</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Clark" title="Jim Clark">Jim Clark</a> (twice F1 champion), <a href="/wiki/Graham_Hill" title="Graham Hill">Graham Hill</a> (only driver to have won the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Motorsport" title="Triple Crown of Motorsport">Triple Crown</a>), <a href="/wiki/John_Surtees" title="John Surtees">John Surtees</a> (only world champion in two and four wheels), <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Stewart" title="Jackie Stewart">Jackie Stewart</a> (three time F1 champion), <a href="/wiki/James_Hunt" title="James Hunt">James Hunt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigel_Mansell" title="Nigel Mansell">Nigel Mansell</a> (only man to hold F1 and IndyCar titles at the same time), <a href="/wiki/Jenson_Button" title="Jenson Button">Jenson Button</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a>. The <a href="/wiki/British_Grand_Prix" title="British Grand Prix">British Grand Prix</a> is held at <a href="/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit" title="Silverstone Circuit">Silverstone</a> every July.\n</p><p>Other major sporting events in the UK include the <a href="/wiki/London_Marathon" title="London Marathon">London Marathon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Boat_Race" title="The Boat Race">The Boat Race</a> on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">River Thames</a>. Cycling is a popular physical activity in the UK. In 1888, inventor <a href="/wiki/Sir_Frank_Bowden,_1st_Baronet" title="Sir Frank Bowden, 1st Baronet">Frank Bowden</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Raleigh_Bicycle_Company" title="Raleigh Bicycle Company">Raleigh Bicycle Company</a>, and by 1913, Raleigh was the biggest bicycle manufacturing company in the world. The <a href="/wiki/Raleigh_Chopper" title="Raleigh Chopper">Raleigh Chopper</a> was named in the list of British design icons. In 1965 <a href="/wiki/Tom_Simpson" title="Tom Simpson">Tom Simpson</a> became the first British world road race champion, and in 2012 <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Wiggins" title="Bradley Wiggins">Bradley Wiggins</a> became the first British <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a> winner. <a href="/wiki/Chris_Froome" title="Chris Froome">Chris Froome</a> has subsequently won the Tour de France four times (2013, 2015, 2016 and 2017). Sprint specialist <a href="/wiki/Mark_Cavendish" title="Mark Cavendish">Mark Cavendish</a> has won thirty Tour de France stages, putting him second on the <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France_records_and_statistics#Stage_wins_per_rider" title="Tour de France records and statistics">all-time list</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg/220px-Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg/330px-Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg/440px-Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1133" data-file-height="908" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jayne_Torvill_and_Christopher_Dean_-_Dancing_on_Ice_2011.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ice dancers <a href="/wiki/Torvill_and_Dean" title="Torvill and Dean">Torvill and Dean</a> in 2011. Their historic gold-medal-winning performance at the 1984 Winter Olympics was watched by a British television audience of more than 24 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In <a href="/wiki/Ice_dancing" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice dancing">ice dancing</a>, many of the compulsory moves were developed by dancers from the UK in the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup> At the 1984 Winter Olympics, <a href="/wiki/Jayne_Torvill" title="Jayne Torvill">Jayne Torvill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Dean" title="Christopher Dean">Christopher Dean</a> won gold and became the highest scoring figure skaters (for a single programme) receiving twelve perfect 6.0s and six 5.9s which included artistic impression scores of 6.0 from every judge. At the 1988 Winter Olympics, ski jumper <a href="/wiki/Eddie_%22The_Eagle%22_Edwards" class="mw-redirect" title="Eddie &quot;The Eagle&quot; Edwards">Eddie "The Eagle" Edwards</a> gained fame as an underdog. Eddie was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Taron_Egerton" title="Taron Egerton">Taron Egerton</a> in the 2016 biographical sports comedy-drama film <i><a href="/wiki/Eddie_the_Eagle_(film)" title="Eddie the Eagle (film)">Eddie the Eagle</a></i>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mo_Farah_(2)_Moscow_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg/220px-Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg/330px-Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg/440px-Mo_Farah_%282%29_Moscow_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="566" data-file-height="378" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mo_Farah_(2)_Moscow_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mo_Farah" title="Mo Farah">Mo Farah</a> is the most successful British track athlete in modern Olympic Games history, winning the 5000&#160;m and 10,000&#160;m events at two Olympic Games.</div></div></div>\n<p>A great number of major sports originated in the United Kingdom, including association football, golf, tennis, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">snooker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darts" title="Darts">darts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billiards" class="mw-redirect" title="Billiards">billiards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squash_(sport)" title="Squash (sport)">squash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">curling</a> and badminton, all of which are popular in Britain. Another sport invented in the UK was baseball,<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> and its early form <a href="/wiki/Rounders" title="Rounders">rounders</a> is popular among children in Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> Snooker and darts are popular indoor games: <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hendry" title="Stephen Hendry">Stephen Hendry</a> is the seven time world snooker champion, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Taylor_(darts_player)" title="Phil Taylor (darts player)">Phil Taylor</a> is the 16 time world darts champion. Snooker player <a href="/wiki/Alex_Higgins" title="Alex Higgins">Alex Higgins</a> (nicknamed <i>The Hurricane</i>) and darts player <a href="/wiki/Eric_Bristow" title="Eric Bristow">Eric Bristow</a> (nicknamed <i>The Crafty Cockney</i>) are credited with popularising each sport.\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:306px;max-width:306px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:142px;max-width:142px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg/140px-David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg" width="140" height="210" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg/210px-David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg/280px-David_Beckham_2010_LA_Galaxy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1719" data-file-height="2574" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Known for his <a href="/wiki/Curl_(football)" title="Curl (football)">bending</a> free-kicks and range of passing, <a href="/wiki/David_Beckham" title="David Beckham">David Beckham</a> was voted <a href="/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Award" title="BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award">BBC Sports Personality of the Year</a> by the public in 2001</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:160px;max-width:160px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg/158px-Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg" width="158" height="211" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg/237px-Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg/316px-Graffiti_of_George_Best.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1704" data-file-height="2272" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Mural of <a href="/wiki/George_Best" title="George Best">George Best</a> in his home city Belfast. Known for his <a href="/wiki/Dummy_(football)" title="Dummy (football)">feints</a> while <a href="/wiki/Dribbling" title="Dribbling">dribbling</a>, Best was on the six man short list for <a href="/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Century" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC Sports Personality of the Century">BBC Sports Personality of the Century</a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>Bodybuilder <a href="/wiki/Reg_Park" title="Reg Park">Reg Park</a> was Mr Britain in 1946 and became <a href="/wiki/Universe_Championships#Winners" title="Universe Championships">Mr Universe</a> in 1951, 1958 and 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_football" title="Gaelic football">Gaelic football</a> is very popular in Northern Ireland, with many teams from the north winning the <a href="/wiki/All-Ireland_Senior_Football_Championship" title="All-Ireland Senior Football Championship">All-Ireland Senior Football Championship</a> since the early 2000s. <a href="/wiki/William_Penny_Brookes" title="William Penny Brookes">William Penny Brookes</a> was prominent in organising the format for the modern <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>, and In 1994, then <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">IOC</a> President <a href="/wiki/Juan_Antonio_Samaranch" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Antonio Samaranch">Juan Antonio Samaranch</a> laid a wreath on Brooke\'s grave, and said, "I came to pay homage and tribute to Dr Brookes, who really was the founder of the modern Olympic Games".<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Participation in women\'s team sport (in addition to profile in the media) has seen a rapid increase in recent years. Popular women\'s team sports include <a href="/wiki/Netball_Superleague" title="Netball Superleague">Netball Superleague</a> formed in 2005, the <a href="/wiki/FA_WSL" class="mw-redirect" title="FA WSL">FA WSL</a> (women\'s football) formed in 2010 (<a href="/wiki/Kelly_Smith" title="Kelly Smith">Kelly Smith</a> is seen as a leading figure in the game), <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Six_Nations_Championship" title="Women&#39;s Six Nations Championship">Women\'s Six Nations Championship</a> in rugby union, and <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Cricket_Super_League" title="Women&#39;s Cricket Super League">Women\'s Cricket Super League</a>.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Highland_games" title="Highland games">Highland games</a> are held throughout the year in Scotland as a way of celebrating Scottish and <a href="/wiki/Celt" class="mw-redirect" title="Celt">Celtic</a> culture and heritage, especially that of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>, with more than 60 games taking place across the country every year. Each December, the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Award" title="BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award">BBC Sports Personality of the Year</a> is announced, as voted for by the British public.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span id="System_of_measurement.2C_roads"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="System_of_measurement,_roads">System of measurement, roads</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: System of measurement, roads">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:197px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg/195px-Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg" width="195" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg/293px-Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg/390px-Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Britanski_merki_za_dalzhina_Grinuich_2005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yard" title="Yard">Yard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foot_(unit)" title="Foot (unit)">foot</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inch" title="Inch">inch</a> measurements at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Observatory</a>, London. The British public commonly measure distance in <a href="/wiki/Miles" class="mw-redirect" title="Miles">miles</a> and yards, height in feet and inches, weight in <a href="/wiki/Stone_(unit)" title="Stone (unit)">stone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pounds_(mass)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pounds (mass)">pounds</a>, speed in <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_hour" title="Miles per hour">miles per hour</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The use of the British <a href="/wiki/Imperial_units" title="Imperial units">imperial system of measure</a>, particularly among the public, is widespread in the United Kingdom and is in many cases permitted by the law.<sup id="cite_ref-WMroads_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WMroads-359">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Distance, height, weight and speed are the most common examples of such usage. An example of giving one\'s body weight would be: 11 and a half <a href="/wiki/Stone_(unit)" title="Stone (unit)">stone</a>, or 11 stone and 7 <a href="/wiki/Pounds_(mass)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pounds (mass)">pounds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> Body height is usually given in <a href="/wiki/Foot_(unit)" title="Foot (unit)">feet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inches" class="mw-redirect" title="Inches">inches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Road_London.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Abbey_Road_London.JPG/190px-Abbey_Road_London.JPG" width="190" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Abbey_Road_London.JPG/285px-Abbey_Road_London.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Abbey_Road_London.JPG/380px-Abbey_Road_London.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2032" data-file-height="1524" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Road_London.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Zebra_crossing" title="Zebra crossing">zebra crossing</a> in Abbey Road, London. This same crossing was featured on the cover of the album <i><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road" title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg/190px-Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg" width="190" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg/285px-Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg/380px-Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg 2x" data-file-width="938" data-file-height="542" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Spaghetti-Junction-Crop.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Gravelly_Hill_Interchange" title="Gravelly Hill Interchange">Gravelly Hill Interchange</a> in Birmingham, England - the original "<a href="/wiki/Spaghetti_Junction" title="Spaghetti Junction">Spaghetti Junction</a>". It is the most famous road junction in the UK.</div></div></div>\n<p>Distances shown on road signs must be in <a href="/wiki/Yard" title="Yard">yards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mile" title="Mile">miles</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_hour" title="Miles per hour">miles per hour</a> appear on speed limit signs and car speedometers.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> Imperial units (such as pounds and ounces) are legally permitted on UK goods after the European Commission announced in 2007 that it was to abandon the requirement for metric-only labelling on packaged goods in the UK and to allow dual metric\xe2\x80\x93imperial marking to continue indefinitely.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Drivers in Britain <a href="/wiki/Drive_on_the_left" class="mw-redirect" title="Drive on the left">drive on the left</a>. Research shows that countries driving on the left have a lower collision rates than those that drive on the right, and it has been suggested that this is partly because the predominantly better-performing right eye is used to monitor oncoming traffic and the driver\'s wing mirror.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> The name of the <a href="/wiki/Zebra_crossing" title="Zebra crossing">zebra crossing</a> is attributed to British <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Member of Parliament">MP</a> and subsequent Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/James_Callaghan" title="James Callaghan">James Callaghan</a>, who in 1948 visited the <a href="/wiki/Transport_Research_Laboratory" title="Transport Research Laboratory">Transport Research Laboratory</a> which was working on a new idea for safe pedestrian crossings. On being shown a design he is said to have remarked that it resembled a zebra.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> Located in <a href="/wiki/Birmingham" title="Birmingham">Birmingham</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gravelly_Hill_Interchange" title="Gravelly Hill Interchange">Gravelly Hill Interchange</a>\'s colloquial name "<a href="/wiki/Spaghetti_Junction" title="Spaghetti Junction">Spaghetti Junction</a>" was coined by journalists from the <i><a href="/wiki/Birmingham_Mail" title="Birmingham Mail">Birmingham Evening Mail</a></i> on 1 June 1965. In 1971, the <a href="/wiki/Green_Cross_Code" title="Green Cross Code">Green Cross Code</a> was introduced to teach children safer road crossing habits. From 1987, <a href="/wiki/Mungo_Jerry" title="Mungo Jerry">Mungo Jerry</a>\'s song "<a href="/wiki/In_the_Summertime" title="In the Summertime">In the Summertime</a>" featured in drink driving adverts. The building of <a href="/wiki/Roundabouts" class="mw-redirect" title="Roundabouts">roundabouts</a> (circular junctions) grew rapidly in the 1960s; there are now more than 10,000 in the UK <sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cat%27s_eye_(road)" title="Cat&#39;s eye (road)">Cat\'s eye</a> retroreflective safety device used in road marking was invented by <a href="/wiki/Percy_Shaw" title="Percy Shaw">Percy Shaw</a> in 1933.\n</p>\n<dl><dt>Cars</dt></dl>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg/220px-Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg/330px-Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg/440px-Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="360" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mini-ature_Parking_Space_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1169507.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Mini" title="Mini">mini</a> became an icon of 1960s British popular culture, and featured in the 1969 caper film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Italian_Job" title="The Italian Job">The Italian Job</a></i>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has had a long history of car making. Some of the best known British brands are <a href="/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Limited" title="Rolls-Royce Limited">Rolls Royce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bentley" title="Bentley">Bentley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin" title="Aston Martin">Aston Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_Cars" title="Jaguar Cars">Jaguar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Land_Rover" title="Land Rover">Land Rover</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mini" title="Mini">Mini</a>. Rolls-Royce was founded by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stewart_Rolls" class="mw-redirect" title="Charles Stewart Rolls">Charles Stewart Rolls</a> and Sir <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Henry_Royce" class="mw-redirect" title="Frederick Henry Royce">Frederick Henry Royce</a> in 1906. In addition to the company\'s reputation for superior engineering quality in its cars, Rolls-Royce Limited was known for manufacturing the high-powered "R" engines, including the iconic <a href="/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Merlin" title="Rolls-Royce Merlin">Rolls-Royce Merlin</a> aero engine which was used for many World War II aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> Bentley Motors Limited was founded by <a href="/wiki/W._O._Bentley" title="W. O. Bentley">W. O. Bentley</a> in 1919 in <a href="/wiki/Cricklewood" title="Cricklewood">Cricklewood</a>, North London, and, like Rolls Royce, is regarded as a British luxury automobile icon. Aston Martin was founded in 1913 by Lionel Martin and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Bamford" title="Robert Bamford">Robert Bamford</a>, and became associated with luxury grand touring cars in the 1950s and 1960s, and with the fictional British spy <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a>. Jaguar was founded in 1922. The <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_E-Type" title="Jaguar E-Type">Jaguar E-Type</a> sports car was released in 1961; <a href="/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari" title="Enzo Ferrari">Enzo Ferrari</a> called it "the most beautiful car ever made".<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup> Jaguar has, in recent years, manufactured cars for the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">British Prime Minister</a>. The company also holds <a href="/wiki/Royal_Warrant_of_Appointment_(United_Kingdom)" title="Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)">royal warrants</a> from Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charles,_Prince_of_Wales" title="Charles, Prince of Wales">Prince Charles</a>. The Land Rover launched in 1948 and specialises in <a href="/wiki/Four-wheel-drive" class="mw-redirect" title="Four-wheel-drive">four-wheel-drive</a>. Many models have been developed for the UK <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a> (MoD). The Mini was released by the <a href="/wiki/British_Motor_Corporation" title="British Motor Corporation">British Motor Corporation</a> in 1959 and became a 1960s cultural icon. The performance versions, the Mini Cooper, was a successful rally car. The distinctive two-door Mini was designed for BMC by <a href="/wiki/Sir_Alec_Issigonis" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Alec Issigonis">Sir Alec Issigonis</a>. It has been named Britain\'s favourite car in a poll.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<dl><dt>Sea, rail transport to continental Europe</dt></dl>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:220px;max-width:220px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:218px;max-width:218px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg/216px-South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg" width="216" height="106" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg/324px-South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg/432px-South_Foreland_Lighthouse_-_geograph.org.uk_-_588478.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="315" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/White_cliffs_of_Dover" class="mw-redirect" title="White cliffs of Dover">White cliffs of Dover</a> in south east England. The cliffs have great symbolic value in the UK because they face towards <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a> (<a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Dover" title="Strait of Dover">21 miles away</a>) across the narrowest part of the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>, where invasions have historically threatened and against which the cliffs form a symbolic guard</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:218px;max-width:218px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:France_manche_vue_dover.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/France_manche_vue_dover.JPG/216px-France_manche_vue_dover.JPG" width="216" height="94" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/France_manche_vue_dover.JPG/324px-France_manche_vue_dover.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/France_manche_vue_dover.JPG/432px-France_manche_vue_dover.JPG 2x" data-file-width="593" data-file-height="258" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">White cliffs of Dover in the distance seen from <a href="/wiki/Cap_Gris_Nez" class="mw-redirect" title="Cap Gris Nez">Cap Gris Nez</a>, France</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Before air travel, boats were the only way to travel from the UK to the European mainland (<a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a>). The shortest route (21 miles or 34&#160;km) is from <a href="/wiki/Dover" title="Dover">Dover</a> in England to <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">Calais</a> in France. The <a href="/wiki/White_Cliffs_of_Dover" title="White Cliffs of Dover">White Cliffs of Dover</a> are at one end of the <a href="/wiki/Kent_Downs" title="Kent Downs">Kent Downs</a> designated <a href="/wiki/Area_of_Outstanding_Natural_Beauty" title="Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty">Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty</a>. The cliff face goes up to 350 feet and the cliffs stretch for 8 miles of coastline. The <a href="/wiki/National_Trust_for_Places_of_Historic_Interest_or_Natural_Beauty" title="National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty">National Trust</a> calls the cliffs "an icon of Britain", with "the white chalk face a symbol of home and war time defence."<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> The white line of cliffs was thus the first or last sight of Britain for travellers. In World War II, thousands of allied troops on the little ships in the <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation" title="Dunkirk evacuation">Dunkirk evacuation</a> saw the welcoming sight of the cliffs.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Dover" title="Port of Dover">Port of Dover</a> is the world\'s busiest passenger port, with 16 million travellers, 2.1 million lorries, 2.8 million cars and motorcycles and 86,000 coaches passing through it each year.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/P%26O_Ferries" title="P&amp;O Ferries">P&amp;O Ferries</a> is the UK\'s largest ferry operator at Dover. Built in 1994, the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Railway">rail</a> tunnel linking <a href="/wiki/Folkestone" title="Folkestone">Folkestone</a>, Kent, in England with <a href="/wiki/Coquelles" title="Coquelles">Coquelles</a> in northern France, beneath the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Dover" title="Strait of Dover">Strait of Dover</a>. The rail tunnel stretches for 31 miles (50&#160;km), and at its lowest point the tunnel is 250 feet (about 76 metres) under the sea. The tunnel carries high-speed <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> passenger trains, the <a href="/wiki/Eurotunnel_Shuttle" title="Eurotunnel Shuttle">Eurotunnel Shuttle</a> for road vehicles\xe2\x80\x94the largest such transport in the world\xe2\x80\x94and <a href="/wiki/Freight_train" class="mw-redirect" title="Freight train">freight trains</a>.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Healthcare">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Coloured_mezzotint;_Florence_Nightingale,_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg/200px-Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg" width="200" height="251" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg/300px-Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg/400px-Coloured_mezzotint%3B_Florence_Nightingale%2C_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3687" data-file-height="4634" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Coloured_mezzotint;_Florence_Nightingale,_Wellcome_L0019661.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The founder of modern <a href="/wiki/Nursing" title="Nursing">nursing</a> <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale" title="Florence Nightingale">Florence Nightingale</a> tending to a patient in 1855. An icon of Victorian Britain, she is known as <i>The Lady with the Lamp</i>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Each of the four countries of the UK has a publicly funded <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">health care</a> system referred to as the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> (NHS). The terms "National Health Service" or "NHS" are also used to refer to the four systems collectively. All of the services were founded in 1948, based on legislation passed by the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour</a> Government that had been elected in 1945 with a manifesto commitment to implement the <a href="/wiki/Beveridge_Report" title="Beveridge Report">Beveridge Report</a> recommendation to create "comprehensive health and rehabilitation services for prevention and cure of disease".<sup id="cite_ref-Beveridge_Report_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beveridge_Report-373">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg/180px-Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg" width="180" height="267" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg/270px-Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg/360px-Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="424" data-file-height="628" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kate_Beckinsale_TIFF_2008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/British_Heart_Foundation" title="British Heart Foundation">British Heart Foundation</a>, which actress <a href="/wiki/Kate_Beckinsale" title="Kate Beckinsale">Kate Beckinsale</a> (<i>pictured</i>) has supported, is the biggest funder of <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular">cardiovascular</a> research in the UK.</div></div></div>\n<p>The NHS was born out of a long-held ideal that good healthcare should be available to all, regardless of wealth. At its launch by the then minister of health, <a href="/wiki/Aneurin_Bevan" title="Aneurin Bevan">Aneurin Bevan</a>, on 5 July 1948, it had at its heart three core principles: That it meet the needs of everyone, that it be free at the point of delivery, and that it be based on clinical need, not ability to pay.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The NHS had a prominent slot during the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony#Second_to_the_right,_and_straight_on_till_morning_(21:35\xe2\x80\x9321:47)" title="2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony">2012 London Summer Olympics opening ceremony</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a>, being described as "the institution which more than any other unites our nation", according to the programme.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup>  <a href="/wiki/Cancer_Research_UK" title="Cancer Research UK">Cancer Research UK</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_Research_UK" title="Alzheimer&#39;s Research UK">Alzheimer\'s Research UK</a> and <a href="/wiki/Together_for_Short_Lives" title="Together for Short Lives">Together for Short Lives</a> are among hundreds of health charities in the UK.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale" title="Florence Nightingale">Florence Nightingale</a> laid the foundation of modern <a href="/wiki/Nursing" title="Nursing">nursing</a> with the establishment of her <a href="/wiki/Nursing_school" title="Nursing school">nursing school</a> at <a href="/wiki/St_Thomas%27_Hospital" title="St Thomas&#39; Hospital">St Thomas\' Hospital</a> in London. It was the <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale_Faculty_of_Nursing_and_Midwifery" title="Florence Nightingale Faculty of Nursing and Midwifery">first secular nursing school in the world</a>, now part of <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King&#39;s College London">King\'s College London</a>. Nightingale wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Notes_on_Nursing" title="Notes on Nursing">Notes on Nursing</a></i> in 1859. The book served as the cornerstone of the curriculum at the Nightingale School and other nursing schools.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Nightingale_Pledge" title="Nightingale Pledge">Nightingale Pledge</a> is taken by new nurses, and the annual <a href="/wiki/International_Nurses_Day" title="International Nurses Day">International Nurses Day</a> (12 May) is celebrated around the world on her birthday. Her social reforms improved healthcare for all sections of society in the UK and around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Pets">Pets</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Pets">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a href="/wiki/File:English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg/230px-English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg" width="230" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg/345px-English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg/460px-English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1064" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:English_Bulldog_about_to_sleep.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>One of Britain\'s oldest indigenous breeds, the <a href="/wiki/Bulldog" title="Bulldog">Bulldog</a> is known as the national dog of Great Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a
